83ba99b8-9b73-4401-9dd8-76d9e0e9b6dc@1@interferes@step in@1@intervene,step in,@"Asthma is a condition in which your airways narrow and swell and produce extra mucus. This can make breathing difficult and trigger coughing, wheezing and shortness of breath.  For some people, asthma is a minor nuisance. For others, it can be a major problem that interferes with daily activities and may lead to a life-threatening asthma attack.  Asthma can't be cured, but its symptoms can be controlled. Because asthma often changes over time, it's important that you work with your doctor to track your signs and symptoms and adjust treatment as needed."
83ba99b8-9b73-4401-9dd8-76d9e0e9b6dc@1@interferes@step in@1@intervene,step in,@"Asthma is a condition in which your airways narrow and swell and produce extra mucus. This can make breathing difficult and trigger coughing, wheezing and shortness of breath.  For some people, asthma is a minor nuisance. For others, it can be a major problem that interferes with daily activities and may lead to a life-threatening asthma attack.  Asthma can't be cured, but its symptoms can be controlled. Because asthma often changes over time, it's important that you work with your doctor to track your signs and symptoms and adjust treatment as needed."
5079683c-43c6-4429-9084-64f6caa9356c@1@fever@fever@0@body temperature increased,temperature increase,increased body temperature,increases temperature,increase temperature,raised temperature,high body temperature,high temperature,@"Valley fever, also called coccidioidomycosis, is an infection caused by the fungus Coccidioides. The fungus is known to live in the soil in the southwestern United States and parts of Mexico and Central and South America. The fungus was also recently found in south-central Washington. People can get Valley fever by breathing in the microscopic fungal spores from the air, although most people who breathe in the spores don’t get sick. Usually, people who get sick with Valley fever will get better on their own within weeks to months, but some people will need antifungal medication. Certain groups of people are at higher risk for becoming severely ill. It’s difficult to prevent exposure to Coccidioides in areas where it’s common in the environment, but people who are at higher risk for severe Valley fever should try to avoid breathing in large amounts of dust if they’re in these areas."
5079683c-43c6-4429-9084-64f6caa9356c@4@endemic@endemic@0@[endem] [ic] :	[endem] [pertaining to],@"Coccidioidomycosis, commonly known as cocci,[1] Valley fever,[1] as well as California fever,[2] desert rheumatism,[2] and San Joaquin Valley fever,[2] is a mammalian fungal disease caused by Coccidioides immitis or Coccidioides posadasii.[3] Coccidioidomycosis is endemic in certain parts of the US in Arizona, California, Nevada, New Mexico, Texas, Utah, and northern Mexico.[4]"
5079683c-43c6-4429-9084-64f6caa9356c@6@acquired@acquired@0@get,assume,take on,take,grow,develop,produce,gain,learn,@"Coccidioidomycosis is a common cause of community-acquired pneumonia in the southwest United States, Mexico, and South America. The disease has seen a marked increase in incidence in the western United States in the last decade and can be acquired by individuals who travel even briefly through an endemic area, presenting a diagnostic dilemma for clinicians who are not familiar with the disease. The clinical and radiographic manifestations of pulmonary coccidioidomycosis often mimic those of other causes of pneumonia. "

5079683c-43c6-4429-9084-64f6caa9356c@6@coccidioidomycosis@Valley fever@1@valley fever,desert rheumatism,san joaquin valley fever,desert fever,disease posada wernicke,@"Coccidioidomycosis is a common cause of community-acquired pneumonia in the southwest United States, Mexico, and South America. The disease has seen a marked increase in incidence in the western United States in the last decade and can be acquired by individuals who travel even briefly through an endemic area, presenting a diagnostic dilemma for clinicians who are not familiar with the disease. The clinical and radiographic manifestations of pulmonary coccidioidomycosis often mimic those of other causes of pneumonia. "
f5f664cf-a0d5-483d-84cc-f09c2f8a515e@3@distinct@distinct@0@[dis] [tinct] :	[separation, taking apart] [tint],@"Pemphigus is a general term for a group of rare autoimmune blistering skin disorders. Autoimmune disorders occur when the body's own immune system mistakenly attacks healthy tissue. The symptoms and severity associated with the various forms of pemphigus vary. All forms of pemphigus are characterized by the development of blistering eruptions on the outer layer of the skin (epidermis). In pemphigus vulgaris, lesions also develop on the mucous membranes such as those lining the inside the mouth. Mucous membranes are the thin, moist coverings of many of the body's internal surfaces. If left untreated, pemphigus will usually be fatal. The exact cause of pemphigus is unknown.  The term pemphigus is a general term for a group of related autoimmune blistering skin diseases. The two main types of pemphigus are pemphigus vulgaris and pemphigus foliaceus. Each type has subtypes. Additional disorders are sometimes classified as pemphigus including paraneoplastic pemphigus and pemphigus IgA. Some physicians consider these disorders similar, yet distinct, autoimmune blistering disorders with different causes and clinical, immunological and microscopic tissue (histological) features. Pemphigoid is a general term for a different group of skin disorders. These other disorders are discussed in the related disorders section of this report."
f5f664cf-a0d5-483d-84cc-f09c2f8a515e@3@autoimmune@autoimmune@0@[auto] [immune] :	[self] [resistant],@"Pemphigus is a general term for a group of rare autoimmune blistering skin disorders. Pemphigoid is a general term for a different group of skin disorders. These other disorders are discussed in the related disorders section of this report."
f5f664cf-a0d5-483d-84cc-f09c2f8a515e@4@disorders@disorders@0@diseases,@"Pemphigus is a general term for a group of rare autoimmune blistering skin disorders. Autoimmune disorders occur when the body's own immune system mistakenly attacks healthy tissue. The symptoms and severity associated with the various forms of pemphigus vary. All forms of pemphigus are characterized by the development of blistering eruptions on the outer layer of the skin (epidermis). In pemphigus vulgaris, lesions also develop on the mucous membranes such as those lining the inside the mouth. Mucous membranes are the thin, moist coverings of many of the body's internal surfaces. If left untreated, pemphigus will usually be fatal. The exact cause of pemphigus is unknown.  The term pemphigus is a general term for a group of related autoimmune blistering skin diseases. The two main types of pemphigus are pemphigus vulgaris and pemphigus foliaceus. Each type has subtypes. Additional disorders are sometimes classified as pemphigus including paraneoplastic pemphigus and pemphigus IgA. Some physicians consider these disorders similar, yet distinct, autoimmune blistering disorders with different causes and clinical, immunological and microscopic tissue (histological) features. Pemphigoid is a general term for a different group of skin disorders. These other disorders are discussed in the related disorders section of this report."

If left untreated, pemphigus will usually be fatal. The exact cause of pemphigus is unknown.  The term pemphigus is a general term for a group of related autoimmune blistering skin diseases. The two main types of pemphigus are pemphigus vulgaris and pemphigus foliaceus. Each type has subtypes. Additional disorders are sometimes classified as pemphigus including paraneoplastic pemphigus and pemphigus IgA. Some physicians consider these disorders similar, yet distinct, autoimmune blistering disorders with different causes and clinical, immunological and microscopic tissue (histological) features. Pemphigoid is a general term for a different group of skin disorders. These other disorders are discussed in the related disorders section of this report."
f5f664cf-a0d5-483d-84cc-f09c2f8a515e@7@untreated@untreated@0@did not receive therapy or drug for,not treatabl,@"Pemphigus is a general term for a group of rare autoimmune blistering skin disorders. Autoimmune disorders occur when the body's own immune system mistakenly attacks healthy tissue. The symptoms and severity associated with the various forms of pemphigus vary. All forms of pemphigus are characterized by the development of blistering eruptions on the outer layer of the skin (epidermis). In pemphigus vulgaris, lesions also develop on the mucous membranes such as those lining the inside the mouth. Mucous membranes are the thin, moist coverings of many of the body's internal surfaces. If left untreated, pemphigus will usually be fatal. The exact cause of pemphigus is unknown.  The term pemphigus is a general term for a group of related autoimmune blistering skin diseases. The two main types of pemphigus are pemphigus vulgaris and pemphigus foliaceus. Each type has subtypes. Additional disorders are sometimes classified as pemphigus including paraneoplastic pemphigus and pemphigus IgA. Some physicians consider these disorders similar, yet distinct, autoimmune blistering disorders with different causes and clinical, immunological and microscopic tissue (histological) features. Pemphigoid is a general term for a different group of skin disorders. These other disorders are discussed in the related disorders section of this report."
f5f664cf-a0d5-483d-84cc-f09c2f8a515e@11@pemphigus@pemphigus@0@[pe] [mphigus] :	[penis] [mphigus],@"Pemphigus is a general term for a group of rare autoimmune blistering skin conditions. Autoimmune conditions occur when the body's own immune system mistakenly attacks healthy tissue. The symptoms and intensity associated with the various forms of pemphigus vary. All forms of pemphigus are characterized by the development of blistering outbreaks on the outside layer of the skin (epidermis). In pemphigus vulgaris, wounds also develop on the mucous membrane tissues such as those running along the inside the mouth. Mucous membranes are the thin, wet coverings of many of the body's internal surfaces. If not treated, pemphigus will usually be fatal. The exact cause of pemphigus is not known.  The term pemphigus is a general term for a group of related autoimmune blistering skin diseases. The two main types of pemphigus are pemphigus vulgaris and pemphigus foliaceus. Each type has subtypes. Additional disorders are sometimes classified as pemphigus including paraneoplastic pemphigus and pemphigus IgA. Pemphigoid is a general term for a different group of skin disorders. These other disorders are discussed in the related disorders section of this report."

f5f664cf-a0d5-483d-84cc-f09c2f8a515e@11@lesions@wound@1@wound,@"Pemphigus is a general term for a group of rare autoimmune blistering skin conditions. Autoimmune conditions occur when the body's own immune system mistakenly attacks healthy tissue. The symptoms and intensity associated with the various forms of pemphigus vary. All forms of pemphigus are characterized by the development of blistering outbreaks on the outside layer of the skin (epidermis). In pemphigus vulgaris, wounds also develop on the mucous membrane tissues such as those running along the inside the mouth. Mucous membranes are the thin, wet coverings of many of the body's internal surfaces. If not treated, pemphigus will usually be fatal. The exact cause of pemphigus is not known.  The term pemphigus is a general term for a group of related autoimmune blistering skin diseases. The two main types of pemphigus are pemphigus vulgaris and pemphigus foliaceus. Each type has subtypes. Additional disorders are sometimes classified as pemphigus including paraneoplastic pemphigus and pemphigus IgA. Some physicians consider these disorders similar, yet distinct, autoimmune blistering disorders with different causes and clinical, immunological and microscopic tissue (histological) features. Pemphigoid is a general term for a different group of skin disorders. These other disorders are discussed in the related disorders section of this report."
f5f664cf-a0d5-483d-84cc-f09c2f8a515e@11@mucous@mucous@0@mucus,portion of mucus,mucus layer,@"Pemphigus is a general term for a group of rare autoimmune blistering skin conditions. Each type has subtypes. Additional disorders are sometimes classified as pemphigus including paraneoplastic pemphigus and pemphigus IgA. Some doctors consider these conditions similar, yet distinct, autoimmune blistering conditions with different causes and clinical, immunological and microscopic tissue (histological) features. Pemphigoid is a general term for a different group of skin conditions. These other conditions are talked about in the related conditions section of this report."
cf1572ab-c6ac-4012-8f7f-d2d9b26d0031@0@classified@classified@0@null@"Pemphigus is a general term for a group of rare autoimmune blistering skin conditions. Autoimmune conditions occur when the body's own immune system mistakenly attacks healthy tissue. The symptoms and intensity associated with the various forms of pemphigus vary. All forms of pemphigus are characterized by the development of blistering outbreaks on the outside layer of the skin (epidermis). In pemphigus vulgaris, wounds also develop on the mucous membrane tissues such as those running along the inside the mouth. Mucous membranes are the thin, wet coverings of many of the body's internal surfaces. If not treated, pemphigus will usually be fatal. The exact cause of pemphigus is not known.  The term pemphigus is a general term for a group of related autoimmune blistering skin conditions. The two main types of pemphigus are pemphigus vulgaris and pemphigus foliaceus. Each type has subtypes. Additional conditions are sometimes classified as pemphigus including paraneoplastic pemphigus and pemphigus IgA. Some doctors consider these conditions similar, yet distinct, autoimmune blistering conditions with different causes and clinical, immunological and microscopic tissue (histological) features. Pemphigoid is a general term for a different group of skin conditions. These other conditions are talked about in the related conditions section of this report."

c82027c0-8f69-4a23-9f21-250e5aa1cc58@3@intersections@intersections@0@intersection point,point of intersection,product,overlap,convergence,@"Intersections of Race/ethnicity and Culture: As a matter of course, work on culture tends to ignore or give passing service to how the rationales and findings concerning culture and education must interact with the psychological impacts of race/ethnicity in those same transactions. The choice makes some sense in the theoretical and empirical literature but also handicaps our efforts to understand the bigger picture and distances the work from its important practical potential. In this group of projects, I am working toward developing an integrative theoretical model by centralizing consideration of how race/ethnicity and culture interact. "
c82027c0-8f69-4a23-9f21-250e5aa1cc58@3@interact@interact@0@[inter] [act] :	[between, among] [milk],@"Intersections of Race/ethnicity and Culture: As a matter of course, work on culture tends to ignore or give passing service to how the rationales and findings concerning culture and education must interact with the psychological impacts of race/ethnicity in those same transactions. The choice makes some sense in the theoretical and empirical literature but also handicaps our efforts to understand the bigger picture and distances the work from its important practical potential. In this group of projects, I am working toward developing an integrative theoretical model by centralizing consideration of how race/ethnicity and culture interact. "
c82027c0-8f69-4a23-9f21-250e5aa1cc58@3@interact@interact@0@[inter] [act] :	[between, among] [milk],@"Intersections of Race/ethnicity and Culture: As a matter of course, work on culture tends to ignore or give passing service to how the rationales and findings concerning culture and education must interact with the psychological impacts of race/ethnicity in those same transactions. c82027c0-8f69-4a23-9f21-250e5aa1cc58@3@theoretical@theory@1@theory,@"Intersections of Race/ethnicity and Culture: As a matter of course, work on culture tends to ignore or give passing service to how the rationales and findings concerning culture and education must interact with the psychological impacts of race/ethnicity in those same transactions. The choice makes some sense in the theoretical and empirical literature but also handicaps our efforts to understand the bigger picture and distances the work from its important practical potential. In this group of projects, I am working toward developing an integrative theoretical model by centralizing consideration of how race/ethnicity and culture interact. "
589b7ed5-ff30-4c28-978b-058c400ea8b9@1@polycythemia@polycythemia@0@abnormally shaped erythrocytes,@"Polycythemia vera is a rare, chronic disorder involving the overproduction of blood cells in the bone marrow (myeloproliferation). The overproduction of red blood cells is most dramatic. But the production of white blood cells and platelets are also elevated in most cases. Since red blood cells are overproduced in the marrow, this leads to abnormally high numbers of circulating red blood cells (red blood mass) within the blood. Consequently, the blood thickens and increases in volume, a condition called hyperviscosity. Thickened blood may not flow through smaller blood vessels properly. A variety of symptoms can occur in individuals with polycythemia vera including nonspecific symptoms such as headaches, fatigue, weakness, dizziness or itchy skin; an enlarged spleen (splenomegaly); a variety of gastrointestinal issues; and the risk of blood clot formation, which may prevent blood flow to vital organs. More than 90 percent of individuals with polycythemia vera have a mutation of the JAK2 gene. The exact role of this mutation in the development of polycythemia vera is not yet known.  Polycythemia vera belongs to a group of diseases known as the myeloproliferative disorders (MPDs). Three other disorders are commonly classified as MPDs: chronic myeloid leukemia, essential thrombocythemia and idiopathic myelofibrosis. "
589b7ed5-ff30-4c28-978b-058c400ea8b9@1@rare@rare@0@not very often,@"Polycythemia vera is a rare, chronic disorder involving the overproduction of blood cells in the bone marrow (myeloproliferation). The overproduction of red blood cells is most dramatic. But the production of white blood cells and platelets are also elevated in most cases. Since red blood cells are overproduced in the marrow, this leads to abnormally high numbers of circulating red blood cells (red blood mass) within the blood. Consequently, the blood thickens and increases in volume, a condition called hyperviscosity. Thickened blood may not flow through smaller blood vessels properly. A variety of symptoms can occur in individuals with polycythemia vera including nonspecific symptoms such as headaches, fatigue, weakness, dizziness or itchy skin; an enlarged spleen (splenomegaly); a variety of gastrointestinal issues; and the risk of blood clot formation, which may prevent blood flow to vital organs. More than 90 percent of individuals with polycythemia vera have a mutation of the JAK2 gene. The exact role of this mutation in the development of polycythemia vera is not yet known.  Polycythemia vera belongs to a group of diseases known as the myeloproliferative disorders (MPDs). Three other disorders are commonly classified as MPDs: chronic myeloid leukemia, essential thrombocythemia and idiopathic myelofibrosis. "
589b7ed5-ff30-4c28-978b-058c400ea8b9@1@chronic@chronic@0@[chron] [ic] :	[chron] [pertaining to],@"Polycythemia vera is a rare, chronic disorder involving the overproduction of blood cells in the bone marrow (myeloproliferation). The overproduction of red blood cells is most dramatic. But the production of white blood cells and platelets are also elevated in most cases. Since red blood cells are overproduced in the marrow, this leads to abnormally high numbers of circulating red blood cells (red blood mass) within the blood. Consequently, the blood thickens and increases in volume, a condition called hyperviscosity. Thickened blood may not flow through smaller blood vessels properly. A variety of symptoms can occur in individuals with polycythemia vera including nonspecific symptoms such as headaches, fatigue, weakness, dizziness or itchy skin; an enlarged spleen (splenomegaly); a variety of gastrointestinal issues; and the risk of blood clot formation, which may prevent blood flow to vital organs. More than 90 percent of individuals with polycythemia vera have a mutation of the JAK2 gene. The exact role of this mutation in the development of polycythemia vera is not yet known.  Polycythemia vera belongs to a group of diseases known as the myeloproliferative disorders (MPDs). Three other disorders are commonly classified as MPDs: chronic myeloid leukemia, essential thrombocythemia and idiopathic myelofibrosis. "

The overproduction of red blood cells is most dramatic. But the production of white blood cells and platelets are also elevated in most cases. Consequently, the blood thickens and increases in volume, a condition called hyperviscosity. Thickened blood may not flow through smaller blood vessels properly. A variety of symptoms can occur in individuals with polycythemia vera including nonspecific symptoms such as headaches, fatigue, weakness, dizziness or itchy skin; an enlarged spleen (splenomegaly); a variety of gastrointestinal issues; and the risk of blood clot formation, which may prevent blood flow to vital organs. More than 90 percent of individuals with polycythemia vera have a mutation of the JAK2 gene. The exact role of this mutation in the development of polycythemia vera is not yet known.  Polycythemia vera belongs to a group of diseases known as the myeloproliferative disorders (MPDs). Three other disorders are commonly classified as MPDs: chronic myeloid leukemia, essential thrombocythemia and idiopathic myelofibrosis. "

Since red blood cells are overproduced in the marrow, this leads to abnormally high numbers of circulating red blood cells (red blood mass) within the blood. Consequently, the blood thickens and increases in volume, a condition called hyperviscosity. Thickened blood may not flow through smaller blood vessels properly. A variety of symptoms can occur in individuals with polycythemia vera including nonspecific symptoms such as headaches, fatigue, weakness, dizziness or itchy skin; an enlarged spleen (splenomegaly); a variety of gastrointestinal issues; and the risk of blood clot formation, which may prevent blood flow to vital organs. The overproduction of red blood cells is most dramatic. But the production of white blood cells and platelets are also elevated in most cases. Since red blood cells are overproduced in the marrow, this leads to abnormally high numbers of circulating red blood cells (red blood mass) within the blood. Consequently, the blood thickens and increases in volume, a condition called hyperviscosity. Thickened blood may not flow through smaller blood vessels properly. A variety of symptoms can occur in individuals with polycythemia vera including nonspecific symptoms such as headaches, fatigue, weakness, dizziness or itchy skin; an enlarged spleen (splenomegaly); a variety of gastrointestinal issues; and the risk of blood clot formation, which may prevent blood flow to vital organs. More than 90 percent of individuals with polycythemia vera have a mutation of the JAK2 gene. The exact role of this mutation in the development of polycythemia vera is not yet known.  Polycythemia vera belongs to a group of diseases known as the myeloproliferative disorders (MPDs). Three other disorders are commonly classified as MPDs: chronic myeloid leukemia, essential thrombocythemia and idiopathic myelofibrosis.  "

Three other disorders are commonly classified as MPDs: chronic myeloid leukemia, essential thrombocythemia and idiopathic myelofibrosis.  "
589b7ed5-ff30-4c28-978b-058c400ea8b9@4@overproduction@overproduction@0@Use verb form: overproduce,@"Polycythemia vera is a rare, chronic disorder involving the overproduction of blood cells in the bone marrow (myeloproliferation). The overproduction of red blood cells is most dramatic. But the production of white blood cells and platelets are also elevated in most cases. Since red blood cells are overproduced in the marrow, this leads to abnormally high numbers of circulating red blood cells (red blood mass) within the blood. Consequently, the blood thickens and increases in volume, a condition called hyperviscosity. Thickened blood may not flow through smaller blood vessels properly. A variety of symptoms can occur in individuals with polycythemia vera including nonspecific symptoms such as headaches, fatigue, weakness, dizziness or itchy skin; an enlarged spleen (splenomegaly); a variety of gastrointestinal issues; and the risk of blood clot formation, which may prevent blood flow to vital organs. More than 90 percent of individuals with polycythemia vera have a mutation of the JAK2 gene. The exact role of this mutation in the development of polycythemia vera is not yet known.  Polycythemia vera belongs to a group of diseases known as the myeloproliferative disorders (MPDs). Three other disorders are commonly classified as MPDs: chronic myeloid leukemia, essential thrombocythemia and idiopathic myelofibrosis.  "
589b7ed5-ff30-4c28-978b-058c400ea8b9@4@dramatic@dramatic@0@[drama] [tic] :	[play] [pertaining to],@"Polycythemia vera is a rare, chronic disorder involving the overproduction of blood cells in the bone marrow (myeloproliferation). The overproduction of red blood cells is most dramatic. But the production of white blood cells and platelets are also elevated in most cases. Three other disorders are commonly classified as MPDs: chronic myeloid leukemia, essential thrombocythemia and idiopathic myelofibrosis.  "

More than 90 percent of individuals with polycythemia vera have a mutation of the JAK2 gene. The exact role of this mutation in the development of polycythemia vera is not yet known.  Polycythemia vera belongs to a group of diseases known as the myeloproliferative disorders (MPDs). Three other disorders are commonly classified as MPDs: chronic myeloid leukemia, essential thrombocythemia and idiopathic myelofibrosis.  "
589b7ed5-ff30-4c28-978b-058c400ea8b9@4@nonspecific@nonspecific@0@not specific,@"Polycythemia vera is a rare, chronic disorder involving the overproduction of blood cells in the bone marrow (myeloproliferation). The overproduction of red blood cells is most dramatic. But the production of white blood cells and platelets are also elevated in most cases. Since red blood cells are overproduced in the marrow, this leads to abnormally high numbers of circulating red blood cells (red blood mass) within the blood. Consequently, the blood thickens and increases in volume, a condition called hyperviscosity. Thickened blood may not flow through smaller blood vessels properly. A variety of symptoms can occur in individuals with polycythemia vera including nonspecific symptoms such as headaches, fatigue, weakness, dizziness or itchy skin; an enlarged spleen (splenomegaly); a variety of gastrointestinal issues; and the risk of blood clot formation, which may prevent blood flow to vital organs. More than 90 percent of individuals with polycythemia vera have a mutation of the JAK2 gene. The exact role of this mutation in the development of polycythemia vera is not yet known.  Polycythemia vera belongs to a group of diseases known as the myeloproliferative disorders (MPDs). Three other disorders are commonly classified as MPDs: chronic myeloid leukemia, essential thrombocythemia and idiopathic myelofibrosis.  "

Polycythemia vera belongs to a group of diseases known as the myeloproliferative disorders (MPDs). Three other disorders are commonly classified as MPDs: chronic myeloid leukemia, essential thrombocythemia and idiopathic myelofibrosis.  "
589b7ed5-ff30-4c28-978b-058c400ea8b9@4@myeloid@myeloid@0@[myelo] [oid] :	[marrow, bone marrow] [resemblance to],@"Polycythemia vera is a rare, chronic disorder involving the overproduction of blood cells in the bone marrow (myeloproliferation). The overproduction of red blood cells is most dramatic. But the production of white blood cells and platelets are also elevated in most cases. Since red blood cells are overproduced in the marrow, this leads to abnormally high numbers of circulating red blood cells (red blood mass) within the blood. Consequently, the blood thickens and increases in volume, a condition called hyperviscosity. Thickened blood may not flow through smaller blood vessels properly. A variety of symptoms can occur in individuals with polycythemia vera including nonspecific symptoms such as headaches, fatigue, weakness, dizziness or itchy skin; an enlarged spleen (splenomegaly); a variety of gastrointestinal issues; and the risk of blood clot formation, which may prevent blood flow to vital organs. More than 90 percent of individuals with polycythemia vera have a mutation of the JAK2 gene. The exact role of this mutation in the development of polycythemia vera is not yet known.  Polycythemia vera belongs to a group of diseases known as the myeloproliferative disorders (MPDs). Three other disorders are commonly classified as MPDs: chronic myeloid leukemia, essential thrombocythemia and idiopathic myelofibrosis.  "

Consequently, the blood thickens and increases in volume, a condition called hyperviscosity. Thickened blood may not flow through smaller blood vessels properly. A variety of symptoms can occur in individuals with polycythemia vera including nonspecific symptoms such as headaches, fatigue, weakness, dizziness or itchy skin; an enlarged spleen (splenomegaly); a variety of gastrointestinal issues; and the risk of blood clot formation, which may prevent blood flow to vital organs. 589b7ed5-ff30-4c28-978b-058c400ea8b9@5@pertianing@pertianing@0@[per] [tianing] :	[through] [tianing],@"Polycythemia vera is a rare, chronic condition involving the overproduction of blood cells in the bone marrow (myeloproliferation). The overproduction of red blood cells is most dramatic. But the production of white blood cells and platelets are also higher in most cases. Since red blood cells are overproduced in the marrow, this result in higher than normal numbers of circulating red blood cells (red blood mass) within the blood. Therefore, the blood thickens and increases in volume, a condition called hyperviscosity. Thickened blood may not flow through small blood vessels the right way. A variety of symptoms can happen in individuals with polycythemia vera including nonspecific symptoms such as headaches, lack of energy, loss of strength, spinning sensations or itching skin; an enlarged spleen (splenomegaly); a variety of gastrointestinal issues (pertianing to the stomach); and the risk of blood clot formation, which may prevent blood flow to critical organs. More than 90 percent of individuals with polycythemia vera have a variation of the JAK2 gene. The exact role of this variation in the development of polycythemia vera is not yet known.  Polycythemia vera belongs to a group of conditions known as the myeloproliferative disorders (MPDs). Three other conditiosn are usually classified as MPDs: chronic myeloid leukemia (cancer of the blood), essential thrombocythemia and idiopathic myelofibrosis.  "

Since red blood cells are overproduced in the marrow, this result in higher than normal numbers of circulating red blood cells (red blood mass) within the blood. Therefore, the blood thickens and increases in volume, a condition called hyperviscosity. Thickened blood may not flow through small blood vessels the right way. A variety of symptoms can happen in individuals with polycythemia vera including nonspecific symptoms such as headaches, lack of energy, loss of strength, spinning sensations or itching skin; an enlarged spleen (splenomegaly); a variety of gastrointestinal issues (pertianing to the stomach); and the risk of blood clot formation, which may prevent blood flow to critical organs. 589b7ed5-ff30-4c28-978b-058c400ea8b9@5@stomach@stomach@0@belly,@"Polycythemia vera is a rare, chronic condition involving the overproduction of blood cells in the bone marrow (myeloproliferation). The overproduction of red blood cells is most dramatic. But the production of white blood cells and platelets are also higher in most cases. Since red blood cells are overproduced in the marrow, this result in higher than normal numbers of circulating red blood cells (red blood mass) within the blood. Therefore, the blood thickens and increases in volume, a condition called hyperviscosity. Thickened blood may not flow through small blood vessels the right way. A variety of symptoms can happen in individuals with polycythemia vera including nonspecific symptoms such as headaches, lack of energy, loss of strength, spinning sensations or itching skin; an enlarged spleen (splenomegaly); a variety of gastrointestinal issues (pertianing to the stomach); and the risk of blood clot formation, which may prevent blood flow to critical organs. More than 90 percent of individuals with polycythemia vera have a variation of the JAK2 gene. The exact role of this variation in the development of polycythemia vera is not yet known. Therefore, the blood thickens and increases in volume, a condition called hyperviscosity. Thickened blood may not flow through small blood vessels the right way. A variety of symptoms can happen in individuals with polycythemia vera including nonspecific symptoms such as headaches, lack of energy, loss of strength, spinning sensations or itching skin; an enlarged spleen (splenomegaly); a variety of stomach issues; and the risk of blood clot formation, which may prevent blood flow to critical organs. More than 90 percent of individuals with polycythemia vera have a variation of the JAK2 gene. The exact role of this variation in the development of polycythemia vera is not yet known.  Polycythemia vera belongs to a group of conditions known as the myeloproliferative disorders (MPDs). Three other conditions are usually classed as MPDs: chronic myeloid leukemia (cancer of the blood), essential thrombocythemia (increased platelets) and idiopathic (unknown origin) myelofibrosis.  "

Polycythemia vera belongs to a group of conditions known as the myeloproliferative disorders (MPDs). Three other conditions are usually classed as MPDs: chronic myeloid leukemia (cancer of the blood), essential thrombocythemia (increased platelets) and idiopathic (unknown origin) myelofibrosis.  "
589b7ed5-ff30-4c28-978b-058c400ea8b9@6@gastrointestinal@gastrointestinal@0@[gastro] [intestin] [al] :	[stomach] [intestin] [pertaining to],@"Polycythemia vera is a rare, chronic condition involving the overproduction of blood cells in the bone marrow (myeloproliferation). The overproduction of red blood cells is most dramatic. But the production of white blood cells and platelets are also higher in most cases. Since red blood cells are overproduced in the marrow, this result in higher than normal numbers of circulating red blood cells (red blood mass) within the blood. Therefore, the blood thickens and increases in volume, a condition called hyperviscosity. Thickened blood may not flow through small blood vessels the right way. A variety of symptoms can happen in individuals with polycythemia vera including nonspecific symptoms such as headaches, lack of energy, loss of strength, spinning sensations or itching skin; an enlarged spleen (splenomegaly); a variety of stomach issues; and the risk of blood clot formation, which may prevent blood flow to critical organs. More than 90 percent of individuals with polycythemia vera have a variation of the JAK2 gene. The exact role of this variation in the development of polycythemia vera is not yet known.  Polycythemia vera belongs to a group of conditions known as the myeloproliferative disorders (MPDs). Three other conditions are usually classed as MPDs: chronic myeloid leukemia (cancer of the blood), essential thrombocythemia (increased platelets) and idiopathic (unknown origin) myelofibrosis.  "

More than 90 percent of individuals with polycythemia vera have a variation of the JAK2 gene. The exact role of this variation in the development of polycythemia vera is not yet known. 589b7ed5-ff30-4c28-978b-058c400ea8b9@7@asthma@asthma@0@[a] [sthma] :	[not, without] [sthma],@"Asthma (from the Greek ?????, ásthma, "panting") is the common chronic inflammatory disease of the airways characterized by variable and recurring symptoms, reversible airflow obstruction, and bronchospasm. Symptoms include wheezing, coughing, chest tightness, and shortness of breath. Asthma is clinically classified according to the frequency of symptoms, forced expiratory volume in 1 second (FEV1), and peak expiratory flow rate. Asthma may also be classified as atopic (extrinsic) or non-atopic (intrinsic).   It is thought to be caused by a combination of genetic and environmental factors. Treatment of acute symptoms is usually with an inhaled short-acting beta-2 agonist (such as salbutamol). Symptoms can be prevented by avoiding triggers, such as allergens and irritants, and by inhaling corticosteroids. Leukotriene antagonists are less effective than corticosteroids and thus less preferred.  Its diagnosis is usually made based on the pattern of symptoms and/or response to therapy over time. The prevalence of asthma has increased significantly since the 1970s. As of 2010, 300 million people were affected worldwide. In 2009 asthma caused 250,000 deaths globally. Despite this, with proper control of asthma with step down therapy, prognosis is generally good.  Causes  Asthma is caused by environmental and genetic factors. These factors influence how severe asthma is and how well it responds to medication. The interaction is complex and not fully understood.  Studying the prevalence of asthma and related diseases such as eczema and hay fever have yielded important clues about some key risk factors. The strongest risk factor for developing asthma is a history of atopic disease; this increases one's risk of hay fever by up to 5× and the risk of asthma by 3–4×. In children between the ages of 3–14, a positive skin test for allergies and an increase in immunoglobulin E increases the chance of having asthma. In adults, the more allergens one reacts positively to in a skin test, the higher the odds of having asthma.  Because much allergic asthma is associated with sensitivity to indoor allergens and because Western styles of housing favor greater exposure to indoor allergens, much attention has focused on increased exposure to these allergens in infancy and early childhood as a primary cause of the rise in asthma. Primary prevention studies aimed at the aggressive reduction of airborne allergens in a home with infants have shown mixed findings. Strict reduction of dust mite allergens, for example, reduces the risk of allergic sensitization to dust mites, and modestly reduces the risk of developing asthma up until the age of 8 years old. However, studies also showed that the effects of exposure to cat and dog allergens worked in the converse fashion; exposure during the first year of life was found to reduce the risk of allergic sensitization and of developing asthma later in life.  The inconsistency of this data has inspired research into other facets of Western society and their impact upon the prevalence of asthma. One subject that appears to show a strong correlation is the development of asthma and obesity. In the United Kingdom and United States, the rise in asthma prevalence has echoed an almost epidemic rise in the prevalence of obesity. In Taiwan, symptoms of allergies and airway hyper-reactivity increased in correlation with each 20% increase in body-mass index. Several factors associated with obesity may play a role in the pathogenesis of asthma, including decreased respiratory function due to a buildup of adipose tissue (fat) and the fact that adipose tissue leads to a pro-inflammatory state, which has been associated with non-eosinophilic asthma.  Asthma has been associated with Churg–Strauss syndrome, and individuals with immunologically mediated urticaria may also experience systemic symptoms with generalized urticaria, rhino-conjunctivitis, orolaryngeal and gastrointestinal symptoms, asthma, and, at worst, anaphylaxis. Additionally, adult-onset asthma has been associated with periocular xanthogranulomas.   "

Several factors associated with obesity may play a role in the pathogenesis of asthma, including decreased respiratory function due to a buildup of adipose tissue (fat) and the fact that adipose tissue leads to a pro-inflammatory state, which has been associated with non-eosinophilic asthma.  Asthma has been associated with Churg–Strauss syndrome, and individuals with immunologically mediated urticaria may also experience systemic symptoms with generalized urticaria, rhino-conjunctivitis, orolaryngeal and gastrointestinal symptoms, asthma, and, at worst, anaphylaxis. Additionally, adult-onset asthma has been associated with periocular xanthogranulomas.   "
589b7ed5-ff30-4c28-978b-058c400ea8b9@7@respiratory@respiratory@0@[re] [spirator] [y] :	[again, back] [spirator] [condition or process of],@"Asthma (from the Greek ?????, ásthma, "panting") is the common chronic inflammatory disease of the airways characterized by variable and recurring symptoms, reversible airflow obstruction, and bronchospasm. Symptoms include wheezing, coughing, chest tightness, and shortness of breath. Asthma is clinically classified according to the frequency of symptoms, forced expiratory volume in 1 second (FEV1), and peak expiratory flow rate. Asthma may also be classified as atopic (extrinsic) or non-atopic (intrinsic).   It is thought to be caused by a combination of genetic and environmental factors. Treatment of acute symptoms is usually with an inhaled short-acting beta-2 agonist (such as salbutamol). Symptoms can be prevented by avoiding triggers, such as allergens and irritants, and by inhaling corticosteroids. Leukotriene antagonists are less effective than corticosteroids and thus less preferred.  Its diagnosis is usually made based on the pattern of symptoms and/or response to therapy over time. The prevalence of asthma has increased significantly since the 1970s. As of 2010, 300 million people were affected worldwide. In 2009 asthma caused 250,000 deaths globally. Despite this, with proper control of asthma with step down therapy, prognosis is generally good.  Causes  Asthma is caused by environmental and genetic factors. These factors influence how severe asthma is and how well it responds to medication. The interaction is complex and not fully understood.  Studying the prevalence of asthma and related diseases such as eczema and hay fever have yielded important clues about some key risk factors. The strongest risk factor for developing asthma is a history of atopic disease; this increases one's risk of hay fever by up to 5× and the risk of asthma by 3–4×. In children between the ages of 3–14, a positive skin test for allergies and an increase in immunoglobulin E increases the chance of having asthma. In adults, the more allergens one reacts positively to in a skin test, the higher the odds of having asthma.  Because much allergic asthma is associated with sensitivity to indoor allergens and because Western styles of housing favor greater exposure to indoor allergens, much attention has focused on increased exposure to these allergens in infancy and early childhood as a primary cause of the rise in asthma. Primary prevention studies aimed at the aggressive reduction of airborne allergens in a home with infants have shown mixed findings. Strict reduction of dust mite allergens, for example, reduces the risk of allergic sensitization to dust mites, and modestly reduces the risk of developing asthma up until the age of 8 years old. However, studies also showed that the effects of exposure to cat and dog allergens worked in the converse fashion; exposure during the first year of life was found to reduce the risk of allergic sensitization and of developing asthma later in life.  The inconsistency of this data has inspired research into other facets of Western society and their impact upon the prevalence of asthma. One subject that appears to show a strong correlation is the development of asthma and obesity. In the United Kingdom and United States, the rise in asthma prevalence has echoed an almost epidemic rise in the prevalence of obesity. In Taiwan, symptoms of allergies and airway hyper-reactivity increased in correlation with each 20% increase in body-mass index. Several factors associated with obesity may play a role in the pathogenesis of asthma, including decreased respiratory function due to a buildup of adipose tissue (fat) and the fact that adipose tissue leads to a pro-inflammatory state, which has been associated with non-eosinophilic asthma.  Asthma has been associated with Churg–Strauss syndrome, and individuals with immunologically mediated urticaria may also experience systemic symptoms with generalized urticaria, rhino-conjunctivitis, orolaryngeal and gastrointestinal symptoms, asthma, and, at worst, anaphylaxis. Additionally, adult-onset asthma has been associated with periocular xanthogranulomas.   "

Primary prevention studies aimed at the aggressive reduction of airborne allergens in a home with infants have shown mixed findings. Strict reduction of dust mite allergens, for example, reduces the risk of allergic sensitization to dust mites, and modestly reduces the risk of developing asthma up until the age of 8 years old. However, studies also showed that the effects of exposure to cat and dog allergens worked in the converse fashion; exposure during the first year of life was found to reduce the risk of allergic sensitization and of developing asthma later in life.  The inconsistency of this data has inspired research into other facets of Western society and their impact upon the prevalence of asthma. One subject that appears to show a strong correlation is the development of asthma and obesity. In the United Kingdom and United States, the rise in asthma prevalence has echoed an almost epidemic rise in the prevalence of obesity. In Taiwan, symptoms of allergies and airway hyper-reactivity increased in correlation with each 20% increase in body-mass index. Several factors associated with obesity may play a role in the pathogenesis of asthma, including decreased respiratory function due to a buildup of adipose tissue (fat) and the fact that adipose tissue leads to a pro-inflammatory state, which has been associated with non-eosinophilic asthma.  Asthma has been associated with Churg–Strauss syndrome, and individuals with immunologically mediated urticaria may also experience systemic symptoms with generalized urticaria, rhino-conjunctivitis, orolaryngeal and gastrointestinal symptoms, asthma, and, at worst, anaphylaxis. Additionally, adult-onset asthma has been associated with periocular xanthogranulomas.   "
589b7ed5-ff30-4c28-978b-058c400ea8b9@8@obstruction@obstruction@0@obstacle,blocked,Use verb form: obstruct,@"Asthma (from the Greek ?????, ásthma, "panting") is the common chronic inflammatory disease of the respiratory tract characterized by variable and recurring symptoms, reversible airflow obstruction, and bronchospasm. Symptoms include wheezing, coughing, chest tightness, and shortness of breath. Asthma is clinically classified according to the frequency of symptoms, forced expiratory volume in 1 second (FEV1), and peak expiratory flow rate. Asthma may also be classified as atopic (extrinsic) or non-atopic (intrinsic).   It is thought to be caused by a combination of genetic and environmental factors. Treatment of acute symptoms is usually with an inhaled short-acting beta-2 agonist (such as salbutamol). Symptoms can be prevented by avoiding triggers, such as allergens and irritants, and by inhaling corticosteroids. Leukotriene antagonists are less effective than corticosteroids and thus less preferred.  Its diagnosis is usually made based on the pattern of symptoms and/or response to therapy over time. The prevalence of asthma has increased significantly since the 1970s. As of 2010, 300 million people were affected worldwide. In 2009 asthma caused 250,000 deaths globally. Despite this, with proper control of asthma with step down therapy, prognosis is generally good.  Causes  Asthma is caused by environmental and genetic factors. These factors influence how severe asthma is and how well it responds to medication. The interaction is complex and not fully understood.  Studying the prevalence of asthma and related diseases such as eczema and hay fever have yielded important clues about some key risk factors. The strongest risk factor for developing asthma is a history of atopic disease; this increases one's risk of hay fever by up to 5× and the risk of asthma by 3–4×. In children between the ages of 3–14, a positive skin test for allergies and an increase in immunoglobulin E increases the chance of having asthma. In adults, the more allergens one reacts positively to in a skin test, the higher the odds of having asthma.  Because much allergic asthma is associated with sensitivity to indoor allergens and because Western styles of housing favor greater exposure to indoor allergens, much attention has focused on increased exposure to these allergens in infancy and early childhood as a primary cause of the rise in asthma. Primary prevention studies aimed at the aggressive reduction of airborne allergens in a home with infants have shown mixed findings. Strict reduction of dust mite allergens, for example, reduces the risk of allergic sensitization to dust mites, and modestly reduces the risk of developing asthma up until the age of 8 years old. However, studies also showed that the effects of exposure to cat and dog allergens worked in the converse fashion; exposure during the first year of life was found to reduce the risk of allergic sensitization and of developing asthma later in life.  The inconsistency of this data has inspired research into other facets of Western society and their impact upon the prevalence of asthma. One subject that appears to show a strong correlation is the development of asthma and obesity. In the United Kingdom and United States, the rise in asthma prevalence has echoed an almost epidemic rise in the prevalence of obesity. In Taiwan, symptoms of allergies and airway hyper-reactivity increased in correlation with each 20% increase in body-mass index. Several factors associated with obesity may play a role in the pathogenesis of asthma, including decreased respiratory function due to a buildup of adipose tissue (fat) and the fact that adipose tissue leads to a pro-inflammatory state, which has been associated with non-eosinophilic asthma.  Asthma has been associated with Churg–Strauss syndrome, and individuals with immunologically mediated urticaria may also experience systemic symptoms with generalized urticaria, rhino-conjunctivitis, orolaryngeal and gastrointestinal symptoms, asthma, and, at worst, anaphylaxis. Additionally, adult-onset asthma has been associated with periocular xanthogranulomas.   "

In children between the ages of 3–14, a positive skin test for allergies and an increase in immunoglobulin E increases the chance of having asthma. In adults, the more allergens one reacts positively to in a skin test, the higher the odds of having asthma.  Because much allergic asthma is associated with sensitivity to indoor allergens and because Western styles of housing favor greater exposure to indoor allergens, much attention has focused on increased exposure to these allergens in infancy and early childhood as a primary cause of the rise in asthma. Primary prevention studies aimed at the aggressive reduction of airborne allergens in a home with infants have shown mixed findings. Strict reduction of dust mite allergens, for example, reduces the risk of allergic sensitization to dust mites, and modestly reduces the risk of developing asthma up until the age of 8 years old. However, studies also showed that the effects of exposure to cat and dog allergens worked in the converse fashion; exposure during the first year of life was found to reduce the risk of allergic sensitization and of developing asthma later in life.  The inconsistency of this data has inspired research into other facets of Western society and their impact upon the prevalence of asthma. One subject that appears to show a strong correlation is the development of asthma and obesity. In the United Kingdom and United States, the rise in asthma prevalence has echoed an almost epidemic rise in the prevalence of obesity. In Taiwan, symptoms of allergies and airway hyper-reactivity increased in correlation with each 20% increase in body-mass index. Several factors associated with obesity may play a role in the pathogenesis of asthma, including decreased respiratory function due to a buildup of adipose tissue (fat) and the fact that adipose tissue leads to a pro-inflammatory state, which has been associated with non-eosinophilic asthma.  Asthma has been associated with Churg–Strauss syndrome, and individuals with immunologically mediated urticaria may also experience systemic symptoms with generalized urticaria, rhino-conjunctivitis, orolaryngeal and gastrointestinal symptoms, asthma, and, at worst, anaphylaxis. Additionally, adult-onset asthma has been associated with periocular xanthogranulomas.   "
589b7ed5-ff30-4c28-978b-058c400ea8b9@9@airflow@airflow@0@air flow,flow of air,@"Asthma (from the Greek ?????, ásthma, "panting") is the common chronic inflammatory disease of the respiratory tract characterized by variable and recurring symptoms, reversible airflow obstruction, and bronchospasm. Symptoms include wheezing, coughing, chest tightness, and shortness of breath. Asthma is clinically classified according to the frequency of symptoms, forced expiratory volume in 1 second (FEV1), and peak expiratory flow rate. Asthma may also be classified as atopic (extrinsic) or non-atopic (intrinsic).   It is thought to be caused by a combination of genetic and environmental factors. Treatment of acute symptoms is usually with an inhaled short-acting beta-2 agonist (such as salbutamol). Symptoms can be prevented by avoiding triggers, such as allergens and irritants, and by inhaling corticosteroids. Leukotriene antagonists are less effective than corticosteroids and thus less preferred.  Its diagnosis is usually made based on the pattern of symptoms and/or response to therapy over time. The prevalence of asthma has increased significantly since the 1970s. As of 2010, 300 million people were affected worldwide. In 2009 asthma caused 250,000 deaths globally. Despite this, with proper control of asthma with step down therapy, prognosis is generally good.  Causes  Asthma is caused by environmental and genetic factors. These factors influence how severe asthma is and how well it responds to medication. The interaction is complex and not fully understood.  Studying the prevalence of asthma and related diseases such as eczema and hay fever have yielded important clues about some key risk factors. The strongest risk factor for developing asthma is a history of atopic disease; this increases one's risk of hay fever by up to 5× and the risk of asthma by 3–4×. In children between the ages of 3–14, a positive skin test for allergies and an increase in immunoglobulin E increases the chance of having asthma. In adults, the more allergens one reacts positively to in a skin test, the higher the odds of having asthma.  Because much allergic asthma is associated with sensitivity to indoor allergens and because Western styles of housing favor greater exposure to indoor allergens, much attention has focused on increased exposure to these allergens in infancy and early childhood as a primary cause of the rise in asthma. Primary prevention studies aimed at the aggressive reduction of airborne allergens in a home with infants have shown mixed findings. Strict reduction of dust mite allergens, for example, reduces the risk of allergic sensitization to dust mites, and modestly reduces the risk of developing asthma up until the age of 8 years old. However, studies also showed that the effects of exposure to cat and dog allergens worked in the converse fashion; exposure during the first year of life was found to reduce the risk of allergic sensitization and of developing asthma later in life.  The inconsistency of this data has inspired research into other facets of Western society and their impact upon the prevalence of asthma. One subject that appears to show a strong correlation is the development of asthma and obesity. In the United Kingdom and United States, the rise in asthma prevalence has echoed an almost epidemic rise in the prevalence of obesity. In Taiwan, symptoms of allergies and airway hyper-reactivity increased in correlation with each 20% increase in body-mass index. Several factors associated with obesity may play a role in the pathogenesis of asthma, including decreased respiratory function due to a buildup of adipose tissue (fat) and the fact that adipose tissue leads to a pro-inflammatory state, which has been associated with non-eosinophilic asthma.  Asthma has been associated with Churg–Strauss syndrome, and individuals with immunologically mediated urticaria may also experience systemic symptoms with generalized urticaria, rhino-conjunctivitis, orolaryngeal and gastrointestinal symptoms, asthma, and, at worst, anaphylaxis. Additionally, adult-onset asthma has been associated with periocular xanthogranulomas.   "

Despite this, with proper control of asthma with step down therapy, prognosis is generally good.  Causes  Asthma is caused by environmental and genetic factors. These factors influence how severe asthma is and how well it responds to medication. The interaction is complex and not fully understood.  Studying the prevalence of asthma and related diseases such as eczema and hay fever have yielded important clues about some key risk factors. The strongest risk factor for developing asthma is a history of atopic disease; this increases one's risk of hay fever by up to 5× and the risk of asthma by 3–4×. In children between the ages of 3–14, a positive skin test for allergies and an increase in immunoglobulin E increases the chance of having asthma. In adults, the more allergens one reacts positively to in a skin test, the higher the odds of having asthma.  Because much allergic asthma is associated with sensitivity to indoor allergens and because Western styles of housing favor greater exposure to indoor allergens, much attention has focused on increased exposure to these allergens in infancy and early childhood as a primary cause of the rise in asthma. Primary prevention studies aimed at the aggressive reduction of airborne allergens in a home with infants have shown mixed findings. Strict reduction of dust mite allergens, for example, reduces the risk of allergic sensitization to dust mites, and modestly reduces the risk of developing asthma up until the age of 8 years old. However, studies also showed that the effects of exposure to cat and dog allergens worked in the converse fashion; exposure during the first year of life was found to reduce the risk of allergic sensitization and of developing asthma later in life.  The inconsistency of this data has inspired research into other facets of Western society and their impact upon the prevalence of asthma. One subject that appears to show a strong correlation is the development of asthma and obesity. In the United Kingdom and United States, the rise in asthma prevalence has echoed an almost epidemic rise in the prevalence of obesity. In Taiwan, symptoms of allergies and airway hyper-reactivity increased in correlation with each 20% increase in body-mass index. Several factors associated with obesity may play a role in the pathogenesis of asthma, including decreased respiratory function due to a buildup of adipose tissue (fat) and the fact that adipose tissue leads to a pro-inflammatory state, which has been associated with non-eosinophilic asthma.  Asthma has been associated with Churg–Strauss syndrome, and individuals with immunologically mediated urticaria may also experience systemic symptoms with generalized urticaria, rhino-conjunctivitis, orolaryngeal and gastrointestinal symptoms, asthma, and, at worst, anaphylaxis. Additionally, adult-onset asthma has been associated with periocular xanthogranulomas.   "
589b7ed5-ff30-4c28-978b-058c400ea8b9@10@according@according@0@agreement,@"Asthma (from the Greek ?????, ásthma, "panting") is the common chronic inflammatory condition of the respiratory tract characterized by variable and recurring symptoms, reversible airflow obstruction, and bronchial spasm. Symptoms include wheezing, coughing, chest tightness, and shortness of breath. Asthma is clinically classified according to the frequency of symptoms, forced expiratory volume in 1 second (FEV1), and peak expiratory flow rate. Asthma may also be classified as atopic (extrinsic) or non-atopic (intrinsic).   It is thought to be caused by a combination of genetic and environmental factors. Treatment of acute symptoms is usually with an inhaled short-acting beta-2 agonist (such as salbutamol). Symptoms can be prevented by avoiding triggers, such as allergens and irritants, and by inhaling corticosteroids. Leukotriene antagonists are less effective than corticosteroids and thus less preferred.  Its diagnosis is usually made based on the pattern of symptoms and/or response to therapy over time. The prevalence of asthma has increased significantly since the 1970s. As of 2010, 300 million people were affected worldwide. In 2009 asthma caused 250,000 deaths globally. Despite this, with proper control of asthma with step down therapy, prognosis is generally good.  Causes  Asthma is caused by environmental and genetic factors. These factors influence how severe asthma is and how well it responds to medication. The interaction is complex and not fully understood.  Studying the prevalence of asthma and related diseases such as eczema and hay fever have yielded important clues about some key risk factors. The strongest risk factor for developing asthma is a history of atopic disease; this increases one's risk of hay fever by up to 5× and the risk of asthma by 3–4×. In children between the ages of 3–14, a positive skin test for allergies and an increase in immunoglobulin E increases the chance of having asthma. In adults, the more allergens one reacts positively to in a skin test, the higher the odds of having asthma.  Because much allergic asthma is associated with sensitivity to indoor allergens and because Western styles of housing favor greater exposure to indoor allergens, much attention has focused on increased exposure to these allergens in infancy and early childhood as a primary cause of the rise in asthma. Primary prevention studies aimed at the aggressive reduction of airborne allergens in a home with infants have shown mixed findings. Strict reduction of dust mite allergens, for example, reduces the risk of allergic sensitization to dust mites, and modestly reduces the risk of developing asthma up until the age of 8 years old. However, studies also showed that the effects of exposure to cat and dog allergens worked in the converse fashion; exposure during the first year of life was found to reduce the risk of allergic sensitization and of developing asthma later in life.  The inconsistency of this data has inspired research into other facets of Western society and their impact upon the prevalence of asthma. One subject that appears to show a strong correlation is the development of asthma and obesity. In the United Kingdom and United States, the rise in asthma prevalence has echoed an almost epidemic rise in the prevalence of obesity. In Taiwan, symptoms of allergies and airway hyper-reactivity increased in correlation with each 20% increase in body-mass index. Several factors associated with obesity may play a role in the pathogenesis of asthma, including decreased respiratory function due to a buildup of adipose tissue (fat) and the fact that adipose tissue leads to a pro-inflammatory state, which has been associated with non-eosinophilic asthma.  Asthma has been associated with Churg–Strauss syndrome, and individuals with immunologically mediated urticaria may also experience systemic symptoms with generalized urticaria, rhino-conjunctivitis, orolaryngeal and gastrointestinal symptoms, asthma, and, at worst, anaphylaxis. Additionally, adult-onset asthma has been associated with periocular xanthogranulomas.   "
589b7ed5-ff30-4c28-978b-058c400ea8b9@10@frequency@how often@1@how often,@"Asthma (from the Greek ?????, ásthma, "panting") is the common chronic inflammatory condition of the respiratory tract characterized by variable and recurring symptoms, reversible airflow obstruction, and bronchial spasm. Symptoms include wheezing, coughing, chest tightness, and shortness of breath. Asthma is clinically classified according to the frequency of symptoms, forced expiratory volume in 1 second (FEV1), and peak expiratory flow rate. Asthma may also be classified as atopic (extrinsic) or non-atopic (intrinsic).   It is thought to be caused by a combination of genetic and environmental factors. Treatment of acute symptoms is usually with an inhaled short-acting beta-2 agonist (such as salbutamol). Symptoms can be prevented by avoiding triggers, such as allergens and irritants, and by inhaling corticosteroids. Leukotriene antagonists are less effective than corticosteroids and thus less preferred.  Its diagnosis is usually made based on the pattern of symptoms and/or response to therapy over time. The prevalence of asthma has increased significantly since the 1970s. As of 2010, 300 million people were affected worldwide. In 2009 asthma caused 250,000 deaths globally. Despite this, with proper control of asthma with step down therapy, prognosis is generally good.  Causes  Asthma is caused by environmental and genetic factors. These factors influence how severe asthma is and how well it responds to medication. The interaction is complex and not fully understood.  Studying the prevalence of asthma and related diseases such as eczema and hay fever have yielded important clues about some key risk factors. The strongest risk factor for developing asthma is a history of atopic disease; this increases one's risk of hay fever by up to 5× and the risk of asthma by 3–4×. In children between the ages of 3–14, a positive skin test for allergies and an increase in immunoglobulin E increases the chance of having asthma. In adults, the more allergens one reacts positively to in a skin test, the higher the odds of having asthma.  Because much allergic asthma is associated with sensitivity to indoor allergens and because Western styles of housing favor greater exposure to indoor allergens, much attention has focused on increased exposure to these allergens in infancy and early childhood as a primary cause of the rise in asthma. Primary prevention studies aimed at the aggressive reduction of airborne allergens in a home with infants have shown mixed findings. Strict reduction of dust mite allergens, for example, reduces the risk of allergic sensitization to dust mites, and modestly reduces the risk of developing asthma up until the age of 8 years old. However, studies also showed that the effects of exposure to cat and dog allergens worked in the converse fashion; exposure during the first year of life was found to reduce the risk of allergic sensitization and of developing asthma later in life.  The inconsistency of this data has inspired research into other facets of Western society and their impact upon the prevalence of asthma. One subject that appears to show a strong correlation is the development of asthma and obesity. In the United Kingdom and United States, the rise in asthma prevalence has echoed an almost epidemic rise in the prevalence of obesity. In Taiwan, symptoms of allergies and airway hyper-reactivity increased in correlation with each 20% increase in body-mass index. Several factors associated with obesity may play a role in the pathogenesis of asthma, including decreased respiratory function due to a buildup of adipose tissue (fat) and the fact that adipose tissue leads to a pro-inflammatory state, which has been associated with non-eosinophilic asthma.  Asthma has been associated with Churg–Strauss syndrome, and individuals with immunologically mediated urticaria may also experience systemic symptoms with generalized urticaria, rhino-conjunctivitis, orolaryngeal and gastrointestinal symptoms, asthma, and, at worst, anaphylaxis. Additionally, adult-onset asthma has been associated with periocular xanthogranulomas.   "

Treatment of acute symptoms is usually with an inhaled short-acting beta-2 agonist (such as salbutamol). Symptoms can be prevented by avoiding triggers, such as allergens and irritants, and by inhaling corticosteroids. Leukotriene antagonists are less effective than corticosteroids and thus less preferred.  Its diagnosis is usually made based on the pattern of symptoms and/or response to therapy over time. The prevalence of asthma has increased significantly since the 1970s. As of 2010, 300 million people were affected worldwide. In 2009 asthma caused 250,000 deaths globally. Despite this, with proper control of asthma with step down therapy, prognosis is generally good.  Causes  Asthma is caused by environmental and genetic factors. These factors influence how severe asthma is and how well it responds to medication. The interaction is complex and not fully understood.  Studying the prevalence of asthma and related diseases such as eczema and hay fever have yielded important clues about some key risk factors. The strongest risk factor for developing asthma is a history of atopic disease; this increases one's risk of hay fever by up to 5× and the risk of asthma by 3–4×. In children between the ages of 3–14, a positive skin test for allergies and an increase in immunoglobulin E increases the chance of having asthma. In adults, the more allergens one reacts positively to in a skin test, the higher the odds of having asthma.  Because much allergic asthma is associated with sensitivity to indoor allergens and because Western styles of housing favor greater exposure to indoor allergens, much attention has focused on increased exposure to these allergens in infancy and early childhood as a primary cause of the rise in asthma. Primary prevention studies aimed at the aggressive reduction of airborne allergens in a home with infants have shown mixed findings. Strict reduction of dust mite allergens, for example, reduces the risk of allergic sensitization to dust mites, and modestly reduces the risk of developing asthma up until the age of 8 years old. However, studies also showed that the effects of exposure to cat and dog allergens worked in the converse fashion; exposure during the first year of life was found to reduce the risk of allergic sensitization and of developing asthma later in life.  The inconsistency of this data has inspired research into other facets of Western society and their impact upon the prevalence of asthma. One subject that appears to show a strong correlation is the development of asthma and obesity. In the United Kingdom and United States, the rise in asthma prevalence has echoed an almost epidemic rise in the prevalence of obesity. In Taiwan, symptoms of allergies and airway hyper-reactivity increased in correlation with each 20% increase in body-mass index. Several factors associated with obesity may play a role in the pathogenesis of asthma, including decreased respiratory function due to a buildup of adipose tissue (fat) and the fact that adipose tissue leads to a pro-inflammatory state, which has been associated with non-eosinophilic asthma.  Asthma has been associated with Churg–Strauss syndrome, and individuals with immunologically mediated urticaria may also experience systemic symptoms with generalized urticaria, rhino-conjunctivitis, orolaryngeal and gastrointestinal symptoms, asthma, and, at worst, anaphylaxis. Additionally, adult-onset asthma has been associated with periocular xanthogranulomas.   "
589b7ed5-ff30-4c28-978b-058c400ea8b9@11@expiratory@expiration@1@expiration,expiration body function,@"Asthma (from the Greek ?????, ásthma, "panting") is the common chronic inflammatory condition of the respiratory tract characterized by variable and recurring symptoms, reversible airflow obstruction, and bronchial spasms. Symptoms include wheezing, coughing, chest tightness, and shortness of breath. Asthma is clinically classed according to the how often symptoms occur, forced expiratory volume in 1 second (FEV1), and peak expiratory flow rate. Asthma may also be classified as atopic (extrinsic) or non-atopic (intrinsic).   It is thought to be caused by a combination of genetic and environmental factors. Treatment of acute symptoms is usually with an inhaled short-acting beta-2 agonist (such as salbutamol). Symptoms can be prevented by avoiding triggers, such as allergens and irritants, and by inhaling corticosteroids. Leukotriene antagonists are less effective than corticosteroids and thus less preferred.  Its diagnosis is usually made based on the pattern of symptoms and/or response to therapy over time. In children between the ages of 3–14, a positive skin test for allergies and an increase in immunoglobulin E increases the chance of having asthma. In adults, the more allergens one reacts positively to in a skin test, the higher the odds of having asthma. One subject that appears to show a strong correlation is the development of asthma and obesity. In Taiwan, symptoms of allergies and airway hyper-reactivity increased in correlation with each 20% increase in body-mass index. Several factors associated with obesity may play a role in the pathogenesis of asthma, including decreased respiratory function due to a buildup of adipose tissue (fat) and the fact that adipose tissue leads to a pro-inflammatory state, which has been associated with non-eosinophilic asthma.  Asthma has been associated with Churg–Strauss syndrome, and individuals with immunologically mediated urticaria may also experience systemic symptoms with generalized urticaria, rhino-conjunctivitis, orolaryngeal and gastrointestinal symptoms, asthma, and, at worst, anaphylaxis. Additionally, adult-onset asthma has been associated with periocular xanthogranulomas.   "

Symptoms include wheezing, coughing, chest tightness, and shortness of breath. Asthma is clinically classed according to the how often symptoms occur, forced expiratory volume in 1 second (FEV1), and peak expiratory flow rate. Asthma may also be classified as atopic (extrinsic) or non-atopic (intrinsic).   It is thought to be caused by a combination of genetic and environmental factors. Treatment of acute symptoms is usually with an inhaled short-acting beta-2 agonist (such as salbutamol). Symptoms can be prevented by avoiding triggers, such as allergens and irritants, and by inhaling corticosteroids. Leukotriene antagonists are less effective than corticosteroids and thus less preferred.  Its diagnosis is usually made based on the pattern of symptoms and/or response to therapy over time. The prevalence of asthma has increased significantly since the 1970s. As of 2010, 300 million people were affected worldwide. In 2009 asthma caused 250,000 deaths globally. Despite this, with proper control of asthma with step down therapy, prognosis is generally good.  Causes  Asthma is caused by environmental and genetic factors. These factors influence how severe asthma is and how well it responds to medication. The interaction is complex and not fully understood.  Studying the prevalence of asthma and related diseases such as eczema and hay fever have yielded important clues about some key risk factors. The strongest risk factor for developing asthma is a history of atopic disease; this increases one's risk of hay fever by up to 5× and the risk of asthma by 3–4×. In children between the ages of 3–14, a positive skin test for allergies and an increase in immunoglobulin E increases the chance of having asthma. In adults, the more allergens one reacts positively to in a skin test, the higher the odds of having asthma. However, studies also showed that the effects of exposure to cat and dog allergens worked in the converse fashion; exposure during the first year of life was found to reduce the risk of allergic sensitization and of developing asthma later in life. One subject that appears to show a strong correlation is the development of asthma and obesity. In the United Kingdom and United States, the rise in asthma prevalence has echoed an almost epidemic rise in the prevalence of obesity. In Taiwan, symptoms of allergies and airway hyper-reactivity increased in correlation with each 20% increase in body-mass index. Several factors associated with obesity may play a role in the pathogenesis of asthma, including decreased respiratory function due to a buildup of adipose tissue (fat) and the fact that adipose tissue leads to a pro-inflammatory state, which has been associated with non-eosinophilic asthma.  Asthma has been associated with Churg–Strauss syndrome, and individuals with immunologically mediated urticaria may also experience systemic symptoms with generalized urticaria, rhino-conjunctivitis, orolaryngeal and gastrointestinal symptoms, asthma, and, at worst, anaphylaxis. Additionally, adult-onset asthma has been associated with periocular xanthogranulomas.   "

Asthma is clinically classed according to the how often symptoms occur, forced expiratory volume in 1 second (FEV1), and peak expiratory flow rate. Asthma may also be classified as atopic (extrinsic) or non-atopic (intrinsic).   It is thought to be caused by a combination of genetic and environmental factors. Leukotriene antagonists are less effective than corticosteroids and thus less preferred.  Its diagnosis is usually made based on the pattern of symptoms and/or response to therapy over time. The strongest risk factor for developing asthma is a history of atopic disease; this increases one's risk of hay fever by up to 5× and the risk of asthma by 3–4×. In Taiwan, symptoms of allergies and airway hyper-reactivity increased in correlation with each 20% increase in body-mass index. Several factors associated with obesity may play a role in the pathogenesis of asthma, including decreased respiratory function due to a buildup of adipose tissue (fat) and the fact that adipose tissue leads to a pro-inflammatory state, which has been associated with non-eosinophilic asthma.  Asthma has been associated with Churg–Strauss syndrome, and individuals with immunologically mediated urticaria may also experience systemic symptoms with generalized urticaria, rhino-conjunctivitis, orolaryngeal and gastrointestinal symptoms, asthma, and, at worst, anaphylaxis. Additionally, adult-onset asthma has been associated with periocular xanthogranulomas.   "
