These factors influence how severe asthma is and how well it responds to medication. The interaction is complex and not fully understood.  Studying the prevalence of asthma and related diseases such as eczema and hay fever have yielded important clues about some key risk factors. The strongest risk factor for developing asthma is a history of atopic disease; this increases one's risk of hay fever by up to 5× and the risk of asthma by 3–4×. In children between the ages of 3–14, a positive skin test for allergies and an increase in immunoglobulin E increases the chance of having asthma. In adults, the more allergens one reacts positively to in a skin test, the higher the odds of having asthma.  Because much allergic asthma is associated with sensitivity to indoor allergens and because Western styles of housing favor greater exposure to indoor allergens, much attention has focused on increased exposure to these allergens in infancy and early childhood as a primary cause of the rise in asthma. Primary prevention studies aimed at the aggressive reduction of airborne allergens in a home with infants have shown mixed findings. Strict reduction of dust mite allergens, for example, reduces the risk of allergic sensitization to dust mites, and modestly reduces the risk of developing asthma up until the age of 8 years old. However, studies also showed that the effects of exposure to cat and dog allergens worked in the converse fashion; exposure during the first year of life was found to reduce the risk of allergic sensitization and of developing asthma later in life.  The inconsistency of this data has inspired research into other facets of Western society and their impact upon the prevalence of asthma. One subject that appears to show a strong correlation is the development of asthma and obesity. In the United Kingdom and United States, the rise in asthma prevalence has echoed an almost epidemic rise in the prevalence of obesity. In Taiwan, symptoms of allergies and airway hyper-reactivity increased in correlation with each 20% increase in body-mass index. Several factors associated with obesity may play a role in the pathogenesis of asthma, including decreased respiratory function due to a buildup of adipose tissue (fat) and the fact that adipose tissue leads to a pro-inflammatory state, which has been associated with non-eosinophilic asthma.  Asthma has been associated with Churg–Strauss syndrome, and individuals with immunologically mediated urticaria may also experience systemic symptoms with generalized urticaria, rhino-conjunctivitis, orolaryngeal and gastrointestinal symptoms, asthma, and, at worst, anaphylaxis. Additionally, adult-onset asthma has been associated with periocular xanthogranulomas.   "
589b7ed5-ff30-4c28-978b-058c400ea8b9@11@reduction@reduction@0@Use verb form: reduce,@"Asthma (from the Greek ?????, ásthma, "panting") is the common chronic inflammatory condition of the respiratory tract characterized by variable and recurring symptoms, reversible airflow obstruction, and bronchial spasms. Symptoms include wheezing, coughing, chest tightness, and shortness of breath. Asthma is clinically classed according to the how often symptoms occur, forced expiratory volume in 1 second (FEV1), and peak expiratory flow rate. Asthma may also be classified as atopic (extrinsic) or non-atopic (intrinsic).   It is thought to be caused by a combination of genetic and environmental factors. Treatment of acute symptoms is usually with an inhaled short-acting beta-2 agonist (such as salbutamol). Symptoms can be prevented by avoiding triggers, such as allergens and irritants, and by inhaling corticosteroids. Leukotriene antagonists are less effective than corticosteroids and thus less preferred.  Its diagnosis is usually made based on the pattern of symptoms and/or response to therapy over time. The prevalence of asthma has increased significantly since the 1970s. As of 2010, 300 million people were affected worldwide. In 2009 asthma caused 250,000 deaths globally. Despite this, with proper control of asthma with step down therapy, prognosis is generally good.  Causes  Asthma is caused by environmental and genetic factors. These factors influence how severe asthma is and how well it responds to medication. The interaction is complex and not fully understood.  Studying the prevalence of asthma and related diseases such as eczema and hay fever have yielded important clues about some key risk factors. The strongest risk factor for developing asthma is a history of atopic disease; this increases one's risk of hay fever by up to 5× and the risk of asthma by 3–4×. In children between the ages of 3–14, a positive skin test for allergies and an increase in immunoglobulin E increases the chance of having asthma. In adults, the more allergens one reacts positively to in a skin test, the higher the odds of having asthma.  Because much allergic asthma is associated with sensitivity to indoor allergens and because Western styles of housing favor greater exposure to indoor allergens, much attention has focused on increased exposure to these allergens in infancy and early childhood as a primary cause of the rise in asthma. Primary prevention studies aimed at the aggressive reduction of airborne allergens in a home with infants have shown mixed findings. Strict reduction of dust mite allergens, for example, reduces the risk of allergic sensitization to dust mites, and modestly reduces the risk of developing asthma up until the age of 8 years old. However, studies also showed that the effects of exposure to cat and dog allergens worked in the converse fashion; exposure during the first year of life was found to reduce the risk of allergic sensitization and of developing asthma later in life.  The inconsistency of this data has inspired research into other facets of Western society and their impact upon the prevalence of asthma. One subject that appears to show a strong correlation is the development of asthma and obesity. In the United Kingdom and United States, the rise in asthma prevalence has echoed an almost epidemic rise in the prevalence of obesity. In Taiwan, symptoms of allergies and airway hyper-reactivity increased in correlation with each 20% increase in body-mass index. Several factors associated with obesity may play a role in the pathogenesis of asthma, including decreased respiratory function due to a buildup of adipose tissue (fat) and the fact that adipose tissue leads to a pro-inflammatory state, which has been associated with non-eosinophilic asthma.  Asthma has been associated with Churg–Strauss syndrome, and individuals with immunologically mediated urticaria may also experience systemic symptoms with generalized urticaria, rhino-conjunctivitis, orolaryngeal and gastrointestinal symptoms, asthma, and, at worst, anaphylaxis. Additionally, adult-onset asthma has been associated with periocular xanthogranulomas.   "

However, studies also showed that the effects of exposure to cat and dog allergens worked in the converse fashion; exposure during the first year of life was found to reduce the risk of allergic sensitization and of developing asthma later in life. One subject that appears to show a strong correlation is the development of asthma and obesity. In the United Kingdom and United States, the rise in asthma prevalence has echoed an almost epidemic rise in the prevalence of obesity. 589b7ed5-ff30-4c28-978b-058c400ea8b9@12@common@common@0@[com] [mon] :	[with, together] [monday],@"Asthma (from the Greek ?????, ásthma, "panting") is the common chronic inflammatory condition of the respiratory tract characterized by variable and recurring symptoms, reversible airflow obstruction, and bronchial spasms. Symptoms include wheezing, coughing, chest tightness, and shortness of breath. Asthma is clinically classed according to how often symptoms happen, forced expiration volume in 1 second (FEV1), and peak expiration flow rate. Asthma may also be classed as atopic (external) or non-atopic (internal).   It is thought to be caused by a combination of genetic and environmental factors. Treating acute symptoms is usually with an inhaled short-acting beta-2 agonist (such as salbutamol). Symptoms can be prevented by avoiding triggers, such as allergens and irritants, and by breathing in corticosteroids. Leukotriene antagonists are less effective than corticosteroids and therefore less preferred.  Its diagnosis is usually made based on the pattern of symptoms and/or response to treatment over time. The prevalence of asthma has increased significantly since the 1970s. As of 2010, 300 million people were impacted worldwide. In 2009 asthma caused 250,000 deaths globally. Despite this, with the right control of asthma with step down treatment, outcome is generally good.  Causes  Asthma is caused by environmental and genetic factors. These factors determine how serious asthma is and how well it responds to medicine. The interaction is complex and not fully understood.  Examining the prevalence of asthma and related conditions such as eczema and hay fever have given important clues about some key risk factors. The strongest risk factor for getting asthma is a history of atopic diseases; this increases one's risk of hay fever by up to 5× and the risk of asthma by 3–4×. In children between the ages of 3–14, a positive skin test for allergies and an increase in immunoglobulin E increases the chance of getting asthma. In adults, the more allergens one reacts positively to in a skin test, the higher the odds of getting asthma.  Because much allergic asthma is linked with sensitivity to indoor allergens and because Western styles of housing favor greater exposure to indoor allergens, much attention has centered on increased exposure to these allergens in infancy and early childhood as a main cause of the rise in asthma. Primary prevention studies aimed at the aggressive reduction of airborne allergens in a home with infants have shown mixed findings. Strict reduction of dust mite allergens, for example, cuts down the risk of allergic sensitization to dust mites, and modestly cuts down the risk of getting asthma up until the age of 8 years old. However, studies also showed that the effects of exposure to cat and dog allergens worked in the converse way; exposure during the first year of life was found to cut down the risk of allergic sensitization and of getting asthma later in life.  The inconsistency of this information has inspired research into other aspects of Western society and their impact upon the prevalence of asthma. One subject that seems to show a strong correlation is the development of asthma and obesity. In the United Kingdom and United States, the increase in asthma prevalence has echoed an almost epidemic increase in the prevalence of obesity. In Taiwan, symptoms of allergies and airway hyper-reactivity increased in correlation with each 20% increase in body-mass index. Many factors linked with obesity may play a part in the pathogenesis of asthma, including reduced respiratory function due to a buildup of adipose tissue (fat) and the fact that adipose tissue leads to a pro-inflammatory state, which has been linked with non-eosinophilic asthma.  Asthma has been linked with Churg–Strauss syndrome, and someone with immunologically mediated urticaria (hives) may also have systemic symptoms with generalized urticaria (hives), rhino-conjunctivitis, orolaryngeal and gastrointestinal (stomach) symptoms, asthma, and, at worst, allergic shock. Additionally, adult-onset asthma has been linked with periocular xanthogranulomas.   "

Asthma has been linked with Churg–Strauss syndrome, and someone with immunologically mediated urticaria (hives) may also have systemic symptoms with generalized urticaria (hives), rhino-conjunctivitis, orolaryngeal and gastrointestinal (stomach) symptoms, asthma, and, at worst, allergic shock. Additionally, adult-onset asthma has been linked with periocular xanthogranulomas.   "

Symptoms include wheezing, coughing, chest tightness, and shortness of breath. Asthma is clinically classed according to how often symptoms happen, forced expiration volume in 1 second (FEV1), and peak expiration flow rate. Asthma may also be classed as atopic (external) or non-atopic (internal).   It is thought to be caused by a combination of genetic and environmental factors. Treating acute symptoms is usually with an inhaled short-acting beta-2 agonist (such as salbutamol). Symptoms can be prevented by avoiding triggers, such as allergens and irritants, and by breathing in corticosteroids. Leukotriene antagonists are less effective than corticosteroids and therefore less preferred.  Its diagnosis is usually made based on the pattern of symptoms and/or response to treatment over time. The prevalence of asthma has increased significantly since the 1970s. As of 2010, 300 million people were impacted worldwide. In 2009 asthma caused 250,000 deaths globally. Despite this, with the right control of asthma with step down treatment, outcome is generally good.  Causes  Asthma is caused by environmental and genetic factors. These factors determine how serious asthma is and how well it responds to medicine. The interaction is complex and not fully understood.  Examining the prevalence of asthma and related conditions such as eczema and hay fever have given important clues about some key risk factors. The strongest risk factor for getting asthma is a history of atopic diseases; this increases one's risk of hay fever by up to 5× and the risk of asthma by 3–4×. In children between the ages of 3–14, a positive skin test for allergies and an increase in immunoglobulin E increases the chance of getting asthma. In adults, the more allergens one reacts positively to in a skin test, the higher the odds of getting asthma.  Because much allergic asthma is linked with sensitivity to indoor allergens and because Western styles of housing favor greater exposure to indoor allergens, much attention has centered on increased exposure to these allergens in infancy and early childhood as a main cause of the rise in asthma. Primary prevention studies aimed at the aggressive reduction of airborne allergens in a home with infants have shown mixed findings. Strict reduction of dust mite allergens, for example, cuts down the risk of allergic sensitization to dust mites, and modestly cuts down the risk of getting asthma up until the age of 8 years old. However, studies also showed that the effects of exposure to cat and dog allergens worked in the converse way; exposure during the first year of life was found to cut down the risk of allergic sensitization and of getting asthma later in life.  The inconsistency of this information has inspired research into other aspects of Western society and their impact upon the prevalence of asthma. One subject that seems to show a strong correlation is the development of asthma and obesity. In the United Kingdom and United States, the increase in asthma prevalence has echoed an almost epidemic increase in the prevalence of obesity. In Taiwan, symptoms of allergies and airway hyper-reactivity increased in correlation with each 20% increase in body-mass index. Many factors linked with obesity may play a part in the pathogenesis of asthma, including reduced respiratory function due to a buildup of adipose tissue (fat) and the fact that adipose tissue leads to a pro-inflammatory state, which has been linked with non-eosinophilic asthma.  Asthma has been linked with Churg–Strauss syndrome, and someone with immunologically mediated urticaria (hives) may also have systemic symptoms with generalized urticaria (hives), rhino-conjunctivitis, orolaryngeal and gastrointestinal (stomach) symptoms, asthma, and, at worst, allergic shock. Additionally, adult-onset asthma has been linked with periocular xanthogranulomas.   "
589b7ed5-ff30-4c28-978b-058c400ea8b9@12@condition@condition@0@status,term,@"Asthma (from the Greek ?????, ásthma, "panting") is the common chronic inflammatory condition of the respiratory tract characterized by variable and recurring symptoms, reversible airflow obstruction, and bronchial spasms. Symptoms include wheezing, coughing, chest tightness, and shortness of breath. Asthma is clinically classed according to how often symptoms happen, forced expiration volume in 1 second (FEV1), and peak expiration flow rate. Asthma may also be classed as atopic (external) or non-atopic (internal).   It is thought to be caused by a combination of genetic and environmental factors. Treating acute symptoms is usually with an inhaled short-acting beta-2 agonist (such as salbutamol). Symptoms can be prevented by avoiding triggers, such as allergens and irritants, and by breathing in corticosteroids. Leukotriene antagonists are less effective than corticosteroids and therefore less preferred.  Its diagnosis is usually made based on the pattern of symptoms and/or response to treatment over time. The prevalence of asthma has increased significantly since the 1970s. As of 2010, 300 million people were impacted worldwide. In 2009 asthma caused 250,000 deaths globally. Despite this, with the right control of asthma with step down treatment, outcome is generally good.  Causes  Asthma is caused by environmental and genetic factors. These factors determine how serious asthma is and how well it responds to medicine. The interaction is complex and not fully understood.  Examining the prevalence of asthma and related conditions such as eczema and hay fever have given important clues about some key risk factors. The strongest risk factor for getting asthma is a history of atopic diseases; this increases one's risk of hay fever by up to 5× and the risk of asthma by 3–4×. In children between the ages of 3–14, a positive skin test for allergies and an increase in immunoglobulin E increases the chance of getting asthma. In adults, the more allergens one reacts positively to in a skin test, the higher the odds of getting asthma.  Because much allergic asthma is linked with sensitivity to indoor allergens and because Western styles of housing favor greater exposure to indoor allergens, much attention has centered on increased exposure to these allergens in infancy and early childhood as a main cause of the rise in asthma. Primary prevention studies aimed at the aggressive reduction of airborne allergens in a home with infants have shown mixed findings. Strict reduction of dust mite allergens, for example, cuts down the risk of allergic sensitization to dust mites, and modestly cuts down the risk of getting asthma up until the age of 8 years old. However, studies also showed that the effects of exposure to cat and dog allergens worked in the converse way; exposure during the first year of life was found to cut down the risk of allergic sensitization and of getting asthma later in life. One subject that seems to show a strong correlation is the development of asthma and obesity. In the United Kingdom and United States, the increase in asthma prevalence has echoed an almost epidemic increase in the prevalence of obesity. In Taiwan, symptoms of allergies and airway hyper-reactivity increased in correlation with each 20% increase in body-mass index. Additionally, adult-onset asthma has been linked with periocular xanthogranulomas.   "

In Taiwan, symptoms of allergies and airway hyper-reactivity increased in correlation with each 20% increase in body-mass index. Many factors linked with obesity may play a part in the pathogenesis of asthma, including reduced respiratory function due to a buildup of adipose tissue (fat) and the fact that adipose tissue leads to a pro-inflammatory state, which has been linked with non-eosinophilic asthma.  Asthma has been linked with Churg–Strauss syndrome, and someone with immunologically mediated urticaria (hives) may also have systemic symptoms with generalized urticaria (hives), rhino-conjunctivitis, orolaryngeal and gastrointestinal (stomach) symptoms, asthma, and, at worst, allergic shock. Additionally, adult-onset asthma has been linked with periocular xanthogranulomas.   "
589b7ed5-ff30-4c28-978b-058c400ea8b9@12@airflow@airflow@0@air flow,flow of air,@"Asthma (from the Greek ?????, ásthma, "panting") is the common chronic inflammatory condition of the respiratory tract characterized by variable and recurring symptoms, reversible airflow obstruction, and bronchial spasms. Symptoms include wheezing, coughing, chest tightness, and shortness of breath. Asthma is clinically classed according to how often symptoms happen, forced expiration volume in 1 second (FEV1), and peak expiration flow rate. Asthma may also be classed as atopic (external) or non-atopic (internal).   It is thought to be caused by a combination of genetic and environmental factors. Treating acute symptoms is usually with an inhaled short-acting beta-2 agonist (such as salbutamol). Symptoms can be prevented by avoiding triggers, such as allergens and irritants, and by breathing in corticosteroids. Leukotriene antagonists are less effective than corticosteroids and therefore less preferred.  Its diagnosis is usually made based on the pattern of symptoms and/or response to treatment over time. The prevalence of asthma has increased significantly since the 1970s. As of 2010, 300 million people were impacted worldwide. In 2009 asthma caused 250,000 deaths globally. Despite this, with the right control of asthma with step down treatment, outcome is generally good.  Causes  Asthma is caused by environmental and genetic factors. These factors determine how serious asthma is and how well it responds to medicine. The interaction is complex and not fully understood.  Examining the prevalence of asthma and related conditions such as eczema and hay fever have given important clues about some key risk factors. The strongest risk factor for getting asthma is a history of atopic diseases; this increases one's risk of hay fever by up to 5× and the risk of asthma by 3–4×. In children between the ages of 3–14, a positive skin test for allergies and an increase in immunoglobulin E increases the chance of getting asthma. In adults, the more allergens one reacts positively to in a skin test, the higher the odds of getting asthma.  Because much allergic asthma is linked with sensitivity to indoor allergens and because Western styles of housing favor greater exposure to indoor allergens, much attention has centered on increased exposure to these allergens in infancy and early childhood as a main cause of the rise in asthma. Primary prevention studies aimed at the aggressive reduction of airborne allergens in a home with infants have shown mixed findings. Strict reduction of dust mite allergens, for example, cuts down the risk of allergic sensitization to dust mites, and modestly cuts down the risk of getting asthma up until the age of 8 years old. However, studies also showed that the effects of exposure to cat and dog allergens worked in the converse way; exposure during the first year of life was found to cut down the risk of allergic sensitization and of getting asthma later in life.  The inconsistency of this information has inspired research into other aspects of Western society and their impact upon the prevalence of asthma. One subject that seems to show a strong correlation is the development of asthma and obesity. In the United Kingdom and United States, the increase in asthma prevalence has echoed an almost epidemic increase in the prevalence of obesity. In Taiwan, symptoms of allergies and airway hyper-reactivity increased in correlation with each 20% increase in body-mass index. Many factors linked with obesity may play a part in the pathogenesis of asthma, including reduced respiratory function due to a buildup of adipose tissue (fat) and the fact that adipose tissue leads to a pro-inflammatory state, which has been linked with non-eosinophilic asthma.  Asthma has been linked with Churg–Strauss syndrome, and someone with immunologically mediated urticaria (hives) may also have systemic symptoms with generalized urticaria (hives), rhino-conjunctivitis, orolaryngeal and gastrointestinal (stomach) symptoms, asthma, and, at worst, allergic shock. Additionally, adult-onset asthma has been linked with periocular xanthogranulomas.   "

In children between the ages of 3–14, a positive skin test for allergies and an increase in immunoglobulin E increases the chance of getting asthma. In adults, the more allergens one reacts positively to in a skin test, the higher the odds of getting asthma.  Because much allergic asthma is linked with sensitivity to indoor allergens and because Western styles of housing favor greater exposure to indoor allergens, much attention has centered on increased exposure to these allergens in infancy and early childhood as a main cause of the rise in asthma. Primary prevention studies aimed at the aggressive reduction of airborne allergens in a home with infants have shown mixed findings. Strict reduction of dust mite allergens, for example, cuts down the risk of allergic sensitization to dust mites, and modestly cuts down the risk of getting asthma up until the age of 8 years old. However, studies also showed that the effects of exposure to cat and dog allergens worked in the converse way; exposure during the first year of life was found to cut down the risk of allergic sensitization and of getting asthma later in life.  The inconsistency of this information has inspired research into other aspects of Western society and their impact upon the prevalence of asthma. One subject that seems to show a strong correlation is the development of asthma and obesity. In the United Kingdom and United States, the increase in asthma prevalence has echoed an almost epidemic increase in the prevalence of obesity. In Taiwan, symptoms of allergies and airway hyper-reactivity increased in correlation with each 20% increase in body-mass index. Many factors linked with obesity may play a part in the pathogenesis of asthma, including reduced respiratory function due to a buildup of adipose tissue (fat) and the fact that adipose tissue leads to a pro-inflammatory state, which has been linked with non-eosinophilic asthma.  Asthma has been linked with Churg–Strauss syndrome, and someone with immunologically mediated urticaria (hives) may also have systemic symptoms with generalized urticaria (hives), rhino-conjunctivitis, orolaryngeal and gastrointestinal (stomach) symptoms, asthma, and, at worst, allergic shock. Additionally, adult-onset asthma has been linked with periocular xanthogranulomas.   "
589b7ed5-ff30-4c28-978b-058c400ea8b9@12@clinically@clinically@0@[clinicall] [y] :	[clinicall] [condition or process of],@"Asthma (from the Greek ?????, ásthma, "panting") is the common chronic inflammatory condition of the respiratory tract characterized by variable and recurring symptoms, reversible airflow obstruction, and bronchial spasms. Symptoms include wheezing, coughing, chest tightness, and shortness of breath. Asthma is clinically classed according to how often symptoms happen, forced expiration volume in 1 second (FEV1), and peak expiration flow rate. Asthma may also be classed as atopic (external) or non-atopic (internal).   It is thought to be caused by a combination of genetic and environmental factors. Treating acute symptoms is usually with an inhaled short-acting beta-2 agonist (such as salbutamol). Symptoms can be prevented by avoiding triggers, such as allergens and irritants, and by breathing in corticosteroids. Leukotriene antagonists are less effective than corticosteroids and therefore less preferred.  Its diagnosis is usually made based on the pattern of symptoms and/or response to treatment over time. The prevalence of asthma has increased significantly since the 1970s. As of 2010, 300 million people were impacted worldwide. In 2009 asthma caused 250,000 deaths globally. Despite this, with the right control of asthma with step down treatment, outcome is generally good.  Causes  Asthma is caused by environmental and genetic factors. These factors determine how serious asthma is and how well it responds to medicine. The interaction is complex and not fully understood.  Examining the prevalence of asthma and related conditions such as eczema and hay fever have given important clues about some key risk factors. The strongest risk factor for getting asthma is a history of atopic diseases; this increases one's risk of hay fever by up to 5× and the risk of asthma by 3–4×. In children between the ages of 3–14, a positive skin test for allergies and an increase in immunoglobulin E increases the chance of getting asthma. In adults, the more allergens one reacts positively to in a skin test, the higher the odds of getting asthma.  Because much allergic asthma is linked with sensitivity to indoor allergens and because Western styles of housing favor greater exposure to indoor allergens, much attention has centered on increased exposure to these allergens in infancy and early childhood as a main cause of the rise in asthma. Primary prevention studies aimed at the aggressive reduction of airborne allergens in a home with infants have shown mixed findings. Strict reduction of dust mite allergens, for example, cuts down the risk of allergic sensitization to dust mites, and modestly cuts down the risk of getting asthma up until the age of 8 years old. However, studies also showed that the effects of exposure to cat and dog allergens worked in the converse way; exposure during the first year of life was found to cut down the risk of allergic sensitization and of getting asthma later in life.  The inconsistency of this information has inspired research into other aspects of Western society and their impact upon the prevalence of asthma. One subject that seems to show a strong correlation is the development of asthma and obesity. In the United Kingdom and United States, the increase in asthma prevalence has echoed an almost epidemic increase in the prevalence of obesity. In Taiwan, symptoms of allergies and airway hyper-reactivity increased in correlation with each 20% increase in body-mass index. Many factors linked with obesity may play a part in the pathogenesis of asthma, including reduced respiratory function due to a buildup of adipose tissue (fat) and the fact that adipose tissue leads to a pro-inflammatory state, which has been linked with non-eosinophilic asthma.  Asthma has been linked with Churg–Strauss syndrome, and someone with immunologically mediated urticaria (hives) may also have systemic symptoms with generalized urticaria (hives), rhino-conjunctivitis, orolaryngeal and gastrointestinal (stomach) symptoms, asthma, and, at worst, allergic shock. Additionally, adult-onset asthma has been linked with periocular xanthogranulomas.   "

Asthma may also be classed as atopic (external) or non-atopic (internal).   It is thought to be caused by a combination of genetic and environmental factors. Treating acute symptoms is usually with an inhaled short-acting beta-2 agonist (such as salbutamol). Symptoms can be prevented by avoiding triggers, such as allergens and irritants, and by breathing in corticosteroids. Leukotriene antagonists are less effective than corticosteroids and therefore less preferred.  Its diagnosis is usually made based on the pattern of symptoms and/or response to treatment over time. The prevalence of asthma has increased significantly since the 1970s. As of 2010, 300 million people were impacted worldwide. In 2009 asthma caused 250,000 deaths globally. Despite this, with the right control of asthma with step down treatment, outcome is generally good.  Causes  Asthma is caused by environmental and genetic factors. These factors determine how serious asthma is and how well it responds to medicine. The interaction is complex and not fully understood.  Examining the prevalence of asthma and related conditions such as eczema and hay fever have given important clues about some key risk factors. The strongest risk factor for getting asthma is a history of atopic diseases; this increases one's risk of hay fever by up to 5× and the risk of asthma by 3–4×. In children between the ages of 3–14, a positive skin test for allergies and an increase in immunoglobulin E increases the chance of getting asthma. In adults, the more allergens one reacts positively to in a skin test, the higher the odds of getting asthma.  Because much allergic asthma is linked with sensitivity to indoor allergens and because Western styles of housing favor greater exposure to indoor allergens, much attention has centered on increased exposure to these allergens in infancy and early childhood as a main cause of the rise in asthma. Primary prevention studies aimed at the aggressive reduction of airborne allergens in a home with infants have shown mixed findings. Strict reduction of dust mite allergens, for example, cuts down the risk of allergic sensitization to dust mites, and modestly cuts down the risk of getting asthma up until the age of 8 years old. However, studies also showed that the effects of exposure to cat and dog allergens worked in the converse way; exposure during the first year of life was found to cut down the risk of allergic sensitization and of getting asthma later in life.  The inconsistency of this information has inspired research into other aspects of Western society and their impact upon the prevalence of asthma. One subject that seems to show a strong correlation is the development of asthma and obesity. In the United Kingdom and United States, the increase in asthma prevalence has echoed an almost epidemic increase in the prevalence of obesity. In Taiwan, symptoms of allergies and airway hyper-reactivity increased in correlation with each 20% increase in body-mass index. Many factors linked with obesity may play a part in the pathogenesis of asthma, including reduced respiratory function due to a buildup of adipose tissue (fat) and the fact that adipose tissue leads to a pro-inflammatory state, which has been linked with non-eosinophilic asthma.  Asthma has been linked with Churg–Strauss syndrome, and someone with immunologically mediated urticaria (hives) may also have systemic symptoms with generalized urticaria (hives), rhino-conjunctivitis, orolaryngeal and gastrointestinal (stomach) symptoms, asthma, and, at worst, allergic shock. Additionally, adult-onset asthma has been linked with periocular xanthogranulomas.   "
589b7ed5-ff30-4c28-978b-058c400ea8b9@12@peak@peak@0@flower,prime,height,top,tip,point,bill,the highest point,@"Asthma (from the Greek ?????, ásthma, "panting") is the common chronic inflammatory condition of the respiratory tract characterized by variable and recurring symptoms, reversible airflow obstruction, and bronchial spasms. Symptoms include wheezing, coughing, chest tightness, and shortness of breath. Asthma is clinically classed according to how often symptoms happen, forced expiration volume in 1 second (FEV1), and peak expiration flow rate. Additionally, adult-onset asthma has been linked with periocular xanthogranulomas.   "

Asthma may also be classed as atopic (external) or non-atopic (internal).   It is thought to be caused by a combination of genetic and environmental factors. In Taiwan, symptoms of allergies and airway hyper-reactivity increased in correlation with each 20% increase in body-mass index. Many factors linked with obesity may play a part in the pathogenesis of asthma, including reduced respiratory function due to a buildup of adipose tissue (fat) and the fact that adipose tissue leads to a pro-inflammatory state, which has been linked with non-eosinophilic asthma.  Asthma has been linked with Churg–Strauss syndrome, and someone with immunologically mediated urticaria (hives) may also have systemic symptoms with generalized urticaria (hives), rhino-conjunctivitis, orolaryngeal and gastrointestinal (stomach) symptoms, asthma, and, at worst, allergic shock. Additionally, adult-onset asthma has been linked with periocular xanthogranulomas.   "
589b7ed5-ff30-4c28-978b-058c400ea8b9@12@(@(@0@null@"Asthma (from the Greek ?????, ásthma, "panting") is the common chronic inflammatory condition of the respiratory tract characterized by variable and recurring symptoms, reversible airflow obstruction, and bronchial spasms. Symptoms include wheezing, coughing, chest tightness, and shortness of breath. Asthma is clinically classed according to how often symptoms happen, forced expiration volume in 1 second (FEV1), and peak expiration flow rate. Asthma may also be classed as atopic (external) or non-atopic (internal).   It is thought to be caused by a combination of genetic and environmental factors. Treating acute symptoms is usually with an inhaled short-acting beta-2 agonist (such as salbutamol). Symptoms can be prevented by avoiding triggers, such as allergens and irritants, and by breathing in corticosteroids. Leukotriene antagonists are less effective than corticosteroids and therefore less preferred.  Its diagnosis is usually made based on the pattern of symptoms and/or response to treatment over time. The prevalence of asthma has increased significantly since the 1970s. As of 2010, 300 million people were impacted worldwide. In 2009 asthma caused 250,000 deaths globally. Despite this, with the right control of asthma with step down treatment, outcome is generally good.  Causes  Asthma is caused by environmental and genetic factors. These factors determine how serious asthma is and how well it responds to medicine. The interaction is complex and not fully understood.  Examining the prevalence of asthma and related conditions such as eczema and hay fever have given important clues about some key risk factors. The strongest risk factor for getting asthma is a history of atopic diseases; this increases one's risk of hay fever by up to 5× and the risk of asthma by 3–4×. In children between the ages of 3–14, a positive skin test for allergies and an increase in immunoglobulin E increases the chance of getting asthma. In adults, the more allergens one reacts positively to in a skin test, the higher the odds of getting asthma.  Because much allergic asthma is linked with sensitivity to indoor allergens and because Western styles of housing favor greater exposure to indoor allergens, much attention has centered on increased exposure to these allergens in infancy and early childhood as a main cause of the rise in asthma. Primary prevention studies aimed at the aggressive reduction of airborne allergens in a home with infants have shown mixed findings. Strict reduction of dust mite allergens, for example, cuts down the risk of allergic sensitization to dust mites, and modestly cuts down the risk of getting asthma up until the age of 8 years old. However, studies also showed that the effects of exposure to cat and dog allergens worked in the converse way; exposure during the first year of life was found to cut down the risk of allergic sensitization and of getting asthma later in life.  The inconsistency of this information has inspired research into other aspects of Western society and their impact upon the prevalence of asthma. One subject that seems to show a strong correlation is the development of asthma and obesity. In the United Kingdom and United States, the increase in asthma prevalence has echoed an almost epidemic increase in the prevalence of obesity. In Taiwan, symptoms of allergies and airway hyper-reactivity increased in correlation with each 20% increase in body-mass index. Many factors linked with obesity may play a part in the pathogenesis of asthma, including reduced respiratory function due to a buildup of adipose tissue (fat) and the fact that adipose tissue leads to a pro-inflammatory state, which has been linked with non-eosinophilic asthma.  Asthma has been linked with Churg–Strauss syndrome, and someone with immunologically mediated urticaria (hives) may also have systemic symptoms with generalized urticaria (hives), rhino-conjunctivitis, orolaryngeal and gastrointestinal (stomach) symptoms, asthma, and, at worst, allergic shock. Additionally, adult-onset asthma has been linked with periocular xanthogranulomas.   "

Because much allergic asthma is linked with sensitivity to indoor allergens and because Western styles of housing favor greater exposure to indoor allergens, much attention has centered on increased exposure to these allergens in infancy and early childhood as a main cause of the rise in asthma. Primary prevention studies aimed at the aggressive reduction of airborne allergens in a home with infants have shown mixed findings. Strict reduction of dust mite allergens, for example, cuts down the risk of allergic sensitization to dust mites, and modestly cuts down the risk of getting asthma up until the age of 8 years old. However, studies also showed that the effects of exposure to cat and dog allergens worked in the converse way; exposure during the first year of life was found to cut down the risk of allergic sensitization and of getting asthma later in life.  The inconsistency of this information has inspired research into other aspects of Western society and their impact upon the prevalence of asthma. One subject that seems to show a strong correlation is the development of asthma and obesity. In the United Kingdom and United States, the increase in asthma prevalence has echoed an almost epidemic increase in the prevalence of obesity. In Taiwan, symptoms of allergies and airway hyper-reactivity increased in correlation with each 20% increase in body-mass index. Many factors linked with obesity may play a part in the pathogenesis of asthma, including reduced respiratory function due to a buildup of adipose tissue (fat) and the fact that adipose tissue leads to a pro-inflammatory state, which has been linked with non-eosinophilic asthma.  Asthma has been linked with Churg–Strauss syndrome, and someone with immunologically mediated urticaria (hives) may also have systemic symptoms with generalized urticaria (hives), rhino-conjunctivitis, orolaryngeal and gastrointestinal (stomach) symptoms, asthma, and, at worst, allergic shock. Additionally, adult-onset asthma has been linked with periocular xanthogranulomas.   "
589b7ed5-ff30-4c28-978b-058c400ea8b9@13@combination@combination@0@Use verb form: combine,@"Asthma (from the Greek ?????, ásthma, "panting") is the common chronic inflammatory condition of the respiratory tract characterized by variable and recurring symptoms, reversible blocked airflow, and bronchial spasms. Symptoms include wheezing, coughing, chest tightness, and shortness of breath. Asthma is clinically classed according to how often symptoms happen, forced expiration volume in 1 second (FEV1), and peak expiration flow rate. Asthma may also be classed as atopic (extrinsic) or non-atopic (intrinsic).   It is thought to be caused by a combination of genetic and environmental factors. Treating acute symptoms is usually with an inhaled short-acting beta-2 agonist (such as salbutamol). Symptoms can be prevented by avoiding triggers, such as allergens and irritants, and by breathing in corticosteroids. Leukotriene antagonists are less effective than corticosteroids and therefore less preferred.  Its diagnosis is usually made based on the pattern of symptoms and/or response to treatment over time. The prevalence of asthma has increased significantly since the 1970s. As of 2010, 300 million people were impacted worldwide. In 2009 asthma caused 250,000 deaths globally. Despite this, with the right control of asthma with step down treatment, outcome is generally good.  Causes  Asthma is caused by environmental and genetic factors. These factors determine how serious asthma is and how well it responds to medicine. The interaction is complex and not fully understood.  Examining the prevalence of asthma and related conditions such as eczema and hay fever have given important clues about some key risk factors. The strongest risk factor for getting asthma is a history of atopic diseases; this increases one's risk of hay fever by up to 5× and the risk of asthma by 3–4×. In children between the ages of 3–14, a positive skin test for allergies and an increase in immunoglobulin E increases the chance of getting asthma. In adults, the more allergens one reacts positively to in a skin test, the higher the odds of getting asthma.  Because much allergic asthma is linked with sensitivity to indoor allergens and because Western styles of housing favor greater exposure to indoor allergens, much attention has centered on increased exposure to these allergens in infancy and early childhood as a main cause of the rise in asthma. Primary prevention studies aimed at the aggressive reduction of airborne allergens in a home with infants have shown mixed findings. Strict reduction of dust mite allergens, for example, cuts down the risk of allergic sensitization to dust mites, and modestly cuts down the risk of getting asthma up until the age of 8 years old. However, studies also showed that the effects of exposure to cat and dog allergens worked in the converse way; exposure during the first year of life was found to cut down the risk of allergic sensitization and of getting asthma later in life.  The inconsistency of this information has inspired research into other aspects of Western society and their impact upon the prevalence of asthma. One subject that seems to show a strong correlation is the development of asthma and obesity. In the United Kingdom and United States, the increase in asthma prevalence has echoed an almost epidemic increase in the prevalence of obesity. In Taiwan, symptoms of allergies and airway hyper-reactivity increased in correlation with each 20% increase in body-mass index. Many factors linked with obesity may play a part in the pathogenesis of asthma, including reduced respiratory function due to a buildup of adipose tissue (fat) and the fact that adipose tissue leads to a pro-inflammatory state, which has been linked with non-eosinophilic asthma.  Asthma has been linked with Churg–Strauss syndrome, and someone with immunologically mediated urticaria (hives) may also have systemic symptoms with generalized urticaria (hives), rhino-conjunctivitis, orolaryngeal and gastrointestinal (stomach) symptoms, asthma, and, at worst, allergic shock. Additionally, adult-onset asthma has been linked with periocular xanthogranulomas.   "

Additionally, adult-onset asthma has been linked with periocular xanthogranulomas.   "

Symptoms include wheezing, coughing, chest tightness, and shortness of breath. Asthma is clinically classed according to how often symptoms happen, forced expiration volume in 1 second (FEV1), and peak expiration flow rate. Asthma may also be classed as atopic (extrinsic) or non-atopic (intrinsic).   It is thought to be caused by a combination of genetic and environmental factors. Treating acute symptoms is usually with an inhaled short-acting beta-2 agonist (such as salbutamol). Symptoms can be prevented by avoiding triggers, such as allergens and irritants, and by breathing in corticosteroids. Leukotriene antagonists are less effective than corticosteroids and therefore less preferred.  Its diagnosis is usually made based on the pattern of symptoms and/or response to treatment over time. The prevalence of asthma has increased significantly since the 1970s. As of 2010, 300 million people were impacted worldwide. In 2009 asthma caused 250,000 deaths globally. Despite this, with the right control of asthma with step down treatment, outcome is generally good.  Causes  Asthma is caused by environmental and genetic factors. These factors determine how serious asthma is and how well it responds to medicine. The interaction is complex and not fully understood. In children between the ages of 3–14, a positive skin test for allergies and an increase in immunoglobulin E increases the chance of getting asthma. Symptoms include wheezing, coughing, chest tightness, and shortness of breath. Asthma is clinically classed according to how often symptoms happen, forced expiration volume in 1 second (FEV1), and peak expiration flow rate. Asthma may also be classed as atopic (extrinsic) or non-atopic (intrinsic).   It is thought to be caused by a combination of genetic and environmental factors. Treating acute symptoms is usually with an inhaled short-acting beta-2 agonist (such as salbutamol). Symptoms can be prevented by avoiding triggers, such as allergens and irritants, and by breathing in corticosteroids. Leukotriene antagonists are less effective than corticosteroids and therefore less preferred.  Its diagnosis is usually made based on the pattern of symptoms and/or response to treatment over time. The prevalence of asthma has increased significantly since the 1970s. As of 2010, 300 million people were impacted worldwide. In 2009 asthma caused 250,000 deaths globally. Despite this, with the right control of asthma with step down treatment, outcome is generally good.  Causes  Asthma is caused by environmental and genetic factors. These factors determine how serious asthma is and how well it responds to medicine. The interaction is complex and not fully understood. In Taiwan, symptoms of allergies and airway hyper-reactivity increased in correlation with each 20% increase in body-mass index. Asthma is clinically classed according to how often symptoms happen, forced expiration volume in 1 second (FEV1), and peak expiration flow rate. Asthma may also be classed as atopic (extrinsic) or non-atopic (intrinsic).   It is thought to be caused by a combination of genetic and environmental factors. Treating acute symptoms is usually with an inhaled short-acting beta-2 agonist (such as salbutamol). Symptoms can be prevented by avoiding triggers, such as allergens and irritants, and by breathing in corticosteroids. Leukotriene antagonists are less effective than corticosteroids and therefore less preferred.  Its diagnosis is usually made based on the pattern of symptoms and/or response to treatment over time. One subject that seems to show a strong correlation is the development of asthma and obesity. In the United Kingdom and United States, the increase in asthma prevalence has echoed an almost epidemic increase in the prevalence of obesity. In Taiwan, symptoms of allergies and airway hyper-reactivity increased in correlation with each 20% increase in body-mass index. Many factors linked with obesity may play a part in the pathogenesis of asthma, including reduced respiratory function due to a buildup of adipose tissue (fat) and the fact that adipose tissue leads to a pro-inflammatory state, which has been linked with non-eosinophilic asthma.  Asthma has been linked with Churg–Strauss syndrome, and someone with immunologically mediated urticaria (hives) may also have systemic symptoms with generalized urticaria (hives), rhino-conjunctivitis, orolaryngeal and gastrointestinal (stomach) symptoms, asthma, and, at worst, allergic shock. In Taiwan, symptoms of allergies and airway hyper-reactivity increased in correlation with each 20% increase in body-mass index. Treating acute symptoms is usually with an inhaled short-acting beta-2 agonist (such as salbutamol). Symptoms can be prevented by avoiding triggers, such as allergens and irritants, and by breathing in corticosteroids. Leukotriene antagonists are less effective than corticosteroids and therefore less preferred.  Its diagnosis is usually made based on the pattern of symptoms and/or response to treatment over time. The prevalence of asthma has increased significantly since the 1970s. As of 2010, 300 million people were impacted worldwide. In 2009 asthma caused 250,000 deaths globally. Despite this, with the right control of asthma with step down treatment, outcome is generally good.  Causes  Asthma is caused by environmental and genetic factors. These factors determine how serious asthma is and how well it responds to medicine. The interaction is complex and not fully understood.  Examining the prevalence of asthma and related conditions such as eczema and hay fever have given important clues about some key risk factors. The strongest risk factor for getting asthma is a history of atopic diseases; this increases one's risk of hay fever by up to 5× and the risk of asthma by 3–4×. In children between the ages of 3–14, a positive skin test for allergies and an increase in immunoglobulin E increases the chance of getting asthma. In adults, the more allergens one reacts positively to in a skin test, the higher the odds of getting asthma.  Because much allergic asthma is linked with sensitivity to indoor allergens and because Western styles of housing favor greater exposure to indoor allergens, much attention has centered on increased exposure to these allergens in infancy and early childhood as a main cause of the rise in asthma. Primary prevention studies aimed at the aggressive reduction of airborne allergens in a home with infants have shown mixed findings. Strict reduction of dust mite allergens, for example, cuts down the risk of allergic sensitization to dust mites, and modestly cuts down the risk of getting asthma up until the age of 8 years old. However, studies also showed that the effects of exposure to cat and dog allergens worked in the converse way; exposure during the first year of life was found to cut down the risk of allergic sensitization and of getting asthma later in life.  The inconsistency of this information has inspired research into other aspects of Western society and their impact upon the prevalence of asthma. One subject that seems to show a strong correlation is the development of asthma and obesity. In the United Kingdom and United States, the increase in asthma prevalence has echoed an almost epidemic increase in the prevalence of obesity. In Taiwan, symptoms of allergies and airway hyper-reactivity increased in correlation with each 20% increase in body-mass index. Many factors linked with obesity may play a part in the pathogenesis of asthma, including reduced respiratory function due to a buildup of adipose tissue (fat) and the fact that adipose tissue leads to a pro-inflammatory state, which has been linked with non-eosinophilic asthma.  Asthma has been linked with Churg–Strauss syndrome, and someone with immunologically mediated urticaria (hives) may also have systemic symptoms with generalized urticaria (hives), rhino-conjunctivitis, orolaryngeal and gastrointestinal (stomach) symptoms, asthma, and, at worst, allergic shock. Additionally, adult-onset asthma has been linked with periocular xanthogranulomas.   "
589b7ed5-ff30-4c28-978b-058c400ea8b9@13@agonist@agonist@0@[a] [gon] [ist] :	[not, without] [gon] [one who specializes in],@"Asthma (from the Greek ?????, ásthma, "panting") is the common chronic inflammatory condition of the respiratory tract characterized by variable and recurring symptoms, reversible blocked airflow, and bronchial spasms. Symptoms include wheezing, coughing, chest tightness, and shortness of breath. Asthma is clinically classed according to how often symptoms happen, forced expiration volume in 1 second (FEV1), and peak expiration flow rate. Asthma may also be classed as atopic (extrinsic) or non-atopic (intrinsic).   It is thought to be caused by a combination of genetic and environmental factors. Treating acute symptoms is usually with an inhaled short-acting beta-2 agonist (such as salbutamol). Symptoms can be prevented by avoiding triggers, such as allergens and irritants, and by breathing in corticosteroids. Leukotriene antagonists are less effective than corticosteroids and therefore less preferred.  Its diagnosis is usually made based on the pattern of symptoms and/or response to treatment over time. The prevalence of asthma has increased significantly since the 1970s. As of 2010, 300 million people were impacted worldwide. In 2009 asthma caused 250,000 deaths globally. Despite this, with the right control of asthma with step down treatment, outcome is generally good.  Causes  Asthma is caused by environmental and genetic factors. These factors determine how serious asthma is and how well it responds to medicine. The interaction is complex and not fully understood.  Examining the prevalence of asthma and related conditions such as eczema and hay fever have given important clues about some key risk factors. The strongest risk factor for getting asthma is a history of atopic diseases; this increases one's risk of hay fever by up to 5× and the risk of asthma by 3–4×. In children between the ages of 3–14, a positive skin test for allergies and an increase in immunoglobulin E increases the chance of getting asthma. In adults, the more allergens one reacts positively to in a skin test, the higher the odds of getting asthma.  Because much allergic asthma is linked with sensitivity to indoor allergens and because Western styles of housing favor greater exposure to indoor allergens, much attention has centered on increased exposure to these allergens in infancy and early childhood as a main cause of the rise in asthma. Primary prevention studies aimed at the aggressive reduction of airborne allergens in a home with infants have shown mixed findings. Strict reduction of dust mite allergens, for example, cuts down the risk of allergic sensitization to dust mites, and modestly cuts down the risk of getting asthma up until the age of 8 years old. However, studies also showed that the effects of exposure to cat and dog allergens worked in the converse way; exposure during the first year of life was found to cut down the risk of allergic sensitization and of getting asthma later in life.  The inconsistency of this information has inspired research into other aspects of Western society and their impact upon the prevalence of asthma. One subject that seems to show a strong correlation is the development of asthma and obesity. In the United Kingdom and United States, the increase in asthma prevalence has echoed an almost epidemic increase in the prevalence of obesity. In Taiwan, symptoms of allergies and airway hyper-reactivity increased in correlation with each 20% increase in body-mass index. Many factors linked with obesity may play a part in the pathogenesis of asthma, including reduced respiratory function due to a buildup of adipose tissue (fat) and the fact that adipose tissue leads to a pro-inflammatory state, which has been linked with non-eosinophilic asthma.  Asthma has been linked with Churg–Strauss syndrome, and someone with immunologically mediated urticaria (hives) may also have systemic symptoms with generalized urticaria (hives), rhino-conjunctivitis, orolaryngeal and gastrointestinal (stomach) symptoms, asthma, and, at worst, allergic shock. Additionally, adult-onset asthma has been linked with periocular xanthogranulomas.   "

In Taiwan, symptoms of allergies and airway hyper-reactivity increased in correlation with each 20% increase in body-mass index. Many factors linked with obesity may play a part in the pathogenesis of asthma, including reduced respiratory function due to a buildup of adipose tissue (fat) and the fact that adipose tissue leads to a pro-inflammatory state, which has been linked with non-eosinophilic asthma.  Asthma has been linked with Churg–Strauss syndrome, and someone with immunologically mediated urticaria (hives) may also have systemic symptoms with generalized urticaria (hives), rhino-conjunctivitis, orolaryngeal and gastrointestinal (stomach) symptoms, asthma, and, at worst, allergic shock. Additionally, adult-onset asthma has been linked with periocular xanthogranulomas.   "
589b7ed5-ff30-4c28-978b-058c400ea8b9@13@breathing@breathing@0@function respiratory,functions respiratory,respiratory function,respiratory system process,inspiration,respiratory inspiration,inspiration function,Use verb form: breathe,@"Asthma (from the Greek ?????, ásthma, "panting") is the common chronic inflammatory condition of the respiratory tract characterized by variable and recurring symptoms, reversible blocked airflow, and bronchial spasms. Symptoms include wheezing, coughing, chest tightness, and shortness of breath. Asthma is clinically classed according to how often symptoms happen, forced expiration volume in 1 second (FEV1), and peak expiration flow rate. Asthma may also be classed as atopic (extrinsic) or non-atopic (intrinsic).   It is thought to be caused by a combination of genetic and environmental factors. Treating acute symptoms is usually with an inhaled short-acting beta-2 agonist (such as salbutamol). Symptoms can be prevented by avoiding triggers, such as allergens and irritants, and by breathing in corticosteroids. Leukotriene antagonists are less effective than corticosteroids and therefore less preferred.  Its diagnosis is usually made based on the pattern of symptoms and/or response to treatment over time. The prevalence of asthma has increased significantly since the 1970s. As of 2010, 300 million people were impacted worldwide. In 2009 asthma caused 250,000 deaths globally. Despite this, with the right control of asthma with step down treatment, outcome is generally good.  Causes  Asthma is caused by environmental and genetic factors. These factors determine how serious asthma is and how well it responds to medicine. The interaction is complex and not fully understood.  Examining the prevalence of asthma and related conditions such as eczema and hay fever have given important clues about some key risk factors. The strongest risk factor for getting asthma is a history of atopic diseases; this increases one's risk of hay fever by up to 5× and the risk of asthma by 3–4×. In children between the ages of 3–14, a positive skin test for allergies and an increase in immunoglobulin E increases the chance of getting asthma. In adults, the more allergens one reacts positively to in a skin test, the higher the odds of getting asthma.  Because much allergic asthma is linked with sensitivity to indoor allergens and because Western styles of housing favor greater exposure to indoor allergens, much attention has centered on increased exposure to these allergens in infancy and early childhood as a main cause of the rise in asthma. Primary prevention studies aimed at the aggressive reduction of airborne allergens in a home with infants have shown mixed findings. Strict reduction of dust mite allergens, for example, cuts down the risk of allergic sensitization to dust mites, and modestly cuts down the risk of getting asthma up until the age of 8 years old. However, studies also showed that the effects of exposure to cat and dog allergens worked in the converse way; exposure during the first year of life was found to cut down the risk of allergic sensitization and of getting asthma later in life.  The inconsistency of this information has inspired research into other aspects of Western society and their impact upon the prevalence of asthma. One subject that seems to show a strong correlation is the development of asthma and obesity. In the United Kingdom and United States, the increase in asthma prevalence has echoed an almost epidemic increase in the prevalence of obesity. In Taiwan, symptoms of allergies and airway hyper-reactivity increased in correlation with each 20% increase in body-mass index. Many factors linked with obesity may play a part in the pathogenesis of asthma, including reduced respiratory function due to a buildup of adipose tissue (fat) and the fact that adipose tissue leads to a pro-inflammatory state, which has been linked with non-eosinophilic asthma.  Asthma has been linked with Churg–Strauss syndrome, and someone with immunologically mediated urticaria (hives) may also have systemic symptoms with generalized urticaria (hives), rhino-conjunctivitis, orolaryngeal and gastrointestinal (stomach) symptoms, asthma, and, at worst, allergic shock. Additionally, adult-onset asthma has been linked with periocular xanthogranulomas.   "

In children between the ages of 3–14, a positive skin test for allergies and an increase in immunoglobulin E increases the chance of getting asthma. In adults, the more allergens one reacts positively to in a skin test, the higher the odds of getting asthma.  Because much allergic asthma is linked with sensitivity to indoor allergens and because Western styles of housing favor greater exposure to indoor allergens, much attention has centered on increased exposure to these allergens in infancy and early childhood as a main cause of the rise in asthma. Primary prevention studies aimed at the aggressive reduction of airborne allergens in a home with infants have shown mixed findings. Strict reduction of dust mite allergens, for example, cuts down the risk of allergic sensitization to dust mites, and modestly cuts down the risk of getting asthma up until the age of 8 years old. However, studies also showed that the effects of exposure to cat and dog allergens worked in the converse way; exposure during the first year of life was found to cut down the risk of allergic sensitization and of getting asthma later in life.  The inconsistency of this information has inspired research into other aspects of Western society and their impact upon the prevalence of asthma. One subject that seems to show a strong correlation is the development of asthma and obesity. In the United Kingdom and United States, the increase in asthma prevalence has echoed an almost epidemic increase in the prevalence of obesity. In Taiwan, symptoms of allergies and airway hyper-reactivity increased in correlation with each 20% increase in body-mass index. Many factors linked with obesity may play a part in the pathogenesis of asthma, including reduced respiratory function due to a buildup of adipose tissue (fat) and the fact that adipose tissue leads to a pro-inflammatory state, which has been linked with non-eosinophilic asthma.  Asthma has been linked with Churg–Strauss syndrome, and someone with immunologically mediated urticaria (hives) may also have systemic symptoms with generalized urticaria (hives), rhino-conjunctivitis, orolaryngeal and gastrointestinal (stomach) symptoms, asthma, and, at worst, allergic shock. Additionally, adult-onset asthma has been linked with periocular xanthogranulomas.   "
589b7ed5-ff30-4c28-978b-058c400ea8b9@13@usually@usually@0@[usuall] [y] :	[usuall] [condition or process of],@"Asthma (from the Greek ?????, ásthma, "panting") is the common chronic inflammatory condition of the respiratory tract characterized by variable and recurring symptoms, reversible blocked airflow, and bronchial spasms. Symptoms include wheezing, coughing, chest tightness, and shortness of breath. Asthma is clinically classed according to how often symptoms happen, forced expiration volume in 1 second (FEV1), and peak expiration flow rate. Asthma may also be classed as atopic (extrinsic) or non-atopic (intrinsic).   It is thought to be caused by a combination of genetic and environmental factors. Treating acute symptoms is usually with an inhaled short-acting beta-2 agonist (such as salbutamol). Symptoms can be prevented by avoiding triggers, such as allergens and irritants, and by breathing in corticosteroids. Leukotriene antagonists are less effective than corticosteroids and therefore less preferred.  Its diagnosis is usually made based on the pattern of symptoms and/or response to treatment over time. The prevalence of asthma has increased significantly since the 1970s. As of 2010, 300 million people were impacted worldwide. In 2009 asthma caused 250,000 deaths globally. Despite this, with the right control of asthma with step down treatment, outcome is generally good.  Causes  Asthma is caused by environmental and genetic factors. These factors determine how serious asthma is and how well it responds to medicine. The interaction is complex and not fully understood.  Examining the prevalence of asthma and related conditions such as eczema and hay fever have given important clues about some key risk factors. The strongest risk factor for getting asthma is a history of atopic diseases; this increases one's risk of hay fever by up to 5× and the risk of asthma by 3–4×. In children between the ages of 3–14, a positive skin test for allergies and an increase in immunoglobulin E increases the chance of getting asthma. In adults, the more allergens one reacts positively to in a skin test, the higher the odds of getting asthma.  Because much allergic asthma is linked with sensitivity to indoor allergens and because Western styles of housing favor greater exposure to indoor allergens, much attention has centered on increased exposure to these allergens in infancy and early childhood as a main cause of the rise in asthma. Primary prevention studies aimed at the aggressive reduction of airborne allergens in a home with infants have shown mixed findings. Strict reduction of dust mite allergens, for example, cuts down the risk of allergic sensitization to dust mites, and modestly cuts down the risk of getting asthma up until the age of 8 years old. However, studies also showed that the effects of exposure to cat and dog allergens worked in the converse way; exposure during the first year of life was found to cut down the risk of allergic sensitization and of getting asthma later in life.  The inconsistency of this information has inspired research into other aspects of Western society and their impact upon the prevalence of asthma. One subject that seems to show a strong correlation is the development of asthma and obesity. In the United Kingdom and United States, the increase in asthma prevalence has echoed an almost epidemic increase in the prevalence of obesity. In Taiwan, symptoms of allergies and airway hyper-reactivity increased in correlation with each 20% increase in body-mass index. Many factors linked with obesity may play a part in the pathogenesis of asthma, including reduced respiratory function due to a buildup of adipose tissue (fat) and the fact that adipose tissue leads to a pro-inflammatory state, which has been linked with non-eosinophilic asthma.  Asthma has been linked with Churg–Strauss syndrome, and someone with immunologically mediated urticaria (hives) may also have systemic symptoms with generalized urticaria (hives), rhino-conjunctivitis, orolaryngeal and gastrointestinal (stomach) symptoms, asthma, and, at worst, allergic shock. Additionally, adult-onset asthma has been linked with periocular xanthogranulomas.   "

Asthma is clinically classed according to how often symptoms happen, forced expiration volume in 1 second (FEV1), and peak expiration flow rate. Asthma may also be classed as atopic (extrinsic) or non-atopic (intrinsic).   It is thought to be caused by a combination of genetic and environmental factors. Treating acute symptoms is usually with an inhaled short-acting beta-2 agonist (such as salbutamol). Symptoms can be prevented by avoiding triggers, such as allergens and irritants, and by breathing in corticosteroids. Leukotriene antagonists are less effective than corticosteroids and therefore less preferred.  Its diagnosis is usually made based on the pattern of symptoms and/or response to treatment over time. The prevalence of asthma has increased significantly since the 1970s. As of 2010, 300 million people were impacted worldwide. In 2009 asthma caused 250,000 deaths globally. Despite this, with the right control of asthma with step down treatment, outcome is generally good.  Causes  Asthma is caused by environmental and genetic factors. These factors determine how serious asthma is and how well it responds to medicine. The interaction is complex and not fully understood.  Examining the prevalence of asthma and related conditions such as eczema and hay fever have given important clues about some key risk factors. The strongest risk factor for getting asthma is a history of atopic diseases; this increases one's risk of hay fever by up to 5× and the risk of asthma by 3–4×. In children between the ages of 3–14, a positive skin test for allergies and an increase in immunoglobulin E increases the chance of getting asthma. In adults, the more allergens one reacts positively to in a skin test, the higher the odds of getting asthma.  Because much allergic asthma is linked with sensitivity to indoor allergens and because Western styles of housing favor greater exposure to indoor allergens, much attention has centered on increased exposure to these allergens in infancy and early childhood as a main cause of the rise in asthma. Primary prevention studies aimed at the aggressive reduction of airborne allergens in a home with infants have shown mixed findings. Strict reduction of dust mite allergens, for example, cuts down the risk of allergic sensitization to dust mites, and modestly cuts down the risk of getting asthma up until the age of 8 years old. However, studies also showed that the effects of exposure to cat and dog allergens worked in the converse way; exposure during the first year of life was found to cut down the risk of allergic sensitization and of getting asthma later in life.  The inconsistency of this information has inspired research into other aspects of Western society and their impact upon the prevalence of asthma. One subject that seems to show a strong correlation is the development of asthma and obesity. In the United Kingdom and United States, the increase in asthma prevalence has echoed an almost epidemic increase in the prevalence of obesity. In Taiwan, symptoms of allergies and airway hyper-reactivity increased in correlation with each 20% increase in body-mass index. Many factors linked with obesity may play a part in the pathogenesis of asthma, including reduced respiratory function due to a buildup of adipose tissue (fat) and the fact that adipose tissue leads to a pro-inflammatory state, which has been linked with non-eosinophilic asthma.  Asthma has been linked with Churg–Strauss syndrome, and someone with immunologically mediated urticaria (hives) may also have systemic symptoms with generalized urticaria (hives), rhino-conjunctivitis, orolaryngeal and gastrointestinal (stomach) symptoms, asthma, and, at worst, allergic shock. Additionally, adult-onset asthma has been linked with periocular xanthogranulomas.   "

Additionally, adult-onset asthma has been linked with periocular xanthogranulomas.   "

In Taiwan, symptoms of allergies and airway hyper-reactivity increased in correlation with each 20% increase in body-mass index. Symptoms include wheezing, coughing, chest tightness, and shortness of breath. In the United Kingdom and United States, the increase in asthma prevalence has echoed an almost epidemic increase in the prevalence of obesity. In Taiwan, symptoms of allergies and airway hyper-reactivity increased in correlation with each 20% increase in body-mass index. Many factors linked with obesity may play a part in the pathogenesis of asthma, including reduced respiratory function due to a buildup of adipose tissue (fat) and the fact that adipose tissue leads to a pro-inflammatory state, which has been linked with non-eosinophilic asthma.  Asthma has been linked with Churg–Strauss syndrome, and someone with immunologically mediated urticaria (hives) may also have systemic symptoms with generalized urticaria (hives), rhino-conjunctivitis, orolaryngeal and gastrointestinal (stomach) symptoms, asthma, and, at worst, allergic shock. Additionally, adult-onset asthma has been linked with periocular xanthogranulomas.   "
589b7ed5-ff30-4c28-978b-058c400ea8b9@13@control@control@0@[co] [ntrol] :	[with, together, in association] [ntrol],@"Asthma (from the Greek ?????, ásthma, "panting") is the common chronic inflammatory condition of the respiratory tract characterized by variable and recurring symptoms, reversible blocked airflow, and bronchial spasms. Symptoms include wheezing, coughing, chest tightness, and shortness of breath. Asthma is clinically classed according to how often symptoms happen, forced expiration volume in 1 second (FEV1), and peak expiration flow rate. Asthma may also be classed as atopic (extrinsic) or non-atopic (intrinsic).   It is thought to be caused by a combination of genetic and environmental factors. Treating acute symptoms is usually with an inhaled short-acting beta-2 agonist (such as salbutamol). Symptoms can be prevented by avoiding triggers, such as allergens and irritants, and by breathing in corticosteroids. Leukotriene antagonists are less effective than corticosteroids and therefore less preferred.  Its diagnosis is usually made based on the pattern of symptoms and/or response to treatment over time. The prevalence of asthma has increased significantly since the 1970s. As of 2010, 300 million people were impacted worldwide. In 2009 asthma caused 250,000 deaths globally. Despite this, with the right control of asthma with step down treatment, outcome is generally good.  Causes  Asthma is caused by environmental and genetic factors. These factors determine how serious asthma is and how well it responds to medicine. The interaction is complex and not fully understood.  Examining the prevalence of asthma and related conditions such as eczema and hay fever have given important clues about some key risk factors. The strongest risk factor for getting asthma is a history of atopic diseases; this increases one's risk of hay fever by up to 5× and the risk of asthma by 3–4×. In children between the ages of 3–14, a positive skin test for allergies and an increase in immunoglobulin E increases the chance of getting asthma. In adults, the more allergens one reacts positively to in a skin test, the higher the odds of getting asthma.  Because much allergic asthma is linked with sensitivity to indoor allergens and because Western styles of housing favor greater exposure to indoor allergens, much attention has centered on increased exposure to these allergens in infancy and early childhood as a main cause of the rise in asthma. Primary prevention studies aimed at the aggressive reduction of airborne allergens in a home with infants have shown mixed findings. Strict reduction of dust mite allergens, for example, cuts down the risk of allergic sensitization to dust mites, and modestly cuts down the risk of getting asthma up until the age of 8 years old. However, studies also showed that the effects of exposure to cat and dog allergens worked in the converse way; exposure during the first year of life was found to cut down the risk of allergic sensitization and of getting asthma later in life.  The inconsistency of this information has inspired research into other aspects of Western society and their impact upon the prevalence of asthma. One subject that seems to show a strong correlation is the development of asthma and obesity. In the United Kingdom and United States, the increase in asthma prevalence has echoed an almost epidemic increase in the prevalence of obesity. In Taiwan, symptoms of allergies and airway hyper-reactivity increased in correlation with each 20% increase in body-mass index. Many factors linked with obesity may play a part in the pathogenesis of asthma, including reduced respiratory function due to a buildup of adipose tissue (fat) and the fact that adipose tissue leads to a pro-inflammatory state, which has been linked with non-eosinophilic asthma.  Asthma has been linked with Churg–Strauss syndrome, and someone with immunologically mediated urticaria (hives) may also have systemic symptoms with generalized urticaria (hives), rhino-conjunctivitis, orolaryngeal and gastrointestinal (stomach) symptoms, asthma, and, at worst, allergic shock. Additionally, adult-onset asthma has been linked with periocular xanthogranulomas.   "
