In children between the ages of 3–14, a positive skin test for allergies and an increase in immunoglobulin E increases the chance of getting asthma. In adults, the more allergens one reacts positively to in a skin test, the higher the odds of getting asthma.  Because much allergic asthma is linked with sensitivity to indoor allergens and because Western styles of housing favor greater exposure to indoor allergens, much attention has centered on increased exposure to these allergens in infancy and early childhood as a main cause of the rise in asthma. Primary prevention studies aimed at the aggressive reduction of airborne allergens in a home with infants have shown mixed findings. Strict reduction of dust mite allergens, for example, cuts down the risk of allergic sensitization to dust mites, and modestly cuts down the risk of getting asthma up until the age of 8 years old. However, studies also showed that the effects of exposure to cat and dog allergens worked in the converse way; exposure during the first year of life was found to cut down the risk of allergic sensitization and of getting asthma later in life.  The inconsistency of this information has inspired research into other aspects of Western society and their impact upon the prevalence of asthma. One subject that seems to show a strong correlation is the development of asthma and obesity. In the United Kingdom and United States, the increase in asthma prevalence has echoed an almost epidemic increase in the prevalence of obesity. In Taiwan, symptoms of allergies and airway hyper-reactivity increased in correlation with each 20% increase in body-mass index. Many factors linked with obesity may play a part in the pathogenesis of asthma, including reduced respiratory function due to a buildup of adipose tissue (fat) and the fact that adipose tissue leads to a pro-inflammatory state, which has been linked with non-eosinophilic asthma.  Asthma has been linked with Churg–Strauss syndrome, and someone with immunologically mediated urticaria (hives) may also have systemic symptoms with generalized urticaria (hives), rhino-conjunctivitis, orolaryngeal and gastrointestinal (stomach) symptoms, asthma, and, at worst, allergic shock. Additionally, adult-onset asthma has been linked with periocular xanthogranulomas.   "
589b7ed5-ff30-4c28-978b-058c400ea8b9@13@factors@factors@0@agent,@"Asthma (from the Greek ?????, ásthma, "panting") is the common chronic inflammatory condition of the respiratory tract characterized by variable and recurring symptoms, reversible blocked airflow, and bronchial spasms. Symptoms include wheezing, coughing, chest tightness, and shortness of breath. Asthma is clinically classed according to how often symptoms happen, forced expiration volume in 1 second (FEV1), and peak expiration flow rate. Asthma may also be classed as atopic (extrinsic) or non-atopic (intrinsic).   It is thought to be caused by a combination of genetic and environmental factors. Treating acute symptoms is usually with an inhaled short-acting beta-2 agonist (such as salbutamol). Symptoms can be prevented by avoiding triggers, such as allergens and irritants, and by breathing in corticosteroids. Leukotriene antagonists are less effective than corticosteroids and therefore less preferred.  Its diagnosis is usually made based on the pattern of symptoms and/or response to treatment over time. The prevalence of asthma has increased significantly since the 1970s. As of 2010, 300 million people were impacted worldwide. In 2009 asthma caused 250,000 deaths globally. Despite this, with the right control of asthma with step down treatment, outcome is generally good.  Causes  Asthma is caused by environmental and genetic factors. These factors determine how serious asthma is and how well it responds to medicine. The interaction is complex and not fully understood.  Examining the prevalence of asthma and related conditions such as eczema and hay fever have given important clues about some key risk factors. The strongest risk factor for getting asthma is a history of atopic diseases; this increases one's risk of hay fever by up to 5× and the risk of asthma by 3–4×. In children between the ages of 3–14, a positive skin test for allergies and an increase in immunoglobulin E increases the chance of getting asthma. In adults, the more allergens one reacts positively to in a skin test, the higher the odds of getting asthma.  Because much allergic asthma is linked with sensitivity to indoor allergens and because Western styles of housing favor greater exposure to indoor allergens, much attention has centered on increased exposure to these allergens in infancy and early childhood as a main cause of the rise in asthma. Primary prevention studies aimed at the aggressive reduction of airborne allergens in a home with infants have shown mixed findings. Strict reduction of dust mite allergens, for example, cuts down the risk of allergic sensitization to dust mites, and modestly cuts down the risk of getting asthma up until the age of 8 years old. However, studies also showed that the effects of exposure to cat and dog allergens worked in the converse way; exposure during the first year of life was found to cut down the risk of allergic sensitization and of getting asthma later in life.  The inconsistency of this information has inspired research into other aspects of Western society and their impact upon the prevalence of asthma. One subject that seems to show a strong correlation is the development of asthma and obesity. In the United Kingdom and United States, the increase in asthma prevalence has echoed an almost epidemic increase in the prevalence of obesity. In Taiwan, symptoms of allergies and airway hyper-reactivity increased in correlation with each 20% increase in body-mass index. Many factors linked with obesity may play a part in the pathogenesis of asthma, including reduced respiratory function due to a buildup of adipose tissue (fat) and the fact that adipose tissue leads to a pro-inflammatory state, which has been linked with non-eosinophilic asthma.  Asthma has been linked with Churg–Strauss syndrome, and someone with immunologically mediated urticaria (hives) may also have systemic symptoms with generalized urticaria (hives), rhino-conjunctivitis, orolaryngeal and gastrointestinal (stomach) symptoms, asthma, and, at worst, allergic shock. Additionally, adult-onset asthma has been linked with periocular xanthogranulomas.   "

Leukotriene antagonists are less effective than corticosteroids and therefore less preferred.  Its diagnosis is usually made based on the pattern of symptoms and/or response to treatment over time. One subject that seems to show a strong correlation is the development of asthma and obesity. In the United Kingdom and United States, the increase in asthma prevalence has echoed an almost epidemic increase in the prevalence of obesity. In Taiwan, symptoms of allergies and airway hyper-reactivity increased in correlation with each 20% increase in body-mass index. Many factors linked with obesity may play a part in the pathogenesis of asthma, including reduced respiratory function due to a buildup of adipose tissue (fat) and the fact that adipose tissue leads to a pro-inflammatory state, which has been linked with non-eosinophilic asthma.  Asthma has been linked with Churg–Strauss syndrome, and someone with immunologically mediated urticaria (hives) may also have systemic symptoms with generalized urticaria (hives), rhino-conjunctivitis, orolaryngeal and gastrointestinal (stomach) symptoms, asthma, and, at worst, allergic shock. Additionally, adult-onset asthma has been linked with periocular xanthogranulomas.   "

Symptoms include wheezing, coughing, chest tightness, and shortness of breath. Leukotriene antagonists are less effective than corticosteroids and therefore less preferred.  Its diagnosis is usually made based on the pattern of symptoms and/or response to treatment over time. Symptoms include wheezing, coughing, chest tightness, and shortness of breath. Asthma is clinically classed according to how often symptoms happen, forced expiration volume in 1 second (FEV1), and peak expiration flow rate. Symptoms can be prevented by avoiding triggers, such as allergens and irritants, and by breathing in corticosteroids. Leukotriene antagonists are less effective than corticosteroids and therefore less preferred.  Its diagnosis is usually made based on the pattern of symptoms and/or response to treatment over time. The prevalence of asthma has increased significantly since the 1970s. As of 2010, 300 million people were impacted worldwide. In 2009 asthma caused 250,000 deaths globally. Despite this, with the right control of asthma with step down treatment, outcome is generally good.  Causes  Asthma is caused by environmental and genetic factors. These factors determine how serious asthma is and how well it responds to medicine. The interaction is complex and not fully understood.  Examining the prevalence of asthma and related conditions such as eczema and hay fever have given important clues about some key risk factors. The strongest risk factor for getting asthma is a history of atopic diseases; this increases one's risk of hay fever by up to 5× and the risk of asthma by 3–4×. In children between the ages of 3–14, a positive skin test for allergies and an increase in immunoglobulin E increases the chance of getting asthma. In adults, the more allergens one reacts positively to in a skin test, the higher the odds of getting asthma.  Because much allergic asthma is linked with sensitivity to indoor allergens and because Western styles of housing favor greater exposure to indoor allergens, much attention has centered on increased exposure to these allergens in infancy and early childhood as a main cause of the rise in asthma. Primary prevention studies aimed at the aggressive reduction of airborne allergens in a home with infants have shown mixed findings. Strict reduction of dust mite allergens, for example, cuts down the risk of allergic sensitization to dust mites, and modestly cuts down the risk of getting asthma up until the age of 8 years old. However, studies also showed that the effects of exposure to cat and dog allergens worked in the converse way; exposure during the first year of life was found to cut down the risk of allergic sensitization and of getting asthma later in life.  The inconsistency of this information has inspired research into other aspects of Western society and their impact upon the prevalence of asthma. One subject that seems to show a strong correlation is the development of asthma and obesity. In the United Kingdom and United States, the increase in asthma prevalence has echoed an almost epidemic increase in the prevalence of obesity. In Taiwan, symptoms of allergies and airway hyper-reactivity increased in correlation with each 20% increase in body-mass index. Many factors linked with obesity may play a part in the pathogenesis of asthma, including reduced respiratory function due to a buildup of adipose tissue (fat) and the fact that adipose tissue leads to a pro-inflammatory state, which has been linked with non-eosinophilic asthma.  Asthma has been linked with Churg–Strauss syndrome, and someone with immunologically mediated urticaria (hives) may also have systemic symptoms with generalized urticaria (hives), rhino-conjunctivitis, orolaryngeal and gastrointestinal (stomach) symptoms, asthma, and, at worst, allergic shock. Additionally, adult-onset asthma has been linked with periocular xanthogranulomas.   "
589b7ed5-ff30-4c28-978b-058c400ea8b9@13@interaction@interaction@0@Use verb form: interact,@"Asthma (from the Greek ?????, ásthma, "panting") is the common chronic inflammatory condition of the respiratory tract characterized by variable and recurring symptoms, reversible blocked airflow, and bronchial spasms. Symptoms include wheezing, coughing, chest tightness, and shortness of breath. Asthma is clinically classed according to how often symptoms happen, forced expiration volume in 1 second (FEV1), and peak expiration flow rate. Asthma may also be classed as atopic (extrinsic) or non-atopic (intrinsic).   It is thought to be caused by a combination of genetic and environmental factors. Treating acute symptoms is usually with an inhaled short-acting beta-2 agonist (such as salbutamol). Symptoms can be prevented by avoiding triggers, such as allergens and irritants, and by breathing in corticosteroids. Leukotriene antagonists are less effective than corticosteroids and therefore less preferred.  Its diagnosis is usually made based on the pattern of symptoms and/or response to treatment over time. The prevalence of asthma has increased significantly since the 1970s. As of 2010, 300 million people were impacted worldwide. In 2009 asthma caused 250,000 deaths globally. Despite this, with the right control of asthma with step down treatment, outcome is generally good.  Causes  Asthma is caused by environmental and genetic factors. These factors determine how serious asthma is and how well it responds to medicine. The interaction is complex and not fully understood.  Examining the prevalence of asthma and related conditions such as eczema and hay fever have given important clues about some key risk factors. The strongest risk factor for getting asthma is a history of atopic diseases; this increases one's risk of hay fever by up to 5× and the risk of asthma by 3–4×. In children between the ages of 3–14, a positive skin test for allergies and an increase in immunoglobulin E increases the chance of getting asthma. In adults, the more allergens one reacts positively to in a skin test, the higher the odds of getting asthma.  Because much allergic asthma is linked with sensitivity to indoor allergens and because Western styles of housing favor greater exposure to indoor allergens, much attention has centered on increased exposure to these allergens in infancy and early childhood as a main cause of the rise in asthma. Primary prevention studies aimed at the aggressive reduction of airborne allergens in a home with infants have shown mixed findings. Strict reduction of dust mite allergens, for example, cuts down the risk of allergic sensitization to dust mites, and modestly cuts down the risk of getting asthma up until the age of 8 years old. However, studies also showed that the effects of exposure to cat and dog allergens worked in the converse way; exposure during the first year of life was found to cut down the risk of allergic sensitization and of getting asthma later in life.  The inconsistency of this information has inspired research into other aspects of Western society and their impact upon the prevalence of asthma. One subject that seems to show a strong correlation is the development of asthma and obesity. In the United Kingdom and United States, the increase in asthma prevalence has echoed an almost epidemic increase in the prevalence of obesity. In Taiwan, symptoms of allergies and airway hyper-reactivity increased in correlation with each 20% increase in body-mass index. Many factors linked with obesity may play a part in the pathogenesis of asthma, including reduced respiratory function due to a buildup of adipose tissue (fat) and the fact that adipose tissue leads to a pro-inflammatory state, which has been linked with non-eosinophilic asthma.  Asthma has been linked with Churg–Strauss syndrome, and someone with immunologically mediated urticaria (hives) may also have systemic symptoms with generalized urticaria (hives), rhino-conjunctivitis, orolaryngeal and gastrointestinal (stomach) symptoms, asthma, and, at worst, allergic shock. Additionally, adult-onset asthma has been linked with periocular xanthogranulomas.   "

589b7ed5-ff30-4c28-978b-058c400ea8b9@13@understood@understood@0@understanding,@"Asthma (from the Greek ?????, ásthma, "panting") is the common chronic inflammatory condition of the respiratory tract characterized by variable and recurring symptoms, reversible blocked airflow, and bronchial spasms. Symptoms include wheezing, coughing, chest tightness, and shortness of breath. Asthma is clinically classed according to how often symptoms happen, forced expiration volume in 1 second (FEV1), and peak expiration flow rate. Asthma may also be classed as atopic (extrinsic) or non-atopic (intrinsic).   It is thought to be caused by a combination of genetic and environmental factors. Treating acute symptoms is usually with an inhaled short-acting beta-2 agonist (such as salbutamol). Symptoms can be prevented by avoiding triggers, such as allergens and irritants, and by breathing in corticosteroids. Leukotriene antagonists are less effective than corticosteroids and therefore less preferred.  Its diagnosis is usually made based on the pattern of symptoms and/or response to treatment over time. The prevalence of asthma has increased significantly since the 1970s. As of 2010, 300 million people were impacted worldwide. In 2009 asthma caused 250,000 deaths globally. Despite this, with the right control of asthma with step down treatment, outcome is generally good.  Causes  Asthma is caused by environmental and genetic factors. These factors determine how serious asthma is and how well it responds to medicine. The interaction is complex and not fully understood.  Examining the prevalence of asthma and related conditions such as eczema and hay fever have given important clues about some key risk factors. The strongest risk factor for getting asthma is a history of atopic diseases; this increases one's risk of hay fever by up to 5× and the risk of asthma by 3–4×. In children between the ages of 3–14, a positive skin test for allergies and an increase in immunoglobulin E increases the chance of getting asthma. In adults, the more allergens one reacts positively to in a skin test, the higher the odds of getting asthma.  Because much allergic asthma is linked with sensitivity to indoor allergens and because Western styles of housing favor greater exposure to indoor allergens, much attention has centered on increased exposure to these allergens in infancy and early childhood as a main cause of the rise in asthma. Primary prevention studies aimed at the aggressive reduction of airborne allergens in a home with infants have shown mixed findings. Strict reduction of dust mite allergens, for example, cuts down the risk of allergic sensitization to dust mites, and modestly cuts down the risk of getting asthma up until the age of 8 years old. However, studies also showed that the effects of exposure to cat and dog allergens worked in the converse way; exposure during the first year of life was found to cut down the risk of allergic sensitization and of getting asthma later in life.  The inconsistency of this information has inspired research into other aspects of Western society and their impact upon the prevalence of asthma. One subject that seems to show a strong correlation is the development of asthma and obesity. In the United Kingdom and United States, the increase in asthma prevalence has echoed an almost epidemic increase in the prevalence of obesity. In Taiwan, symptoms of allergies and airway hyper-reactivity increased in correlation with each 20% increase in body-mass index. Many factors linked with obesity may play a part in the pathogenesis of asthma, including reduced respiratory function due to a buildup of adipose tissue (fat) and the fact that adipose tissue leads to a pro-inflammatory state, which has been linked with non-eosinophilic asthma.  Asthma has been linked with Churg–Strauss syndrome, and someone with immunologically mediated urticaria (hives) may also have systemic symptoms with generalized urticaria (hives), rhino-conjunctivitis, orolaryngeal and gastrointestinal (stomach) symptoms, asthma, and, at worst, allergic shock. Additionally, adult-onset asthma has been linked with periocular xanthogranulomas.   "

In Taiwan, symptoms of allergies and airway hyper-reactivity increased in correlation with each 20% increase in body-mass index. Asthma has been linked with Churg–Strauss syndrome, and someone with immunologically mediated urticaria (hives) may also have systemic symptoms with generalized urticaria (hives), rhino-conjunctivitis, orolaryngeal and gastrointestinal (stomach) symptoms, asthma, and, at worst, allergic shock. Additionally, adult-onset asthma has been linked with periocular xanthogranulomas.   "
589b7ed5-ff30-4c28-978b-058c400ea8b9@13@eczema@eczema@0@[ec] [zema] :	[out, away] [zema],@"Asthma (from the Greek ?????, ásthma, "panting") is the common chronic inflammatory condition of the respiratory tract characterized by variable and recurring symptoms, reversible blocked airflow, and bronchial spasms. Symptoms include wheezing, coughing, chest tightness, and shortness of breath. Asthma is clinically classed according to how often symptoms happen, forced expiration volume in 1 second (FEV1), and peak expiration flow rate. Asthma may also be classed as atopic (extrinsic) or non-atopic (intrinsic).   It is thought to be caused by a combination of genetic and environmental factors. Treating acute symptoms is usually with an inhaled short-acting beta-2 agonist (such as salbutamol). Symptoms can be prevented by avoiding triggers, such as allergens and irritants, and by breathing in corticosteroids. Leukotriene antagonists are less effective than corticosteroids and therefore less preferred.  Its diagnosis is usually made based on the pattern of symptoms and/or response to treatment over time. The prevalence of asthma has increased significantly since the 1970s. As of 2010, 300 million people were impacted worldwide. In 2009 asthma caused 250,000 deaths globally. Despite this, with the right control of asthma with step down treatment, outcome is generally good.  Causes  Asthma is caused by environmental and genetic factors. These factors determine how serious asthma is and how well it responds to medicine. The interaction is complex and not fully understood.  Examining the prevalence of asthma and related conditions such as eczema and hay fever have given important clues about some key risk factors. The strongest risk factor for getting asthma is a history of atopic diseases; this increases one's risk of hay fever by up to 5× and the risk of asthma by 3–4×. In children between the ages of 3–14, a positive skin test for allergies and an increase in immunoglobulin E increases the chance of getting asthma. In adults, the more allergens one reacts positively to in a skin test, the higher the odds of getting asthma.  Because much allergic asthma is linked with sensitivity to indoor allergens and because Western styles of housing favor greater exposure to indoor allergens, much attention has centered on increased exposure to these allergens in infancy and early childhood as a main cause of the rise in asthma. Primary prevention studies aimed at the aggressive reduction of airborne allergens in a home with infants have shown mixed findings. Strict reduction of dust mite allergens, for example, cuts down the risk of allergic sensitization to dust mites, and modestly cuts down the risk of getting asthma up until the age of 8 years old. However, studies also showed that the effects of exposure to cat and dog allergens worked in the converse way; exposure during the first year of life was found to cut down the risk of allergic sensitization and of getting asthma later in life.  The inconsistency of this information has inspired research into other aspects of Western society and their impact upon the prevalence of asthma. One subject that seems to show a strong correlation is the development of asthma and obesity. In the United Kingdom and United States, the increase in asthma prevalence has echoed an almost epidemic increase in the prevalence of obesity. In Taiwan, symptoms of allergies and airway hyper-reactivity increased in correlation with each 20% increase in body-mass index. Many factors linked with obesity may play a part in the pathogenesis of asthma, including reduced respiratory function due to a buildup of adipose tissue (fat) and the fact that adipose tissue leads to a pro-inflammatory state, which has been linked with non-eosinophilic asthma.  Asthma has been linked with Churg–Strauss syndrome, and someone with immunologically mediated urticaria (hives) may also have systemic symptoms with generalized urticaria (hives), rhino-conjunctivitis, orolaryngeal and gastrointestinal (stomach) symptoms, asthma, and, at worst, allergic shock. Additionally, adult-onset asthma has been linked with periocular xanthogranulomas.   "

Primary prevention studies aimed at the aggressive reduction of airborne allergens in a home with infants have shown mixed findings. Strict reduction of dust mite allergens, for example, cuts down the risk of allergic sensitization to dust mites, and modestly cuts down the risk of getting asthma up until the age of 8 years old. However, studies also showed that the effects of exposure to cat and dog allergens worked in the converse way; exposure during the first year of life was found to cut down the risk of allergic sensitization and of getting asthma later in life.  The inconsistency of this information has inspired research into other aspects of Western society and their impact upon the prevalence of asthma. One subject that seems to show a strong correlation is the development of asthma and obesity. In the United Kingdom and United States, the increase in asthma prevalence has echoed an almost epidemic increase in the prevalence of obesity. In Taiwan, symptoms of allergies and airway hyper-reactivity increased in correlation with each 20% increase in body-mass index. Many factors linked with obesity may play a part in the pathogenesis of asthma, including reduced respiratory function due to a buildup of adipose tissue (fat) and the fact that adipose tissue leads to a pro-inflammatory state, which has been linked with non-eosinophilic asthma.  Asthma has been linked with Churg–Strauss syndrome, and someone with immunologically mediated urticaria (hives) may also have systemic symptoms with generalized urticaria (hives), rhino-conjunctivitis, orolaryngeal and gastrointestinal (stomach) symptoms, asthma, and, at worst, allergic shock. Additionally, adult-onset asthma has been linked with periocular xanthogranulomas.   "
589b7ed5-ff30-4c28-978b-058c400ea8b9@13@asthma@asthma@0@[a] [sthma] :	[not, without] [sthma],@"Asthma (from the Greek ?????, ásthma, "panting") is the common chronic inflammatory condition of the respiratory tract characterized by variable and recurring symptoms, reversible blocked airflow, and bronchial spasms. Symptoms include wheezing, coughing, chest tightness, and shortness of breath. Asthma is clinically classed according to how often symptoms happen, forced expiration volume in 1 second (FEV1), and peak expiration flow rate. Asthma may also be classed as atopic (extrinsic) or non-atopic (intrinsic).   It is thought to be caused by a combination of genetic and environmental factors. Treating acute symptoms is usually with an inhaled short-acting beta-2 agonist (such as salbutamol). Symptoms can be prevented by avoiding triggers, such as allergens and irritants, and by breathing in corticosteroids. Leukotriene antagonists are less effective than corticosteroids and therefore less preferred.  Its diagnosis is usually made based on the pattern of symptoms and/or response to treatment over time. The prevalence of asthma has increased significantly since the 1970s. As of 2010, 300 million people were impacted worldwide. In 2009 asthma caused 250,000 deaths globally. Despite this, with the right control of asthma with step down treatment, outcome is generally good.  Causes  Asthma is caused by environmental and genetic factors. These factors determine how serious asthma is and how well it responds to medicine. The interaction is complex and not fully understood.  Examining the prevalence of asthma and related conditions such as eczema and hay fever have given important clues about some key risk factors. The strongest risk factor for getting asthma is a history of atopic diseases; this increases one's risk of hay fever by up to 5× and the risk of asthma by 3–4×. In children between the ages of 3–14, a positive skin test for allergies and an increase in immunoglobulin E increases the chance of getting asthma. In adults, the more allergens one reacts positively to in a skin test, the higher the odds of getting asthma.  Because much allergic asthma is linked with sensitivity to indoor allergens and because Western styles of housing favor greater exposure to indoor allergens, much attention has centered on increased exposure to these allergens in infancy and early childhood as a main cause of the rise in asthma. Primary prevention studies aimed at the aggressive reduction of airborne allergens in a home with infants have shown mixed findings. Strict reduction of dust mite allergens, for example, cuts down the risk of allergic sensitization to dust mites, and modestly cuts down the risk of getting asthma up until the age of 8 years old. However, studies also showed that the effects of exposure to cat and dog allergens worked in the converse way; exposure during the first year of life was found to cut down the risk of allergic sensitization and of getting asthma later in life.  The inconsistency of this information has inspired research into other aspects of Western society and their impact upon the prevalence of asthma. One subject that seems to show a strong correlation is the development of asthma and obesity. In the United Kingdom and United States, the increase in asthma prevalence has echoed an almost epidemic increase in the prevalence of obesity. In Taiwan, symptoms of allergies and airway hyper-reactivity increased in correlation with each 20% increase in body-mass index. Many factors linked with obesity may play a part in the pathogenesis of asthma, including reduced respiratory function due to a buildup of adipose tissue (fat) and the fact that adipose tissue leads to a pro-inflammatory state, which has been linked with non-eosinophilic asthma.  Asthma has been linked with Churg–Strauss syndrome, and someone with immunologically mediated urticaria (hives) may also have systemic symptoms with generalized urticaria (hives), rhino-conjunctivitis, orolaryngeal and gastrointestinal (stomach) symptoms, asthma, and, at worst, allergic shock. Additionally, adult-onset asthma has been linked with periocular xanthogranulomas.   "

Symptoms can be prevented by avoiding triggers, such as allergens and irritants, and by breathing in corticosteroids. Leukotriene antagonists are less effective than corticosteroids and therefore less preferred.  Its diagnosis is usually made based on the pattern of symptoms and/or response to treatment over time. The prevalence of asthma has increased significantly since the 1970s. As of 2010, 300 million people were impacted worldwide. In 2009 asthma caused 250,000 deaths globally. Despite this, with the right control of asthma with step down treatment, outcome is generally good.  Causes  Asthma is caused by environmental and genetic factors. These factors determine how serious asthma is and how well it responds to medicine. The interaction is complex and not fully understood.  Examining the prevalence of asthma and related conditions such as eczema and hay fever have given important clues about some key risk factors. The strongest risk factor for getting asthma is a history of atopic diseases; this increases one's risk of hay fever by up to 5× and the risk of asthma by 3–4×. In children between the ages of 3–14, a positive skin test for allergies and an increase in immunoglobulin E increases the chance of getting asthma. In adults, the more allergens one reacts positively to in a skin test, the higher the odds of getting asthma.  Because much allergic asthma is linked with sensitivity to indoor allergens and because Western styles of housing favor greater exposure to indoor allergens, much attention has centered on increased exposure to these allergens in infancy and early childhood as a main cause of the rise in asthma. Primary prevention studies aimed at the aggressive reduction of airborne allergens in a home with infants have shown mixed findings. Strict reduction of dust mite allergens, for example, cuts down the risk of allergic sensitization to dust mites, and modestly cuts down the risk of getting asthma up until the age of 8 years old. However, studies also showed that the effects of exposure to cat and dog allergens worked in the converse way; exposure during the first year of life was found to cut down the risk of allergic sensitization and of getting asthma later in life.  The inconsistency of this information has inspired research into other aspects of Western society and their impact upon the prevalence of asthma. One subject that seems to show a strong correlation is the development of asthma and obesity. In the United Kingdom and United States, the increase in asthma prevalence has echoed an almost epidemic increase in the prevalence of obesity. In Taiwan, symptoms of allergies and airway hyper-reactivity increased in correlation with each 20% increase in body-mass index. Many factors linked with obesity may play a part in the pathogenesis of asthma, including reduced respiratory function due to a buildup of adipose tissue (fat) and the fact that adipose tissue leads to a pro-inflammatory state, which has been linked with non-eosinophilic asthma.  Asthma has been linked with Churg–Strauss syndrome, and someone with immunologically mediated urticaria (hives) may also have systemic symptoms with generalized urticaria (hives), rhino-conjunctivitis, orolaryngeal and gastrointestinal (stomach) symptoms, asthma, and, at worst, allergic shock. Additionally, adult-onset asthma has been linked with periocular xanthogranulomas.   "
589b7ed5-ff30-4c28-978b-058c400ea8b9@13@exposure@exposure@0@photo,picture,pic,ex,@"Asthma (from the Greek ?????, ásthma, "panting") is the common chronic inflammatory condition of the respiratory tract characterized by variable and recurring symptoms, reversible blocked airflow, and bronchial spasms. Symptoms include wheezing, coughing, chest tightness, and shortness of breath. Asthma is clinically classed according to how often symptoms happen, forced expiration volume in 1 second (FEV1), and peak expiration flow rate. Asthma may also be classed as atopic (extrinsic) or non-atopic (intrinsic).   It is thought to be caused by a combination of genetic and environmental factors. Treating acute symptoms is usually with an inhaled short-acting beta-2 agonist (such as salbutamol). Symptoms can be prevented by avoiding triggers, such as allergens and irritants, and by breathing in corticosteroids. Leukotriene antagonists are less effective than corticosteroids and therefore less preferred.  Its diagnosis is usually made based on the pattern of symptoms and/or response to treatment over time. The prevalence of asthma has increased significantly since the 1970s. As of 2010, 300 million people were impacted worldwide. In 2009 asthma caused 250,000 deaths globally. Despite this, with the right control of asthma with step down treatment, outcome is generally good.  Causes  Asthma is caused by environmental and genetic factors. These factors determine how serious asthma is and how well it responds to medicine. The interaction is complex and not fully understood.  Examining the prevalence of asthma and related conditions such as eczema and hay fever have given important clues about some key risk factors. The strongest risk factor for getting asthma is a history of atopic diseases; this increases one's risk of hay fever by up to 5× and the risk of asthma by 3–4×. In children between the ages of 3–14, a positive skin test for allergies and an increase in immunoglobulin E increases the chance of getting asthma. In adults, the more allergens one reacts positively to in a skin test, the higher the odds of getting asthma.  Because much allergic asthma is linked with sensitivity to indoor allergens and because Western styles of housing favor greater exposure to indoor allergens, much attention has centered on increased exposure to these allergens in infancy and early childhood as a main cause of the rise in asthma. Primary prevention studies aimed at the aggressive reduction of airborne allergens in a home with infants have shown mixed findings. Strict reduction of dust mite allergens, for example, cuts down the risk of allergic sensitization to dust mites, and modestly cuts down the risk of getting asthma up until the age of 8 years old. However, studies also showed that the effects of exposure to cat and dog allergens worked in the converse way; exposure during the first year of life was found to cut down the risk of allergic sensitization and of getting asthma later in life.  The inconsistency of this information has inspired research into other aspects of Western society and their impact upon the prevalence of asthma. One subject that seems to show a strong correlation is the development of asthma and obesity. In the United Kingdom and United States, the increase in asthma prevalence has echoed an almost epidemic increase in the prevalence of obesity. In Taiwan, symptoms of allergies and airway hyper-reactivity increased in correlation with each 20% increase in body-mass index. Many factors linked with obesity may play a part in the pathogenesis of asthma, including reduced respiratory function due to a buildup of adipose tissue (fat) and the fact that adipose tissue leads to a pro-inflammatory state, which has been linked with non-eosinophilic asthma.  Asthma has been linked with Churg–Strauss syndrome, and someone with immunologically mediated urticaria (hives) may also have systemic symptoms with generalized urticaria (hives), rhino-conjunctivitis, orolaryngeal and gastrointestinal (stomach) symptoms, asthma, and, at worst, allergic shock. Additionally, adult-onset asthma has been linked with periocular xanthogranulomas.   "

Symptoms include wheezing, coughing, chest tightness, and shortness of breath. Asthma is clinically classed according to how often symptoms happen, forced expiration volume in 1 second (FEV1), and peak expiration flow rate. Asthma may also be classed as atopic (extrinsic) or non-atopic (intrinsic).   It is thought to be caused by a combination of genetic and environmental factors. Treating acute symptoms is usually with an inhaled short-acting beta-2 agonist (such as salbutamol). Symptoms can be prevented by avoiding triggers, such as allergens and irritants, and by breathing in corticosteroids. Leukotriene antagonists are less effective than corticosteroids and therefore less preferred.  Its diagnosis is usually made based on the pattern of symptoms and/or response to treatment over time. The prevalence of asthma has increased significantly since the 1970s. As of 2010, 300 million people were impacted worldwide. In 2009 asthma caused 250,000 deaths globally. Despite this, with the right control of asthma with step down treatment, outcome is generally good.  Causes  Asthma is caused by environmental and genetic factors. These factors determine how serious asthma is and how well it responds to medicine. The interaction is complex and not fully understood. In children between the ages of 3–14, a positive skin test for allergies and an increase in immunoglobulin E increases the chance of getting asthma. In adults, the more allergens one reacts positively to in a skin test, the higher the odds of getting asthma.  Because much allergic asthma is linked with sensitivity to indoor allergens and because Western styles of housing favor greater exposure to indoor allergens, much attention has centered on increased exposure to these allergens in infancy and early childhood as a main cause of the rise in asthma. Primary prevention studies aimed at the aggressive reduction of airborne allergens in a home with infants have shown mixed findings. Strict reduction of dust mite allergens, for example, cuts down the risk of allergic sensitization to dust mites, and modestly cuts down the risk of getting asthma up until the age of 8 years old. However, studies also showed that the effects of exposure to cat and dog allergens worked in the converse way; exposure during the first year of life was found to cut down the risk of allergic sensitization and of getting asthma later in life. In Taiwan, symptoms of allergies and airway hyper-reactivity increased in correlation with each 20% increase in body-mass index. Asthma has been linked with Churg–Strauss syndrome, and someone with immunologically mediated urticaria (hives) may also have systemic symptoms with generalized urticaria (hives), rhino-conjunctivitis, orolaryngeal and gastrointestinal (stomach) symptoms, asthma, and, at worst, allergic shock. Additionally, adult-onset asthma has been linked with periocular xanthogranulomas.   "

Many factors linked with obesity may play a part in the pathogenesis of asthma, including reduced respiratory function due to a buildup of adipose tissue (fat) and the fact that adipose tissue leads to a pro-inflammatory state, which has been linked with non-eosinophilic asthma.  Asthma has been linked with Churg–Strauss syndrome, and someone with immunologically mediated urticaria (hives) may also have systemic symptoms with generalized urticaria (hives), rhino-conjunctivitis, orolaryngeal and gastrointestinal (stomach) symptoms, asthma, and, at worst, allergic shock. Additionally, adult-onset asthma has been linked with periocular xanthogranulomas.   "
589b7ed5-ff30-4c28-978b-058c400ea8b9@13@infants@infants@0@baby,babe,@"Asthma (from the Greek ?????, ásthma, "panting") is the common chronic inflammatory condition of the respiratory tract characterized by variable and recurring symptoms, reversible blocked airflow, and bronchial spasms. Symptoms include wheezing, coughing, chest tightness, and shortness of breath. Asthma is clinically classed according to how often symptoms happen, forced expiration volume in 1 second (FEV1), and peak expiration flow rate. Asthma may also be classed as atopic (extrinsic) or non-atopic (intrinsic).   It is thought to be caused by a combination of genetic and environmental factors. Treating acute symptoms is usually with an inhaled short-acting beta-2 agonist (such as salbutamol). Symptoms can be prevented by avoiding triggers, such as allergens and irritants, and by breathing in corticosteroids. Leukotriene antagonists are less effective than corticosteroids and therefore less preferred.  Its diagnosis is usually made based on the pattern of symptoms and/or response to treatment over time. The prevalence of asthma has increased significantly since the 1970s. As of 2010, 300 million people were impacted worldwide. In 2009 asthma caused 250,000 deaths globally. Despite this, with the right control of asthma with step down treatment, outcome is generally good.  Causes  Asthma is caused by environmental and genetic factors. These factors determine how serious asthma is and how well it responds to medicine. The interaction is complex and not fully understood.  Examining the prevalence of asthma and related conditions such as eczema and hay fever have given important clues about some key risk factors. The strongest risk factor for getting asthma is a history of atopic diseases; this increases one's risk of hay fever by up to 5× and the risk of asthma by 3–4×. In children between the ages of 3–14, a positive skin test for allergies and an increase in immunoglobulin E increases the chance of getting asthma. In adults, the more allergens one reacts positively to in a skin test, the higher the odds of getting asthma.  Because much allergic asthma is linked with sensitivity to indoor allergens and because Western styles of housing favor greater exposure to indoor allergens, much attention has centered on increased exposure to these allergens in infancy and early childhood as a main cause of the rise in asthma. Primary prevention studies aimed at the aggressive reduction of airborne allergens in a home with infants have shown mixed findings. Strict reduction of dust mite allergens, for example, cuts down the risk of allergic sensitization to dust mites, and modestly cuts down the risk of getting asthma up until the age of 8 years old. However, studies also showed that the effects of exposure to cat and dog allergens worked in the converse way; exposure during the first year of life was found to cut down the risk of allergic sensitization and of getting asthma later in life.  The inconsistency of this information has inspired research into other aspects of Western society and their impact upon the prevalence of asthma. One subject that seems to show a strong correlation is the development of asthma and obesity. In the United Kingdom and United States, the increase in asthma prevalence has echoed an almost epidemic increase in the prevalence of obesity. In Taiwan, symptoms of allergies and airway hyper-reactivity increased in correlation with each 20% increase in body-mass index. Many factors linked with obesity may play a part in the pathogenesis of asthma, including reduced respiratory function due to a buildup of adipose tissue (fat) and the fact that adipose tissue leads to a pro-inflammatory state, which has been linked with non-eosinophilic asthma.  Asthma has been linked with Churg–Strauss syndrome, and someone with immunologically mediated urticaria (hives) may also have systemic symptoms with generalized urticaria (hives), rhino-conjunctivitis, orolaryngeal and gastrointestinal (stomach) symptoms, asthma, and, at worst, allergic shock. Additionally, adult-onset asthma has been linked with periocular xanthogranulomas.   "

Because much allergic asthma is linked with sensitivity to indoor allergens and because Western styles of housing favor greater exposure to indoor allergens, much attention has centered on increased exposure to these allergens in infancy and early childhood as a main cause of the rise in asthma. Primary prevention studies aimed at the aggressive reduction of airborne allergens in a home with infants have shown mixed findings. Strict reduction of dust mite allergens, for example, cuts down the risk of allergic sensitization to dust mites, and modestly cuts down the risk of getting asthma up until the age of 8 years old. However, studies also showed that the effects of exposure to cat and dog allergens worked in the converse way; exposure during the first year of life was found to cut down the risk of allergic sensitization and of getting asthma later in life.  The inconsistency of this information has inspired research into other aspects of Western society and their impact upon the prevalence of asthma. One subject that seems to show a strong correlation is the development of asthma and obesity. In the United Kingdom and United States, the increase in asthma prevalence has echoed an almost epidemic increase in the prevalence of obesity. In Taiwan, symptoms of allergies and airway hyper-reactivity increased in correlation with each 20% increase in body-mass index. Many factors linked with obesity may play a part in the pathogenesis of asthma, including reduced respiratory function due to a buildup of adipose tissue (fat) and the fact that adipose tissue leads to a pro-inflammatory state, which has been linked with non-eosinophilic asthma.  Asthma has been linked with Churg–Strauss syndrome, and someone with immunologically mediated urticaria (hives) may also have systemic symptoms with generalized urticaria (hives), rhino-conjunctivitis, orolaryngeal and gastrointestinal (stomach) symptoms, asthma, and, at worst, allergic shock. Additionally, adult-onset asthma has been linked with periocular xanthogranulomas.   "
589b7ed5-ff30-4c28-978b-058c400ea8b9@13@inspired@inspired@0@root on,@"Asthma (from the Greek ?????, ásthma, "panting") is the common chronic inflammatory condition of the respiratory tract characterized by variable and recurring symptoms, reversible blocked airflow, and bronchial spasms. Symptoms include wheezing, coughing, chest tightness, and shortness of breath. Asthma is clinically classed according to how often symptoms happen, forced expiration volume in 1 second (FEV1), and peak expiration flow rate. Asthma may also be classed as atopic (extrinsic) or non-atopic (intrinsic).   It is thought to be caused by a combination of genetic and environmental factors. Treating acute symptoms is usually with an inhaled short-acting beta-2 agonist (such as salbutamol). Symptoms can be prevented by avoiding triggers, such as allergens and irritants, and by breathing in corticosteroids. Leukotriene antagonists are less effective than corticosteroids and therefore less preferred.  Its diagnosis is usually made based on the pattern of symptoms and/or response to treatment over time. The prevalence of asthma has increased significantly since the 1970s. As of 2010, 300 million people were impacted worldwide. In 2009 asthma caused 250,000 deaths globally. Despite this, with the right control of asthma with step down treatment, outcome is generally good.  Causes  Asthma is caused by environmental and genetic factors. These factors determine how serious asthma is and how well it responds to medicine. The interaction is complex and not fully understood.  Examining the prevalence of asthma and related conditions such as eczema and hay fever have given important clues about some key risk factors. The strongest risk factor for getting asthma is a history of atopic diseases; this increases one's risk of hay fever by up to 5× and the risk of asthma by 3–4×. In children between the ages of 3–14, a positive skin test for allergies and an increase in immunoglobulin E increases the chance of getting asthma. In adults, the more allergens one reacts positively to in a skin test, the higher the odds of getting asthma.  Because much allergic asthma is linked with sensitivity to indoor allergens and because Western styles of housing favor greater exposure to indoor allergens, much attention has centered on increased exposure to these allergens in infancy and early childhood as a main cause of the rise in asthma. Primary prevention studies aimed at the aggressive reduction of airborne allergens in a home with infants have shown mixed findings. Strict reduction of dust mite allergens, for example, cuts down the risk of allergic sensitization to dust mites, and modestly cuts down the risk of getting asthma up until the age of 8 years old. However, studies also showed that the effects of exposure to cat and dog allergens worked in the converse way; exposure during the first year of life was found to cut down the risk of allergic sensitization and of getting asthma later in life.  The inconsistency of this information has inspired research into other aspects of Western society and their impact upon the prevalence of asthma. One subject that seems to show a strong correlation is the development of asthma and obesity. In the United Kingdom and United States, the increase in asthma prevalence has echoed an almost epidemic increase in the prevalence of obesity. In Taiwan, symptoms of allergies and airway hyper-reactivity increased in correlation with each 20% increase in body-mass index. Many factors linked with obesity may play a part in the pathogenesis of asthma, including reduced respiratory function due to a buildup of adipose tissue (fat) and the fact that adipose tissue leads to a pro-inflammatory state, which has been linked with non-eosinophilic asthma.  Asthma has been linked with Churg–Strauss syndrome, and someone with immunologically mediated urticaria (hives) may also have systemic symptoms with generalized urticaria (hives), rhino-conjunctivitis, orolaryngeal and gastrointestinal (stomach) symptoms, asthma, and, at worst, allergic shock. Additionally, adult-onset asthma has been linked with periocular xanthogranulomas.   "

Symptoms include wheezing, coughing, chest tightness, and shortness of breath. Asthma is clinically classed according to how often symptoms happen, forced expiration volume in 1 second (FEV1), and peak expiration flow rate. Asthma may also be classed as atopic (extrinsic) or non-atopic (intrinsic).   It is thought to be caused by a combination of genetic and environmental factors. Symptoms can be prevented by avoiding triggers, such as allergens and irritants, and by breathing in corticosteroids. Leukotriene antagonists are less effective than corticosteroids and therefore less preferred.  Its diagnosis is usually made based on the pattern of symptoms and/or response to treatment over time. The prevalence of asthma has increased significantly since the 1970s. As of 2010, 300 million people were impacted worldwide. In 2009 asthma caused 250,000 deaths globally. Despite this, with the right control of asthma with step down treatment, outcome is generally good.  Causes  Asthma is caused by environmental and genetic factors. Symptoms include wheezing, coughing, chest tightness, and shortness of breath. Asthma is clinically classed according to how often symptoms happen, forced expiration volume in 1 second (FEV1), and peak expiration flow rate. Asthma may also be classed as atopic (extrinsic) or non-atopic (intrinsic).   It is thought to be caused by a combination of genetic and environmental factors. Treating acute symptoms is usually with an inhaled short-acting beta-2 agonist (such as salbutamol). Symptoms can be prevented by avoiding triggers, such as allergens and irritants, and by breathing in corticosteroids. Leukotriene antagonists are less effective than corticosteroids and therefore less preferred.  Its diagnosis is usually made based on the pattern of symptoms and/or response to treatment over time. The prevalence of asthma has increased significantly since the 1970s. As of 2010, 300 million people were impacted worldwide. In 2009 asthma caused 250,000 deaths globally. Despite this, with the right control of asthma with step down treatment, outcome is generally good.  Causes  Asthma is caused by environmental and genetic factors. These factors determine how serious asthma is and how well it responds to medicine. The interaction is complex and not fully understood. In Taiwan, symptoms of allergies and airway hyper-reactivity increased in correlation with each 20% increase in body-mass index. Symptoms can be prevented by avoiding triggers, such as allergens and irritants, and by breathing in corticosteroids. Leukotriene antagonists are less effective than corticosteroids and therefore less preferred.  Its diagnosis is usually made based on the pattern of symptoms and/or response to treatment over time. The prevalence of asthma has increased significantly since the 1970s. As of 2010, 300 million people were impacted worldwide. In 2009 asthma caused 250,000 deaths globally. Despite this, with the right control of asthma with step down treatment, outcome is generally good.  Causes  Asthma is caused by environmental and genetic factors. These factors determine how serious asthma is and how well it responds to medicine. The interaction is complex and not fully understood.  Examining the prevalence of asthma and related conditions such as eczema and hay fever have given important clues about some key risk factors. The strongest risk factor for getting asthma is a history of atopic diseases; this increases one's risk of hay fever by up to 5× and the risk of asthma by 3–4×. In children between the ages of 3–14, a positive skin test for allergies and an increase in immunoglobulin E increases the chance of getting asthma. In adults, the more allergens one reacts positively to in a skin test, the higher the odds of getting asthma.  Because much allergic asthma is linked with sensitivity to indoor allergens and because Western styles of housing favor greater exposure to indoor allergens, much attention has centered on increased exposure to these allergens in infancy and early childhood as a main cause of the rise in asthma. Primary prevention studies aimed at the aggressive reduction of airborne allergens in a home with infants have shown mixed findings. Strict reduction of dust mite allergens, for example, cuts down the risk of allergic sensitization to dust mites, and modestly cuts down the risk of getting asthma up until the age of 8 years old. However, studies also showed that the effects of exposure to cat and dog allergens worked in the converse way; exposure during the first year of life was found to cut down the risk of allergic sensitization and of getting asthma later in life.  The inconsistency of this information has inspired research into other aspects of Western society and their impact upon the prevalence of asthma. One subject that seems to show a strong correlation is the development of asthma and obesity. In the United Kingdom and United States, the increase in asthma prevalence has echoed an almost epidemic increase in the prevalence of obesity. In Taiwan, symptoms of allergies and airway hyper-reactivity increased in correlation with each 20% increase in body-mass index. Many factors linked with obesity may play a part in the pathogenesis of asthma, including reduced respiratory function due to a buildup of adipose tissue (fat) and the fact that adipose tissue leads to a pro-inflammatory state, which has been linked with non-eosinophilic asthma.  Asthma has been linked with Churg–Strauss syndrome, and someone with immunologically mediated urticaria (hives) may also have systemic symptoms with generalized urticaria (hives), rhino-conjunctivitis, orolaryngeal and gastrointestinal (stomach) symptoms, asthma, and, at worst, allergic shock. Additionally, adult-onset asthma has been linked with periocular xanthogranulomas.   "
589b7ed5-ff30-4c28-978b-058c400ea8b9@13@subject@subject@0@national,@"Asthma (from the Greek ?????, ásthma, "panting") is the common chronic inflammatory condition of the respiratory tract characterized by variable and recurring symptoms, reversible blocked airflow, and bronchial spasms. Symptoms include wheezing, coughing, chest tightness, and shortness of breath. Asthma is clinically classed according to how often symptoms happen, forced expiration volume in 1 second (FEV1), and peak expiration flow rate. Asthma may also be classed as atopic (extrinsic) or non-atopic (intrinsic).   It is thought to be caused by a combination of genetic and environmental factors. Treating acute symptoms is usually with an inhaled short-acting beta-2 agonist (such as salbutamol). Symptoms can be prevented by avoiding triggers, such as allergens and irritants, and by breathing in corticosteroids. Leukotriene antagonists are less effective than corticosteroids and therefore less preferred.  Its diagnosis is usually made based on the pattern of symptoms and/or response to treatment over time. The prevalence of asthma has increased significantly since the 1970s. As of 2010, 300 million people were impacted worldwide. In 2009 asthma caused 250,000 deaths globally. Despite this, with the right control of asthma with step down treatment, outcome is generally good.  Causes  Asthma is caused by environmental and genetic factors. These factors determine how serious asthma is and how well it responds to medicine. The interaction is complex and not fully understood.  Examining the prevalence of asthma and related conditions such as eczema and hay fever have given important clues about some key risk factors. The strongest risk factor for getting asthma is a history of atopic diseases; this increases one's risk of hay fever by up to 5× and the risk of asthma by 3–4×. In children between the ages of 3–14, a positive skin test for allergies and an increase in immunoglobulin E increases the chance of getting asthma. In adults, the more allergens one reacts positively to in a skin test, the higher the odds of getting asthma.  Because much allergic asthma is linked with sensitivity to indoor allergens and because Western styles of housing favor greater exposure to indoor allergens, much attention has centered on increased exposure to these allergens in infancy and early childhood as a main cause of the rise in asthma. Primary prevention studies aimed at the aggressive reduction of airborne allergens in a home with infants have shown mixed findings. Strict reduction of dust mite allergens, for example, cuts down the risk of allergic sensitization to dust mites, and modestly cuts down the risk of getting asthma up until the age of 8 years old. However, studies also showed that the effects of exposure to cat and dog allergens worked in the converse way; exposure during the first year of life was found to cut down the risk of allergic sensitization and of getting asthma later in life.  The inconsistency of this information has inspired research into other aspects of Western society and their impact upon the prevalence of asthma. One subject that seems to show a strong correlation is the development of asthma and obesity. In the United Kingdom and United States, the increase in asthma prevalence has echoed an almost epidemic increase in the prevalence of obesity. In Taiwan, symptoms of allergies and airway hyper-reactivity increased in correlation with each 20% increase in body-mass index. Many factors linked with obesity may play a part in the pathogenesis of asthma, including reduced respiratory function due to a buildup of adipose tissue (fat) and the fact that adipose tissue leads to a pro-inflammatory state, which has been linked with non-eosinophilic asthma.  Asthma has been linked with Churg–Strauss syndrome, and someone with immunologically mediated urticaria (hives) may also have systemic symptoms with generalized urticaria (hives), rhino-conjunctivitis, orolaryngeal and gastrointestinal (stomach) symptoms, asthma, and, at worst, allergic shock. Additionally, adult-onset asthma has been linked with periocular xanthogranulomas.   "

Symptoms include wheezing, coughing, chest tightness, and shortness of breath. Asthma has been linked with Churg–Strauss syndrome, and someone with immunologically mediated urticaria (hives) may also have systemic symptoms with generalized urticaria (hives), rhino-conjunctivitis, orolaryngeal and gastrointestinal (stomach) symptoms, asthma, and, at worst, allergic shock. Additionally, adult-onset asthma has been linked with periocular xanthogranulomas.   "
589b7ed5-ff30-4c28-978b-058c400ea8b9@13@almost@almost@0@about,most,near,@"Asthma (from the Greek ?????, ásthma, "panting") is the common chronic inflammatory condition of the respiratory tract characterized by variable and recurring symptoms, reversible blocked airflow, and bronchial spasms. Symptoms include wheezing, coughing, chest tightness, and shortness of breath. Asthma is clinically classed according to how often symptoms happen, forced expiration volume in 1 second (FEV1), and peak expiration flow rate. Asthma may also be classed as atopic (extrinsic) or non-atopic (intrinsic).   It is thought to be caused by a combination of genetic and environmental factors. Treating acute symptoms is usually with an inhaled short-acting beta-2 agonist (such as salbutamol). Symptoms can be prevented by avoiding triggers, such as allergens and irritants, and by breathing in corticosteroids. Leukotriene antagonists are less effective than corticosteroids and therefore less preferred.  Its diagnosis is usually made based on the pattern of symptoms and/or response to treatment over time. The prevalence of asthma has increased significantly since the 1970s. As of 2010, 300 million people were impacted worldwide. In 2009 asthma caused 250,000 deaths globally. Despite this, with the right control of asthma with step down treatment, outcome is generally good.  Causes  Asthma is caused by environmental and genetic factors. These factors determine how serious asthma is and how well it responds to medicine. The interaction is complex and not fully understood.  Examining the prevalence of asthma and related conditions such as eczema and hay fever have given important clues about some key risk factors. The strongest risk factor for getting asthma is a history of atopic diseases; this increases one's risk of hay fever by up to 5× and the risk of asthma by 3–4×. In children between the ages of 3–14, a positive skin test for allergies and an increase in immunoglobulin E increases the chance of getting asthma. In adults, the more allergens one reacts positively to in a skin test, the higher the odds of getting asthma.  Because much allergic asthma is linked with sensitivity to indoor allergens and because Western styles of housing favor greater exposure to indoor allergens, much attention has centered on increased exposure to these allergens in infancy and early childhood as a main cause of the rise in asthma. Primary prevention studies aimed at the aggressive reduction of airborne allergens in a home with infants have shown mixed findings. Strict reduction of dust mite allergens, for example, cuts down the risk of allergic sensitization to dust mites, and modestly cuts down the risk of getting asthma up until the age of 8 years old. However, studies also showed that the effects of exposure to cat and dog allergens worked in the converse way; exposure during the first year of life was found to cut down the risk of allergic sensitization and of getting asthma later in life.  The inconsistency of this information has inspired research into other aspects of Western society and their impact upon the prevalence of asthma. One subject that seems to show a strong correlation is the development of asthma and obesity. In the United Kingdom and United States, the increase in asthma prevalence has echoed an almost epidemic increase in the prevalence of obesity. In Taiwan, symptoms of allergies and airway hyper-reactivity increased in correlation with each 20% increase in body-mass index. Many factors linked with obesity may play a part in the pathogenesis of asthma, including reduced respiratory function due to a buildup of adipose tissue (fat) and the fact that adipose tissue leads to a pro-inflammatory state, which has been linked with non-eosinophilic asthma.  Asthma has been linked with Churg–Strauss syndrome, and someone with immunologically mediated urticaria (hives) may also have systemic symptoms with generalized urticaria (hives), rhino-conjunctivitis, orolaryngeal and gastrointestinal (stomach) symptoms, asthma, and, at worst, allergic shock. Additionally, adult-onset asthma has been linked with periocular xanthogranulomas.   "

Because much allergic asthma is linked with sensitivity to indoor allergens and because Western styles of housing favor greater exposure to indoor allergens, much attention has centered on increased exposure to these allergens in infancy and early childhood as a main cause of the rise in asthma. Primary prevention studies aimed at the aggressive reduction of airborne allergens in a home with infants have shown mixed findings. Strict reduction of dust mite allergens, for example, cuts down the risk of allergic sensitization to dust mites, and modestly cuts down the risk of getting asthma up until the age of 8 years old. However, studies also showed that the effects of exposure to cat and dog allergens worked in the converse way; exposure during the first year of life was found to cut down the risk of allergic sensitization and of getting asthma later in life.  The inconsistency of this information has inspired research into other aspects of Western society and their impact upon the prevalence of asthma. One subject that seems to show a strong correlation is the development of asthma and obesity. In the United Kingdom and United States, the increase in asthma prevalence has echoed an almost epidemic increase in the prevalence of obesity. In Taiwan, symptoms of allergies and airway hyper-reactivity increased in correlation with each 20% increase in body-mass index. Many factors linked with obesity may play a part in the pathogenesis of asthma, including reduced respiratory function due to a buildup of adipose tissue (fat) and the fact that adipose tissue leads to a pro-inflammatory state, which has been linked with non-eosinophilic asthma.  Asthma has been linked with Churg–Strauss syndrome, and someone with immunologically mediated urticaria (hives) may also have systemic symptoms with generalized urticaria (hives), rhino-conjunctivitis, orolaryngeal and gastrointestinal (stomach) symptoms, asthma, and, at worst, allergic shock. Additionally, adult-onset asthma has been linked with periocular xanthogranulomas.   "
589b7ed5-ff30-4c28-978b-058c400ea8b9@13@pathogenesis@pathogenesis@0@[patho] [genesis] :	[disease] [generation],@"Asthma (from the Greek ?????, ásthma, "panting") is the common chronic inflammatory condition of the respiratory tract characterized by variable and recurring symptoms, reversible blocked airflow, and bronchial spasms. Symptoms include wheezing, coughing, chest tightness, and shortness of breath. Asthma is clinically classed according to how often symptoms happen, forced expiration volume in 1 second (FEV1), and peak expiration flow rate. Asthma may also be classed as atopic (extrinsic) or non-atopic (intrinsic).   It is thought to be caused by a combination of genetic and environmental factors. Treating acute symptoms is usually with an inhaled short-acting beta-2 agonist (such as salbutamol). Symptoms can be prevented by avoiding triggers, such as allergens and irritants, and by breathing in corticosteroids. Leukotriene antagonists are less effective than corticosteroids and therefore less preferred.  Its diagnosis is usually made based on the pattern of symptoms and/or response to treatment over time. The prevalence of asthma has increased significantly since the 1970s. As of 2010, 300 million people were impacted worldwide. In 2009 asthma caused 250,000 deaths globally. Despite this, with the right control of asthma with step down treatment, outcome is generally good.  Causes  Asthma is caused by environmental and genetic factors. These factors determine how serious asthma is and how well it responds to medicine. The interaction is complex and not fully understood.  Examining the prevalence of asthma and related conditions such as eczema and hay fever have given important clues about some key risk factors. The strongest risk factor for getting asthma is a history of atopic diseases; this increases one's risk of hay fever by up to 5× and the risk of asthma by 3–4×. In children between the ages of 3–14, a positive skin test for allergies and an increase in immunoglobulin E increases the chance of getting asthma. In adults, the more allergens one reacts positively to in a skin test, the higher the odds of getting asthma.  Because much allergic asthma is linked with sensitivity to indoor allergens and because Western styles of housing favor greater exposure to indoor allergens, much attention has centered on increased exposure to these allergens in infancy and early childhood as a main cause of the rise in asthma. Primary prevention studies aimed at the aggressive reduction of airborne allergens in a home with infants have shown mixed findings. Strict reduction of dust mite allergens, for example, cuts down the risk of allergic sensitization to dust mites, and modestly cuts down the risk of getting asthma up until the age of 8 years old. However, studies also showed that the effects of exposure to cat and dog allergens worked in the converse way; exposure during the first year of life was found to cut down the risk of allergic sensitization and of getting asthma later in life.  The inconsistency of this information has inspired research into other aspects of Western society and their impact upon the prevalence of asthma. One subject that seems to show a strong correlation is the development of asthma and obesity. In the United Kingdom and United States, the increase in asthma prevalence has echoed an almost epidemic increase in the prevalence of obesity. In Taiwan, symptoms of allergies and airway hyper-reactivity increased in correlation with each 20% increase in body-mass index. Many factors linked with obesity may play a part in the pathogenesis of asthma, including reduced respiratory function due to a buildup of adipose tissue (fat) and the fact that adipose tissue leads to a pro-inflammatory state, which has been linked with non-eosinophilic asthma.  Asthma has been linked with Churg–Strauss syndrome, and someone with immunologically mediated urticaria (hives) may also have systemic symptoms with generalized urticaria (hives), rhino-conjunctivitis, orolaryngeal and gastrointestinal (stomach) symptoms, asthma, and, at worst, allergic shock. Additionally, adult-onset asthma has been linked with periocular xanthogranulomas.   "

Treating acute symptoms is usually with an inhaled short-acting beta-2 agonist (such as salbutamol). Symptoms can be prevented by avoiding triggers, such as allergens and irritants, and by breathing in corticosteroids. Leukotriene antagonists are less effective than corticosteroids and therefore less preferred.  Its diagnosis is usually made based on the pattern of symptoms and/or response to treatment over time. The prevalence of asthma has increased significantly since the 1970s. As of 2010, 300 million people were impacted worldwide. In 2009 asthma caused 250,000 deaths globally. Despite this, with the right control of asthma with step down treatment, outcome is generally good.  Causes  Asthma is caused by environmental and genetic factors. These factors determine how serious asthma is and how well it responds to medicine. The interaction is complex and not fully understood.  Examining the prevalence of asthma and related conditions such as eczema and hay fever have given important clues about some key risk factors. The strongest risk factor for getting asthma is a history of atopic diseases; this increases one's risk of hay fever by up to 5× and the risk of asthma by 3–4×. In children between the ages of 3–14, a positive skin test for allergies and an increase in immunoglobulin E increases the chance of getting asthma. In adults, the more allergens one reacts positively to in a skin test, the higher the odds of getting asthma.  Because much allergic asthma is linked with sensitivity to indoor allergens and because Western styles of housing favor greater exposure to indoor allergens, much attention has centered on increased exposure to these allergens in infancy and early childhood as a main cause of the rise in asthma. Primary prevention studies aimed at the aggressive reduction of airborne allergens in a home with infants have shown mixed findings. Strict reduction of dust mite allergens, for example, cuts down the risk of allergic sensitization to dust mites, and modestly cuts down the risk of getting asthma up until the age of 8 years old. However, studies also showed that the effects of exposure to cat and dog allergens worked in the converse way; exposure during the first year of life was found to cut down the risk of allergic sensitization and of getting asthma later in life.  The inconsistency of this information has inspired research into other aspects of Western society and their impact upon the prevalence of asthma. One subject that seems to show a strong correlation is the development of asthma and obesity. In the United Kingdom and United States, the increase in asthma prevalence has echoed an almost epidemic increase in the prevalence of obesity. In Taiwan, symptoms of allergies and airway hyper-reactivity increased in correlation with each 20% increase in body-mass index. Many factors linked with obesity may play a part in the pathogenesis of asthma, including reduced respiratory function due to a buildup of adipose tissue (fat) and the fact that adipose tissue leads to a pro-inflammatory state, which has been linked with non-eosinophilic asthma.  Asthma has been linked with Churg–Strauss syndrome, and someone with immunologically mediated urticaria (hives) may also have systemic symptoms with generalized urticaria (hives), rhino-conjunctivitis, orolaryngeal and gastrointestinal (stomach) symptoms, asthma, and, at worst, allergic shock. Additionally, adult-onset asthma has been linked with periocular xanthogranulomas.   "
589b7ed5-ff30-4c28-978b-058c400ea8b9@13@inflammatory@inflammatory@0@[inflammator] [y] :	[inflammator] [condition or process of],@"Asthma (from the Greek ?????, ásthma, "panting") is the common chronic inflammatory condition of the respiratory tract characterized by variable and recurring symptoms, reversible blocked airflow, and bronchial spasms. Symptoms include wheezing, coughing, chest tightness, and shortness of breath. Asthma is clinically classed according to how often symptoms happen, forced expiration volume in 1 second (FEV1), and peak expiration flow rate. Asthma may also be classed as atopic (extrinsic) or non-atopic (intrinsic).   It is thought to be caused by a combination of genetic and environmental factors. Treating acute symptoms is usually with an inhaled short-acting beta-2 agonist (such as salbutamol). Symptoms can be prevented by avoiding triggers, such as allergens and irritants, and by breathing in corticosteroids. Leukotriene antagonists are less effective than corticosteroids and therefore less preferred.  Its diagnosis is usually made based on the pattern of symptoms and/or response to treatment over time. Despite this, with the right control of asthma with step down treatment, outcome is generally good.  Causes  Asthma is caused by environmental and genetic factors.
