589b7ed5-ff30-4c28-978b-058c400ea8b9@15@retaining@hold@1@continue,keep,keep on,hold,keep back,hold back,@"Cirrhosis is an outcome of chronic liver disease characterized by replacement of liver tissue by fibrosis, scar tissue and regenerative nodules (lumps that happen as a result of a process in which damaged tissue is reformed), resulting in loss of liver function. Cirrhosis is usually caused by alcohol addiction, hepatitis B and C, and fatty liver disease, but has many other possible causes. Some cases are idiopathic (i.e., cause is not known).  Ascites (retaining fluid in the abdominal cavity) is the most common complication of cirrhosis, and is linked with a poor quality of life, increased risk of infection, and a poor long-term result. Other potentially life-threatening complications are hepatic encephalopathy (confusion and coma) and bleeding from esophageal varices. Cirrhosis is generally irreversible, and treatment usually focuses on preventing progression and complications. In advanced stages of cirrhosis the only choice is a liver transplant.  The word "cirrhosis" comes from Greek ?????? [kirrhós] meaning yellow, tawny (the orange-yellow color of the diseased liver) + Eng. med. suff. -osis. While the clinical entity was known before, it was René Laennec who gave it the name "cirrhosis" in his 1819 work in which he also describes the stethoscope.  Pathophysiology  The liver plays a critical role in forming proteins (e.g., albumin, clotting factors and complement), detoxifing and storing (e.g., vitamin A). In addition, it participates in the metabolism of lipids and carbohydrates.  Cirrhosis is often preceded by hepatitis and fatty liver (steatosis), independent of the cause. If the cause is taken away at this stage, the changes are still fully reversible.  The pathological hallmark of cirrhosis is the development of scar tissue that replaces normal parenchyma, stoping the portal flow of blood through the organ and disturbing normal function. Recent research shows the pivotal role of the stellate cell, a cell type that usually stores vitamin A, in the development of cirrhosis. Damage to the hepatic parenchyma leads to activation of the stellate cell, which becomes contractile (called myofibroblast) and blocks blood flow in the circulation. In addition, it releases TGF-?1, which results in a fibrotic response and proliferation of connective tissue. Furthermore, it releases TIMP 1 and 2, naturally occurring inhibitors of matrix metalloproteinases, which prevents them from breaking down fibrotic material in the extracellular matrix.  The fibrous tissue bands (septa) separate liver cell nodules, which eventually replace the whole liver architecture, leading to reduced blood flow throughout. The spleen becomes congested, which leads to hypersplenism and increased sequestration of platelets. Portal high blood pressure is responsible for most serious complications of cirrhosis.  Diagnosis  The gold standard for diagnosing cirrhosis is a liver biopsy, through a percutaneous, transjugular, laparoscopic, or fine-needle approach. A biopsy is not necessary if the clinical, laboratory, and radiologic data indicate cirrhosis. Furthermore, there is a small but important risk to liver biopsy, and cirrhosis itself predisposes for complications due to liver biopsy. Ascites, low platelet count, and spider nevi are useful physical findings."
589b7ed5-ff30-4c28-978b-058c400ea8b9@15@abdominal@abdominal@0@[abdomin] [al] :	[abdomen] [pertaining to],@"Cirrhosis is an outcome of chronic liver disease characterized by replacement of liver tissue by fibrosis, scar tissue and regenerative nodules (lumps that happen as a result of a process in which damaged tissue is reformed), resulting in loss of liver function. Cirrhosis is usually caused by alcohol addiction, hepatitis B and C, and fatty liver disease, but has many other possible causes. Some cases are idiopathic (i.e., cause is not known).  Ascites (retaining fluid in the abdominal cavity) is the most common complication of cirrhosis, and is linked with a poor quality of life, increased risk of infection, and a poor long-term result. Other potentially life-threatening complications are hepatic encephalopathy (confusion and coma) and bleeding from esophageal varices. Cirrhosis is generally irreversible, and treatment usually focuses on preventing progression and complications. In advanced stages of cirrhosis the only choice is a liver transplant.  The word "cirrhosis" comes from Greek ?????? [kirrhós] meaning yellow, tawny (the orange-yellow color of the diseased liver) + Eng. med. suff. -osis. While the clinical entity was known before, it was René Laennec who gave it the name "cirrhosis" in his 1819 work in which he also describes the stethoscope.  Pathophysiology  The liver plays a critical role in forming proteins (e.g., albumin, clotting factors and complement), detoxifing and storing (e.g., vitamin A). In addition, it participates in the metabolism of lipids and carbohydrates.  Cirrhosis is often preceded by hepatitis and fatty liver (steatosis), independent of the cause. If the cause is taken away at this stage, the changes are still fully reversible.  The pathological hallmark of cirrhosis is the development of scar tissue that replaces normal parenchyma, stoping the portal flow of blood through the organ and disturbing normal function. Recent research shows the pivotal role of the stellate cell, a cell type that usually stores vitamin A, in the development of cirrhosis. Damage to the hepatic parenchyma leads to activation of the stellate cell, which becomes contractile (called myofibroblast) and blocks blood flow in the circulation. In addition, it releases TGF-?1, which results in a fibrotic response and proliferation of connective tissue. Furthermore, it releases TIMP 1 and 2, naturally occurring inhibitors of matrix metalloproteinases, which prevents them from breaking down fibrotic material in the extracellular matrix.  The fibrous tissue bands (septa) separate liver cell nodules, which eventually replace the whole liver architecture, leading to reduced blood flow throughout. The spleen becomes congested, which leads to hypersplenism and increased sequestration of platelets. Portal high blood pressure is responsible for most serious complications of cirrhosis.  Diagnosis  The gold standard for diagnosing cirrhosis is a liver biopsy, through a percutaneous, transjugular, laparoscopic, or fine-needle approach. A biopsy is not necessary if the clinical, laboratory, and radiologic data indicate cirrhosis. Furthermore, there is a small but important risk to liver biopsy, and cirrhosis itself predisposes for complications due to liver biopsy. Ascites, low platelet count, and spider nevi are useful physical findings."
589b7ed5-ff30-4c28-978b-058c400ea8b9@15@cavity@cavity@0@pit,enclosed space,tooth decay,decay dental,decay dent,dent decay,dental decay,decay tooth,@"Cirrhosis is an outcome of chronic liver disease characterized by replacement of liver tissue by fibrosis, scar tissue and regenerative nodules (lumps that happen as a result of a process in which damaged tissue is reformed), resulting in loss of liver function. In addition, it releases TGF-?1, which results in a fibrotic response and proliferation of connective tissue. Furthermore, it releases TIMP 1 and 2, naturally occurring inhibitors of matrix metalloproteinases, which prevents them from breaking down fibrotic material in the extracellular matrix.  The fibrous tissue bands (septa) separate liver cell nodules, which eventually replace the whole liver architecture, leading to reduced blood flow throughout. The spleen becomes congested, which leads to hypersplenism and increased sequestration of platelets. Portal high blood pressure is responsible for most serious complications of cirrhosis.  Diagnosis  The gold standard for diagnosing cirrhosis is a liver biopsy, through a percutaneous, transjugular, laparoscopic, or fine-needle approach. A biopsy is not necessary if the clinical, laboratory, and radiologic data indicate cirrhosis. Furthermore, there is a small but important risk to liver biopsy, and cirrhosis itself predisposes for complications due to liver biopsy. Ascites, low platelet count, and spider nevi are useful physical findings."
589b7ed5-ff30-4c28-978b-058c400ea8b9@15@complication@complication@0@Use verb form: complicate,@"Cirrhosis is an outcome of chronic liver disease characterized by replacement of liver tissue by fibrosis, scar tissue and regenerative nodules (lumps that happen as a result of a process in which damaged tissue is reformed), resulting in loss of liver function. Cirrhosis is usually caused by alcohol addiction, hepatitis B and C, and fatty liver disease, but has many other possible causes. Some cases are idiopathic (i.e., cause is not known).  Ascites (retaining fluid in the abdominal cavity) is the most common complication of cirrhosis, and is linked with a poor quality of life, increased risk of infection, and a poor long-term result. Other potentially life-threatening complications are hepatic encephalopathy (confusion and coma) and bleeding from esophageal varices. Cirrhosis is generally irreversible, and treatment usually focuses on preventing progression and complications. In advanced stages of cirrhosis the only choice is a liver transplant.  The word "cirrhosis" comes from Greek ?????? [kirrhós] meaning yellow, tawny (the orange-yellow color of the diseased liver) + Eng. med. suff. -osis. While the clinical entity was known before, it was René Laennec who gave it the name "cirrhosis" in his 1819 work in which he also describes the stethoscope.  Pathophysiology  The liver plays a critical role in forming proteins (e.g., albumin, clotting factors and complement), detoxifing and storing (e.g., vitamin A). In addition, it participates in the metabolism of lipids and carbohydrates.  Cirrhosis is often preceded by hepatitis and fatty liver (steatosis), independent of the cause. If the cause is taken away at this stage, the changes are still fully reversible.  The pathological hallmark of cirrhosis is the development of scar tissue that replaces normal parenchyma, stoping the portal flow of blood through the organ and disturbing normal function. Recent research shows the pivotal role of the stellate cell, a cell type that usually stores vitamin A, in the development of cirrhosis. Damage to the hepatic parenchyma leads to activation of the stellate cell, which becomes contractile (called myofibroblast) and blocks blood flow in the circulation. In addition, it releases TGF-?1, which results in a fibrotic response and proliferation of connective tissue. Furthermore, it releases TIMP 1 and 2, naturally occurring inhibitors of matrix metalloproteinases, which prevents them from breaking down fibrotic material in the extracellular matrix.  The fibrous tissue bands (septa) separate liver cell nodules, which eventually replace the whole liver architecture, leading to reduced blood flow throughout. The spleen becomes congested, which leads to hypersplenism and increased sequestration of platelets. Portal high blood pressure is responsible for most serious complications of cirrhosis.  Diagnosis  The gold standard for diagnosing cirrhosis is a liver biopsy, through a percutaneous, transjugular, laparoscopic, or fine-needle approach. A biopsy is not necessary if the clinical, laboratory, and radiologic data indicate cirrhosis. Furthermore, there is a small but important risk to liver biopsy, and cirrhosis itself predisposes for complications due to liver biopsy. Ascites, low platelet count, and spider nevi are useful physical findings."

589b7ed5-ff30-4c28-978b-058c400ea8b9@17@consequence@outcome@1@effect,outcome,result,event,issue,import,moment,@"Cirrhosis is a consequence of chronic liver disease characterized by replacement of liver tissue by fibrosis, scar tissue and regenerative nodules (lumps that occur as a result of a process in which damaged tissue is regenerated), leading to loss of liver function. Cirrhosis is most commonly caused by alcoholism, hepatitis B and C, and fatty liver disease, but has many other possible causes. Some cases are idiopathic (i.e., of unknown cause).  Ascites (fluid retention in the abdominal cavity) is the most common complication of cirrhosis, and is associated with a poor quality of life, increased risk of infection, and a poor long-term outcome. Other potentially life-threatening complications are hepatic encephalopathy (confusion and coma) and bleeding from esophageal varices. Cirrhosis is generally irreversible, and treatment usually focuses on preventing progression and complications. In advanced stages of cirrhosis the only option is a liver transplant.  The word "cirrhosis" derives from Greek ?????? [kirrhós] meaning yellowish, tawny (the orange-yellow colour of the diseased liver) + Eng. med. suff. -osis. While the clinical entity was known before, it was René Laennec who gave it the name "cirrhosis" in his 1819 work in which he also describes the stethoscope.  Pathophysiology  The liver plays a vital role in synthesis of proteins (e.g., albumin, clotting factors and complement), detoxification and storage (e.g., vitamin A). In addition, it participates in the metabolism of lipids and carbohydrates.  Cirrhosis is often preceded by hepatitis and fatty liver (steatosis), independent of the cause. If the cause is removed at this stage, the changes are still fully reversible.  The pathological hallmark of cirrhosis is the development of scar tissue that replaces normal parenchyma, blocking the portal flow of blood through the organ and disturbing normal function. Recent research shows the pivotal role of the stellate cell, a cell type that normally stores vitamin A, in the development of cirrhosis. Damage to the hepatic parenchyma leads to activation of the stellate cell, which becomes contractile (called myofibroblast) and obstructs blood flow in the circulation. In addition, it secretes TGF-?1, which leads to a fibrotic response and proliferation of connective tissue. Furthermore, it secretes TIMP 1 and 2, naturally occurring inhibitors of matrix metalloproteinases, which prevents them from breaking down fibrotic material in the extracellular matrix.  The fibrous tissue bands (septa) separate hepatocyte nodules, which eventually replace the entire liver architecture, leading to decreased blood flow throughout. The spleen becomes congested, which leads to hypersplenism and increased sequestration of platelets. Portal hypertension is responsible for most severe complications of cirrhosis.  Diagnosis  The gold standard for diagnosis of cirrhosis is a liver biopsy, through a percutaneous, transjugular, laparoscopic, or fine-needle approach. A biopsy is not necessary if the clinical, laboratory, and radiologic data suggests cirrhosis. Furthermore, there is a small but significant risk to liver biopsy, and cirrhosis itself predisposes for complications due to liver biopsy. Ascites, low platelet count, and spider nevi are useful physical findings."

While the clinical entity was known before, it was René Laennec who gave it the name "cirrhosis" in his 1819 work in which he also describes the stethoscope.  Pathophysiology  The liver plays a vital role in synthesis of proteins (e.g., albumin, clotting factors and complement), detoxification and storage (e.g., vitamin A). In addition, it participates in the metabolism of lipids and carbohydrates.  Cirrhosis is often preceded by hepatitis and fatty liver (steatosis), independent of the cause. If the cause is removed at this stage, the changes are still fully reversible.  The pathological hallmark of cirrhosis is the development of scar tissue that replaces normal parenchyma, blocking the portal flow of blood through the organ and disturbing normal function. Recent research shows the pivotal role of the stellate cell, a cell type that normally stores vitamin A, in the development of cirrhosis. Damage to the hepatic parenchyma leads to activation of the stellate cell, which becomes contractile (called myofibroblast) and obstructs blood flow in the circulation. In addition, it secretes TGF-?1, which leads to a fibrotic response and proliferation of connective tissue. Furthermore, it secretes TIMP 1 and 2, naturally occurring inhibitors of matrix metalloproteinases, which prevents them from breaking down fibrotic material in the extracellular matrix.  The fibrous tissue bands (septa) separate hepatocyte nodules, which eventually replace the entire liver architecture, leading to decreased blood flow throughout. The spleen becomes congested, which leads to hypersplenism and increased sequestration of platelets. Portal hypertension is responsible for most severe complications of cirrhosis.  Diagnosis  The gold standard for diagnosis of cirrhosis is a liver biopsy, through a percutaneous, transjugular, laparoscopic, or fine-needle approach. A biopsy is not necessary if the clinical, laboratory, and radiologic data suggests cirrhosis. Furthermore, there is a small but significant risk to liver biopsy, and cirrhosis itself predisposes for complications due to liver biopsy. Ascites, low platelet count, and spider nevi are useful physical findings."
589b7ed5-ff30-4c28-978b-058c400ea8b9@17@leads@result@1@take,direct,guide,leave,result,head,run,go,pass,top,chair,@"Cirrhosis is a consequence of chronic liver disease characterized by replacement of liver tissue by fibrosis, scar tissue and regenerative nodules (lumps that occur as a result of a process in which damaged tissue is regenerated), leading to loss of liver function. Cirrhosis is most commonly caused by alcoholism, hepatitis B and C, and fatty liver disease, but has many other possible causes. Some cases are idiopathic (i.e., of unknown cause).  Ascites (fluid retention in the abdominal cavity) is the most common complication of cirrhosis, and is associated with a poor quality of life, increased risk of infection, and a poor long-term outcome. Other potentially life-threatening complications are hepatic encephalopathy (confusion and coma) and bleeding from esophageal varices. Cirrhosis is generally irreversible, and treatment usually focuses on preventing progression and complications. In advanced stages of cirrhosis the only option is a liver transplant.  The word "cirrhosis" derives from Greek ?????? [kirrhós] meaning yellowish, tawny (the orange-yellow colour of the diseased liver) + Eng. med. suff. -osis. While the clinical entity was known before, it was René Laennec who gave it the name "cirrhosis" in his 1819 work in which he also describes the stethoscope.  Pathophysiology  The liver plays a vital role in synthesis of proteins (e.g., albumin, clotting factors and complement), detoxification and storage (e.g., vitamin A). In addition, it participates in the metabolism of lipids and carbohydrates.  Cirrhosis is often preceded by hepatitis and fatty liver (steatosis), independent of the cause. If the cause is removed at this stage, the changes are still fully reversible.  The pathological hallmark of cirrhosis is the development of scar tissue that replaces normal parenchyma, blocking the portal flow of blood through the organ and disturbing normal function. Recent research shows the pivotal role of the stellate cell, a cell type that normally stores vitamin A, in the development of cirrhosis. Damage to the hepatic parenchyma leads to activation of the stellate cell, which becomes contractile (called myofibroblast) and obstructs blood flow in the circulation. In addition, it secretes TGF-?1, which leads to a fibrotic response and proliferation of connective tissue. Furthermore, it secretes TIMP 1 and 2, naturally occurring inhibitors of matrix metalloproteinases, which prevents them from breaking down fibrotic material in the extracellular matrix.  The fibrous tissue bands (septa) separate hepatocyte nodules, which eventually replace the entire liver architecture, leading to decreased blood flow throughout. The spleen becomes congested, which leads to hypersplenism and increased sequestration of platelets. Portal hypertension is responsible for most severe complications of cirrhosis.  Diagnosis  The gold standard for diagnosis of cirrhosis is a liver biopsy, through a percutaneous, transjugular, laparoscopic, or fine-needle approach. A biopsy is not necessary if the clinical, laboratory, and radiologic data suggests cirrhosis. Furthermore, there is a small but significant risk to liver biopsy, and cirrhosis itself predisposes for complications due to liver biopsy. Ascites, low platelet count, and spider nevi are useful physical findings."

Ascites, low platelet count, and spider nevi are useful physical findings."

If the cause is removed at this stage, the changes are still fully reversible. 589b7ed5-ff30-4c28-978b-058c400ea8b9@18@consequence@outcome@1@effect,outcome,result,event,issue,import,moment,@"Cirrhosis is an outcome of chronic liver disease characterized by replacement of liver tissue by fibrosis, scar tissue and regenerative nodules (lumps that happen as a result of a process in which damaged tissue reforms). This results in loss of liver function. Cirrhosis is usually caused by alcohol addiction, hepatitis B and C, and fatty liver disease, but has many other possible causes. Some cases are idiopathic (i.e., cause is not known).  Ascites (retaining fluid in the abdominal cavity) is the most common complication of cirrhosis, and is linked with a poor quality of life, increased risk of infection, and a poor long-term result. Other potentially life-threatening complications are hepatic encephalopathy (confusion and coma) and bleeding from esophageal varices. Cirrhosis is generally irreversible, and treatment usually focuses on preventing progression and complications. In advanced stages of cirrhosis the only choice is a liver transplant.  The word "cirrhosis" comes from Greek ?????? [kirrhós] meaning yellow, tawny (the orange-yellow color of the diseased liver) + Eng. med. suff. -osis. While the clinical entity was known before, it was René Laennec who gave it the name "cirrhosis" in his 1819 work in which he also describes the stethoscope.  Pathophysiology  The liver plays a critical role in forming proteins (e.g., albumin, clotting factors and complement), detoxifying and storing (e.g., vitamin A). In addition, it participates in the metabolism of lipids and carbohydrates.  Cirrhosis is often preceded by hepatitis and fatty liver (steatosis), independent of the cause. If the cause is taken away at this stage, the changes are still fully reversible.  The pathological hallmark of cirrhosis is the development of scar tissue that replaces normal parenchyma, stopping the portal flow of blood through the organ and disturbing normal function. Recent research shows the pivotal role of the stellate cell, a cell type that usually stores vitamin A, in the development of cirrhosis. Damage to the hepatic parenchyma leads to activation of the stellate cell, which becomes contractile (called myofibroblast) and blocks blood flow in the circulation. In addition, it releases TGF-?1, which results in a fibrotic response and proliferation of connective tissue. Furthermore, it secretes TIMP 1 and 2, naturally occurring inhibitors of matrix metalloproteinases, which prevents them from breaking down fibrotic material in the extracellular matrix.  The fibrous tissue bands (septa) separate liver cell nodules, which eventually replace the whole liver architecture, leading to reduced blood flow throughout. The spleen becomes congested, which leads to hypersplenism and increased sequestration of platelets. Portal high blood pressure is responsible for most serious complications of cirrhosis.  Diagnosis  The gold standard for diagnosis of cirrhosis is a liver biopsy, through a percutaneous, transjugular, laparoscopic, or fine-needle approach. A biopsy is not necessary if the clinical, laboratory, and radiologic data indicate cirrhosis. Furthermore, there is a small but important risk to liver biopsy, and cirrhosis itself predisposes for complications due to liver biopsy. Ascites, low platelet count, and spider nevi are useful physical findings."
589b7ed5-ff30-4c28-978b-058c400ea8b9@18@fibrosis@fibrosis@0@[fibr] [osis] :	[fiber] [a condition, disease or increase],@"Cirrhosis is an outcome of chronic liver disease characterized by replacement of liver tissue by fibrosis, scar tissue and regenerative nodules (lumps that happen as a result of a process in which damaged tissue reforms). This results in loss of liver function. Cirrhosis is usually caused by alcohol addiction, hepatitis B and C, and fatty liver disease, but has many other possible causes. Some cases are idiopathic (i.e., cause is not known).  Ascites (retaining fluid in the abdominal cavity) is the most common complication of cirrhosis, and is linked with a poor quality of life, increased risk of infection, and a poor long-term result. Other potentially life-threatening complications are hepatic encephalopathy (confusion and coma) and bleeding from esophageal varices. Cirrhosis is generally irreversible, and treatment usually focuses on preventing progression and complications. In advanced stages of cirrhosis the only choice is a liver transplant.  The word "cirrhosis" comes from Greek ?????? [kirrhós] meaning yellow, tawny (the orange-yellow color of the diseased liver) + Eng. med. suff. -osis. While the clinical entity was known before, it was René Laennec who gave it the name "cirrhosis" in his 1819 work in which he also describes the stethoscope.  Pathophysiology  The liver plays a critical role in forming proteins (e.g., albumin, clotting factors and complement), detoxifying and storing (e.g., vitamin A). In addition, it participates in the metabolism of lipids and carbohydrates.  Cirrhosis is often preceded by hepatitis and fatty liver (steatosis), independent of the cause. If the cause is taken away at this stage, the changes are still fully reversible.  The pathological hallmark of cirrhosis is the development of scar tissue that replaces normal parenchyma, stopping the portal flow of blood through the organ and disturbing normal function. Recent research shows the pivotal role of the stellate cell, a cell type that usually stores vitamin A, in the development of cirrhosis. Damage to the hepatic parenchyma leads to activation of the stellate cell, which becomes contractile (called myofibroblast) and blocks blood flow in the circulation. In addition, it releases TGF-?1, which results in a fibrotic response and proliferation of connective tissue. Furthermore, it secretes TIMP 1 and 2, naturally occurring inhibitors of matrix metalloproteinases, which prevents them from breaking down fibrotic material in the extracellular matrix.  The fibrous tissue bands (septa) separate liver cell nodules, which eventually replace the whole liver architecture, leading to reduced blood flow throughout. The spleen becomes congested, which leads to hypersplenism and increased sequestration of platelets. Portal high blood pressure is responsible for most serious complications of cirrhosis.  Diagnosis  The gold standard for diagnosis of cirrhosis is a liver biopsy, through a percutaneous, transjugular, laparoscopic, or fine-needle approach. A biopsy is not necessary if the clinical, laboratory, and radiologic data indicate cirrhosis. Furthermore, there is a small but important risk to liver biopsy, and cirrhosis itself predisposes for complications due to liver biopsy. Ascites, low platelet count, and spider nevi are useful physical findings."

This results in loss of liver function. Cirrhosis is usually caused by alcohol addiction, hepatitis B and C, and fatty liver disease, but has many other possible causes. Some cases are idiopathic (i.e., cause is not known).  Ascites (retaining fluid in the abdominal cavity) is the most common complication of cirrhosis, and is linked with a poor quality of life, increased risk of infection, and a poor long-term result. Other potentially life-threatening complications are hepatic encephalopathy (confusion and coma) and bleeding from esophageal varices. Cirrhosis is generally irreversible, and treatment usually focuses on preventing progression and complications. In advanced stages of cirrhosis the only choice is a liver transplant.  The word "cirrhosis" comes from Greek ?????? [kirrhós] meaning yellow, tawny (the orange-yellow color of the diseased liver) + Eng. med. suff. -osis. While the clinical entity was known before, it was René Laennec who gave it the name "cirrhosis" in his 1819 work in which he also describes the stethoscope.  Pathophysiology  The liver plays a critical role in forming proteins (e.g., albumin, clotting factors and complement), detoxifying and storing (e.g., vitamin A). In addition, it participates in the metabolism of lipids and carbohydrates.  Cirrhosis is often preceded by hepatitis and fatty liver (steatosis), independent of the cause. If the cause is taken away at this stage, the changes are still fully reversible.  The pathological hallmark of cirrhosis is the development of scar tissue that replaces normal parenchyma, stopping the portal flow of blood through the organ and disturbing normal function. Recent research shows the pivotal role of the stellate cell, a cell type that usually stores vitamin A, in the development of cirrhosis. Damage to the hepatic parenchyma leads to activation of the stellate cell, which becomes contractile (called myofibroblast) and blocks blood flow in the circulation. In addition, it releases TGF-?1, which results in a fibrotic response and proliferation of connective tissue. Furthermore, it secretes TIMP 1 and 2, naturally occurring inhibitors of matrix metalloproteinases, which prevents them from breaking down fibrotic material in the extracellular matrix.  The fibrous tissue bands (septa) separate liver cell nodules, which eventually replace the whole liver architecture, leading to reduced blood flow throughout. The spleen becomes congested, which leads to hypersplenism and increased sequestration of platelets. Portal high blood pressure is responsible for most serious complications of cirrhosis.  Diagnosis  The gold standard for diagnosis of cirrhosis is a liver biopsy, through a percutaneous, transjugular, laparoscopic, or fine-needle approach. A biopsy is not necessary if the clinical, laboratory, and radiologic data indicate cirrhosis. Furthermore, there is a small but important risk to liver biopsy, and cirrhosis itself predisposes for complications due to liver biopsy. Ascites, low platelet count, and spider nevi are useful physical findings."
589b7ed5-ff30-4c28-978b-058c400ea8b9@18@retention@Use verb form: retain@1@keeping,holding,memory,Use verb form: retain,@"Cirrhosis is an outcome of chronic liver disease characterized by replacement of liver tissue by fibrosis, scar tissue and regenerative nodules (lumps that happen as a result of a process in which damaged tissue reforms). This results in loss of liver function. Cirrhosis is usually caused by alcohol addiction, hepatitis B and C, and fatty liver disease, but has many other possible causes. Diagnosis  The gold standard for diagnosis of cirrhosis is a liver biopsy, through a percutaneous, transjugular, laparoscopic, or fine-needle approach. A biopsy is not necessary if the clinical, laboratory, and radiologic data indicate cirrhosis. Furthermore, there is a small but important risk to liver biopsy, and cirrhosis itself predisposes for complications due to liver biopsy. Ascites, low platelet count, and spider nevi are useful physical findings."
589b7ed5-ff30-4c28-978b-058c400ea8b9@18@yellowish@yellow@1@yellow,@"Cirrhosis is an outcome of chronic liver disease characterized by replacement of liver tissue by fibrosis, scar tissue and regenerative nodules (lumps that happen as a result of a process in which damaged tissue reforms). This results in loss of liver function. Cirrhosis is usually caused by alcohol addiction, hepatitis B and C, and fatty liver disease, but has many other possible causes. Some cases are idiopathic (i.e., cause is not known).  Ascites (retaining fluid in the abdominal cavity) is the most common complication of cirrhosis, and is linked with a poor quality of life, increased risk of infection, and a poor long-term result. Other potentially life-threatening complications are hepatic encephalopathy (confusion and coma) and bleeding from esophageal varices. Cirrhosis is generally irreversible, and treatment usually focuses on preventing progression and complications. In advanced stages of cirrhosis the only choice is a liver transplant.  The word "cirrhosis" comes from Greek ?????? [kirrhós] meaning yellow, tawny (the orange-yellow color of the diseased liver) + Eng. med. suff. -osis. While the clinical entity was known before, it was René Laennec who gave it the name "cirrhosis" in his 1819 work in which he also describes the stethoscope.  Pathophysiology  The liver plays a critical role in forming proteins (e.g., albumin, clotting factors and complement), detoxifying and storing (e.g., vitamin A). In addition, it participates in the metabolism of lipids and carbohydrates.  Cirrhosis is often preceded by hepatitis and fatty liver (steatosis), independent of the cause. If the cause is taken away at this stage, the changes are still fully reversible.  The pathological hallmark of cirrhosis is the development of scar tissue that replaces normal parenchyma, stopping the portal flow of blood through the organ and disturbing normal function. Recent research shows the pivotal role of the stellate cell, a cell type that usually stores vitamin A, in the development of cirrhosis. Damage to the hepatic parenchyma leads to activation of the stellate cell, which becomes contractile (called myofibroblast) and blocks blood flow in the circulation. In addition, it releases TGF-?1, which results in a fibrotic response and proliferation of connective tissue. Furthermore, it secretes TIMP 1 and 2, naturally occurring inhibitors of matrix metalloproteinases, which prevents them from breaking down fibrotic material in the extracellular matrix.  The fibrous tissue bands (septa) separate liver cell nodules, which eventually replace the whole liver architecture, leading to reduced blood flow throughout. The spleen becomes congested, which leads to hypersplenism and increased sequestration of platelets. Portal high blood pressure is responsible for most serious complications of cirrhosis.  Diagnosis  The gold standard for diagnosis of cirrhosis is a liver biopsy, through a percutaneous, transjugular, laparoscopic, or fine-needle approach. A biopsy is not necessary if the clinical, laboratory, and radiologic data indicate cirrhosis. Furthermore, there is a small but important risk to liver biopsy, and cirrhosis itself predisposes for complications due to liver biopsy. Ascites, low platelet count, and spider nevi are useful physical findings."

Damage to the hepatic parenchyma leads to activation of the stellate cell, which becomes contractile (called myofibroblast) and blocks blood flow in the circulation. In addition, it releases TGF-?1, which results in a fibrotic response and proliferation of connective tissue. Furthermore, it secretes TIMP 1 and 2, naturally occurring inhibitors of matrix metalloproteinases, which prevents them from breaking down fibrotic material in the extracellular matrix.  The fibrous tissue bands (septa) separate liver cell nodules, which eventually replace the whole liver architecture, leading to reduced blood flow throughout. The spleen becomes congested, which leads to hypersplenism and increased sequestration of platelets. Portal high blood pressure is responsible for most serious complications of cirrhosis.  Diagnosis  The gold standard for diagnosis of cirrhosis is a liver biopsy, through a percutaneous, transjugular, laparoscopic, or fine-needle approach. A biopsy is not necessary if the clinical, laboratory, and radiologic data indicate cirrhosis. Furthermore, there is a small but important risk to liver biopsy, and cirrhosis itself predisposes for complications due to liver biopsy. Ascites, low platelet count, and spider nevi are useful physical findings."
589b7ed5-ff30-4c28-978b-058c400ea8b9@18@blocking@stop@1@stop,block off,block up,bar,jam,stuff,close up,forget,blank out,@"Cirrhosis is an outcome of chronic liver disease characterized by replacement of liver tissue by fibrosis, scar tissue and regenerative nodules (lumps that happen as a result of a process in which damaged tissue reforms). This results in loss of liver function. Cirrhosis is usually caused by alcohol addiction, hepatitis B and C, and fatty liver disease, but has many other possible causes. Some cases are idiopathic (i.e., cause is not known).  Ascites (retaining fluid in the abdominal cavity) is the most common complication of cirrhosis, and is linked with a poor quality of life, increased risk of infection, and a poor long-term result. Other potentially life-threatening complications are hepatic encephalopathy (confusion and coma) and bleeding from esophageal varices. Cirrhosis is generally irreversible, and treatment usually focuses on preventing progression and complications. In advanced stages of cirrhosis the only choice is a liver transplant.  The word "cirrhosis" comes from Greek ?????? [kirrhós] meaning yellow, tawny (the orange-yellow color of the diseased liver) + Eng. med. suff. -osis. While the clinical entity was known before, it was René Laennec who gave it the name "cirrhosis" in his 1819 work in which he also describes the stethoscope.  Pathophysiology  The liver plays a critical role in forming proteins (e.g., albumin, clotting factors and complement), detoxifying and storing (e.g., vitamin A). In addition, it participates in the metabolism of lipids and carbohydrates.  Cirrhosis is often preceded by hepatitis and fatty liver (steatosis), independent of the cause. If the cause is taken away at this stage, the changes are still fully reversible.  The pathological hallmark of cirrhosis is the development of scar tissue that replaces normal parenchyma, stopping the portal flow of blood through the organ and disturbing normal function. Recent research shows the pivotal role of the stellate cell, a cell type that usually stores vitamin A, in the development of cirrhosis. Damage to the hepatic parenchyma leads to activation of the stellate cell, which becomes contractile (called myofibroblast) and blocks blood flow in the circulation. In addition, it releases TGF-?1, which results in a fibrotic response and proliferation of connective tissue. Furthermore, it secretes TIMP 1 and 2, naturally occurring inhibitors of matrix metalloproteinases, which prevents them from breaking down fibrotic material in the extracellular matrix.  The fibrous tissue bands (septa) separate liver cell nodules, which eventually replace the whole liver architecture, leading to reduced blood flow throughout. The spleen becomes congested, which leads to hypersplenism and increased sequestration of platelets. Portal high blood pressure is responsible for most serious complications of cirrhosis.  Diagnosis  The gold standard for diagnosis of cirrhosis is a liver biopsy, through a percutaneous, transjugular, laparoscopic, or fine-needle approach. A biopsy is not necessary if the clinical, laboratory, and radiologic data indicate cirrhosis. Furthermore, there is a small but important risk to liver biopsy, and cirrhosis itself predisposes for complications due to liver biopsy. Ascites, low platelet count, and spider nevi are useful physical findings."

Some cases are idiopathic (i.e., cause is not known). While the clinical entity was known before, it was René Laennec who gave it the name "cirrhosis" in his 1819 work in which he also describes the stethoscope.  Pathophysiology  The liver plays a critical role in forming proteins (e.g., albumin, clotting factors and complement), detoxifying and storing (e.g., vitamin A). In addition, it participates in the metabolism of lipids and carbohydrates.  Cirrhosis is often preceded by hepatitis and fatty liver (steatosis), independent of the cause. If the cause is taken away at this stage, the changes are still fully reversible.  The pathological hallmark of cirrhosis is the development of scar tissue that replaces normal parenchyma, stopping the portal flow of blood through the organ and disturbing normal function. Recent research shows the pivotal role of the stellate cell, a cell type that usually stores vitamin A, in the development of cirrhosis. Damage to the hepatic parenchyma leads to activation of the stellate cell, which becomes contractile (called myofibroblast) and blocks blood flow in the circulation. In addition, it releases TGF-?1, which results in a fibrotic response and proliferation of connective tissue. Furthermore, it secretes TIMP 1 and 2, naturally occurring inhibitors of matrix metalloproteinases, which prevents them from breaking down fibrotic material in the extracellular matrix.  The fibrous tissue bands (septa) separate liver cell nodules, which eventually replace the whole liver architecture, leading to reduced blood flow throughout. The spleen becomes congested, which leads to hypersplenism and increased sequestration of platelets. Portal high blood pressure is responsible for most serious complications of cirrhosis.  Diagnosis  The gold standard for diagnosis of cirrhosis is a liver biopsy, through a percutaneous, transjugular, laparoscopic, or fine-needle approach. A biopsy is not necessary if the clinical, laboratory, and radiologic data indicate cirrhosis. Furthermore, there is a small but important risk to liver biopsy, and cirrhosis itself predisposes for complications due to liver biopsy. Ascites, low platelet count, and spider nevi are useful physical findings."
589b7ed5-ff30-4c28-978b-058c400ea8b9@18@severe@serious@1@hard,serious,high grade,grade high,@"Cirrhosis is an outcome of chronic liver disease characterized by replacement of liver tissue by fibrosis, scar tissue and regenerative nodules (lumps that happen as a result of a process in which damaged tissue reforms). This results in loss of liver function. Cirrhosis is usually caused by alcohol addiction, hepatitis B and C, and fatty liver disease, but has many other possible causes. Some cases are idiopathic (i.e., cause is not known).  Ascites (retaining fluid in the abdominal cavity) is the most common complication of cirrhosis, and is linked with a poor quality of life, increased risk of infection, and a poor long-term result. Other potentially life-threatening complications are hepatic encephalopathy (confusion and coma) and bleeding from esophageal varices. Cirrhosis is generally irreversible, and treatment usually focuses on preventing progression and complications. In advanced stages of cirrhosis the only choice is a liver transplant.  The word "cirrhosis" comes from Greek ?????? [kirrhós] meaning yellow, tawny (the orange-yellow color of the diseased liver) + Eng. med. suff. -osis. While the clinical entity was known before, it was René Laennec who gave it the name "cirrhosis" in his 1819 work in which he also describes the stethoscope.  Pathophysiology  The liver plays a critical role in forming proteins (e.g., albumin, clotting factors and complement), detoxifying and storing (e.g., vitamin A). In addition, it participates in the metabolism of lipids and carbohydrates.  Cirrhosis is often preceded by hepatitis and fatty liver (steatosis), independent of the cause. If the cause is taken away at this stage, the changes are still fully reversible.  The pathological hallmark of cirrhosis is the development of scar tissue that replaces normal parenchyma, stopping the portal flow of blood through the organ and disturbing normal function. Recent research shows the pivotal role of the stellate cell, a cell type that usually stores vitamin A, in the development of cirrhosis. Damage to the hepatic parenchyma leads to activation of the stellate cell, which becomes contractile (called myofibroblast) and blocks blood flow in the circulation. In addition, it releases TGF-?1, which results in a fibrotic response and proliferation of connective tissue. Furthermore, it secretes TIMP 1 and 2, naturally occurring inhibitors of matrix metalloproteinases, which prevents them from breaking down fibrotic material in the extracellular matrix.  The fibrous tissue bands (septa) separate liver cell nodules, which eventually replace the whole liver architecture, leading to reduced blood flow throughout. The spleen becomes congested, which leads to hypersplenism and increased sequestration of platelets. Portal high blood pressure is responsible for most serious complications of cirrhosis.  Diagnosis  The gold standard for diagnosis of cirrhosis is a liver biopsy, through a percutaneous, transjugular, laparoscopic, or fine-needle approach. A biopsy is not necessary if the clinical, laboratory, and radiologic data indicate cirrhosis. Furthermore, there is a small but important risk to liver biopsy, and cirrhosis itself predisposes for complications due to liver biopsy. Ascites, low platelet count, and spider nevi are useful physical findings."

A biopsy is not necessary if the clinical, laboratory, and radiologic data indicate cirrhosis. Ascites, low platelet count, and spider nevi are useful physical findings."

fd0f15a6-7494-4067-9ca2-ece2456c55f7@1@rare@rare@0@not very often,@"Polycythemia vera is a rare, chronic disorder involving the overproduction of blood cells in the bone marrow (myeloproliferation). The overproduction of red blood cells is most dramatic. But the production of white blood cells and platelets are also elevated in most cases. Since red blood cells are overproduced in the marrow, this leads to abnormally high numbers of circulating red blood cells (red blood mass) within the blood. Consequently, the blood thickens and increases in volume, a condition called hyperviscosity. Thickened blood may not flow through smaller blood vessels properly. A variety of symptoms can occur in individuals with polycythemia vera including nonspecific symptoms such as headaches, fatigue, weakness, dizziness or itchy skin; an enlarged spleen (splenomegaly); a variety of gastrointestinal issues; and the risk of blood clot formation, which may prevent blood flow to vital organs. More than 90 percent of individuals with polycythemia vera have a mutation of the JAK2 gene. The exact role of this mutation in the development of polycythemia vera is not yet known.  Polycythemia vera belongs to a group of diseases known as the myeloproliferative disorders (MPDs). Three other disorders are commonly classified as MPDs: chronic myeloid leukemia, essential thrombocythemia and idiopathic myelofibrosis.  "
fd0f15a6-7494-4067-9ca2-ece2456c55f7@1@chronic@chronic@0@[chron] [ic] :	[chron] [pertaining to],@"Polycythemia vera is a rare, chronic disorder involving the overproduction of blood cells in the bone marrow (myeloproliferation). The overproduction of red blood cells is most dramatic. But the production of white blood cells and platelets are also elevated in most cases. Since red blood cells are overproduced in the marrow, this leads to abnormally high numbers of circulating red blood cells (red blood mass) within the blood. Consequently, the blood thickens and increases in volume, a condition called hyperviscosity. Thickened blood may not flow through smaller blood vessels properly. A variety of symptoms can occur in individuals with polycythemia vera including nonspecific symptoms such as headaches, fatigue, weakness, dizziness or itchy skin; an enlarged spleen (splenomegaly); a variety of gastrointestinal issues; and the risk of blood clot formation, which may prevent blood flow to vital organs. Three other disorders are commonly classified as MPDs: chronic myeloid leukemia, essential thrombocythemia and idiopathic myelofibrosis.  "

Polycythemia vera belongs to a group of diseases known as the myeloproliferative disorders (MPDs). Three other disorders are commonly classified as MPDs: chronic myeloid leukemia, essential thrombocythemia and idiopathic myelofibrosis.  "
fd0f15a6-7494-4067-9ca2-ece2456c55f7@1@rare@rare@0@not very often,@"Polycythemia vera is a rare, chronic disorder involving the overproduction of blood cells in the bone marrow (myeloproliferation). The overproduction of red blood cells is most dramatic. But the production of white blood cells and platelets are also elevated in most cases. Since red blood cells are overproduced in the marrow, this leads to abnormally high numbers of circulating red blood cells (red blood mass) within the blood. Consequently, the blood thickens and increases in volume, a condition called hyperviscosity. Thickened blood may not flow through smaller blood vessels properly. A variety of symptoms can occur in individuals with polycythemia vera including nonspecific symptoms such as headaches, fatigue, weakness, dizziness or itchy skin; an enlarged spleen (splenomegaly); a variety of gastrointestinal issues; and the risk of blood clot formation, which may prevent blood flow to vital organs. More than 90 percent of individuals with polycythemia vera have a mutation of the JAK2 gene. The exact role of this mutation in the development of polycythemia vera is not yet known.  Polycythemia vera belongs to a group of diseases known as the myeloproliferative disorders (MPDs). Three other disorders are commonly classified as MPDs: chronic myeloid leukemia, essential thrombocythemia and idiopathic myelofibrosis.  "

fd0f15a6-7494-4067-9ca2-ece2456c55f7@1@(@(@0@null@"Polycythemia vera is a rare, chronic disorder involving the overproduction of blood cells in the bone marrow (myeloproliferation). The overproduction of red blood cells is most dramatic. But the production of white blood cells and platelets are also elevated in most cases. Since red blood cells are overproduced in the marrow, this leads to abnormally high numbers of circulating red blood cells (red blood mass) within the blood. Consequently, the blood thickens and increases in volume, a condition called hyperviscosity. Thickened blood may not flow through smaller blood vessels properly. A variety of symptoms can occur in individuals with polycythemia vera including nonspecific symptoms such as headaches, fatigue, weakness, dizziness or itchy skin; an enlarged spleen (splenomegaly); a variety of gastrointestinal issues; and the risk of blood clot formation, which may prevent blood flow to vital organs. More than 90 percent of individuals with polycythemia vera have a mutation of the JAK2 gene. The exact role of this mutation in the development of polycythemia vera is not yet known.  Polycythemia vera belongs to a group of diseases known as the myeloproliferative disorders (MPDs). Three other disorders are commonly classified as MPDs: chronic myeloid leukemia, essential thrombocythemia and idiopathic myelofibrosis.  "
fd0f15a6-7494-4067-9ca2-ece2456c55f7@1@a @a @0@null@"Polycythemia vera is a rare, chronic disorder involving the overproduction of blood cells in the bone marrow (myeloproliferation). The overproduction of red blood cells is most dramatic. But the production of white blood cells and platelets are also elevated in most cases. Since red blood cells are overproduced in the marrow, this leads to abnormally high numbers of circulating red blood cells (red blood mass) within the blood. Consequently, the blood thickens and increases in volume, a condition called hyperviscosity. Thickened blood may not flow through smaller blood vessels properly. A variety of symptoms can occur in individuals with polycythemia vera including nonspecific symptoms such as headaches, fatigue, weakness, dizziness or itchy skin; an enlarged spleen (splenomegaly); a variety of gastrointestinal issues; and the risk of blood clot formation, which may prevent blood flow to vital organs. More than 90 percent of individuals with polycythemia vera have a mutation of the JAK2 gene. The exact role of this mutation in the development of polycythemia vera is not yet known.  Polycythemia vera belongs to a group of diseases known as the myeloproliferative disorders (MPDs). Three other disorders are commonly classified as MPDs: chronic myeloid leukemia, essential thrombocythemia and idiopathic myelofibrosis.  "

The overproduction of red blood cells is most dramatic. But the production of white blood cells and platelets are also elevated in most cases. Since red blood cells are overproduced in the marrow, this leads to abnormally high numbers of circulating red blood cells (red blood mass) within the blood. Consequently, the blood thickens and increases in volume, a condition called hyperviscosity. Thickened blood may not flow through smaller blood vessels properly. A variety of symptoms can occur in individuals with polycythemia vera including nonspecific symptoms such as headaches, fatigue, weakness, dizziness or itchy skin; an enlarged spleen (splenomegaly); a variety of gastrointestinal issues; and the risk of blood clot formation, which may prevent blood flow to vital organs. More than 90 percent of individuals with polycythemia vera have a mutation of the JAK2 gene. The exact role of this mutation in the development of polycythemia vera is not yet known.  Polycythemia vera belongs to a group of diseases known as the myeloproliferative disorders (MPDs). Three other disorders are commonly classified as MPDs: chronic myeloid leukemia, essential thrombocythemia and idiopathic myelofibrosis.  "
fd0f15a6-7494-4067-9ca2-ece2456c55f7@1@essential@essential@0@all important,@"Polycythemia vera is a rare, chronic disorder involving the overproduction of blood cells in the bone marrow (myeloproliferation). The overproduction of red blood cells is most dramatic. But the production of white blood cells and platelets are also elevated in most cases. Since red blood cells are overproduced in the marrow, this leads to abnormally high numbers of circulating red blood cells (red blood mass) within the blood. fd0f15a6-7494-4067-9ca2-ece2456c55f7@2@affecting@involve@1@impact,bear upon,bear on,touch on,involve,regard,@"Polycythemia vera is a rare, chronic condition that involves the overproduction of blood cells in the bone marrow (called: myeloproliferation). Overproducing red blood cells is most dramatic. But the production of white blood cells and platelets are also higher in most cases. Since red blood cells are overproduced in the marrow, this results in abnormally high numbers of  red blood cells (red blood mass) going around within the blood. Consequently, the blood thickens and increases in volume, a condition called hyperviscosity. Thickened blood may not flow through smaller blood vessels in the right way. A variety of symptoms can happen in someone with polycythemia vera including not specific symptoms such as headaches, lack of energy, feeling weak, dizzy spells or itching skin; an enlarged spleen (called: splenomegaly); a variety of issues with the stomach; and the risk of blood clots forming, which may prevent blood flow to critical organs. More than 90 percent of people with polycythemia vera have a genetic change of the JAK2 gene. The exact role of this genetic change in the development of polycythemia vera is not yet known.  Polycythemia vera belongs to a group of conditions known as the myeloproliferative disorders (called: MPDs). Three other conditions are usually classified as MPDs: chronic myeloid leukemia (cancer of the blood), essential thrombocythemia (with increased plately count) and idiopathic (with unknown origin) myelofibrosis.  "
fd0f15a6-7494-4067-9ca2-ece2456c55f7@2@dramatic@dramatic@0@[drama] [tic] :	[play] [pertaining to],@"Polycythemia vera is a rare, chronic condition that involves the overproduction of blood cells in the bone marrow (called: myeloproliferation). A variety of symptoms can happen in someone with polycythemia vera including not specific symptoms such as headaches, lack of energy, feeling weak, dizzy spells or itching skin; an enlarged spleen (called: splenomegaly); a variety of issues with the stomach; and the risk of blood clots forming, which may prevent blood flow to critical organs. More than 90 percent of people with polycythemia vera have a genetic change of the JAK2 gene. The exact role of this genetic change in the development of polycythemia vera is not yet known.  Polycythemia vera belongs to a group of conditions known as the myeloproliferative disorders (called: MPDs). Three other conditions are usually classified as MPDs: chronic myeloid leukemia (cancer of the blood), essential thrombocythemia (with increased plately count) and idiopathic (with unknown origin) myelofibrosis. fd0f15a6-7494-4067-9ca2-ece2456c55f7@3@rare@rare@0@not very often,@"Pemphigus is a general term for a group of rare autoimmune blistering skin disorders. Autoimmune disorders occur when the body's own immune system mistakenly attacks healthy tissue. The symptoms and severity associated with the various forms of pemphigus vary. All forms of pemphigus are characterized by the development of blistering eruptions on the outer layer of the skin (epidermis). In pemphigus vulgaris, lesions also develop on the mucous membranes such as those lining the inside the mouth. Mucous membranes are the thin, moist coverings of many of the body's internal surfaces. If left untreated, pemphigus will usually be fatal. The exact cause of pemphigus is unknown.  The term pemphigus is a general term for a group of related autoimmune blistering skin diseases. The two main types of pemphigus are pemphigus vulgaris and pemphigus foliaceus. Each type has subtypes. Additional disorders are sometimes classified as pemphigus including paraneoplastic pemphigus and pemphigus IgA. Some physicians consider these disorders similar, yet distinct, autoimmune blistering disorders with different causes and clinical, immunological and microscopic tissue (histological) features. Pemphigoid is a general term for a different group of skin disorders. These other disorders are discussed in the related disorders section of this report.  "
fd0f15a6-7494-4067-9ca2-ece2456c55f7@3@autoimmune@autoimmune@0@[auto] [immune] :	[self] [resistant],@"Pemphigus is a general term for a group of rare autoimmune blistering skin disorders. fd0f15a6-7494-4067-9ca2-ece2456c55f7@3@disorders@diseases@1@diseases,condition,@"Pemphigus is a general term for a group of rare autoimmune blistering skin disorders. Autoimmune disorders occur when the body's own immune system mistakenly attacks healthy tissue. The symptoms and severity associated with the various forms of pemphigus vary. All forms of pemphigus are characterized by the development of blistering eruptions on the outer layer of the skin (epidermis). In pemphigus vulgaris, lesions also develop on the mucous membranes such as those lining the inside the mouth. Mucous membranes are the thin, moist coverings of many of the body's internal surfaces. If left untreated, pemphigus will usually be fatal. The exact cause of pemphigus is unknown.  The term pemphigus is a general term for a group of related autoimmune blistering skin diseases. The two main types of pemphigus are pemphigus vulgaris and pemphigus foliaceus. Each type has subtypes. Additional disorders are sometimes classified as pemphigus including paraneoplastic pemphigus and pemphigus IgA. Some physicians consider these disorders similar, yet distinct, autoimmune blistering disorders with different causes and clinical, immunological and microscopic tissue (histological) features. Pemphigoid is a general term for a different group of skin disorders. These other disorders are discussed in the related disorders section of this report.  "
fd0f15a6-7494-4067-9ca2-ece2456c55f7@3@occur@happen@1@happen,come about,@"Pemphigus is a general term for a group of rare autoimmune blistering skin disorders. Autoimmune disorders occur when the body's own immune system mistakenly attacks healthy tissue. The symptoms and severity associated with the various forms of pemphigus vary. All forms of pemphigus are characterized by the development of blistering eruptions on the outer layer of the skin (epidermis). In pemphigus vulgaris, lesions also develop on the mucous membranes such as those lining the inside the mouth. Mucous membranes are the thin, moist coverings of many of the body's internal surfaces. Additional disorders are sometimes classified as pemphigus including paraneoplastic pemphigus and pemphigus IgA. fd0f15a6-7494-4067-9ca2-ece2456c55f7@3@mucous@mucous@0@mucus,portion of mucus,mucus layer,@"Pemphigus is a general term for a group of rare autoimmune blistering skin disorders. Autoimmune disorders occur when the body's own immune system mistakenly attacks healthy tissue. The symptoms and severity associated with the various forms of pemphigus vary. All forms of pemphigus are characterized by the development of blistering eruptions on the outer layer of the skin (epidermis). In pemphigus vulgaris, lesions also develop on the mucous membranes such as those lining the inside the mouth. Mucous membranes are the thin, moist coverings of many of the body's internal surfaces. If left untreated, pemphigus will usually be fatal. The exact cause of pemphigus is unknown.  The term pemphigus is a general term for a group of related autoimmune blistering skin diseases. The two main types of pemphigus are pemphigus vulgaris and pemphigus foliaceus. Each type has subtypes. Additional disorders are sometimes classified as pemphigus including paraneoplastic pemphigus and pemphigus IgA. Some physicians consider these disorders similar, yet distinct, autoimmune blistering disorders with different causes and clinical, immunological and microscopic tissue (histological) features. Pemphigoid is a general term for a different group of skin disorders. These other disorders are discussed in the related disorders section of this report.  "

fd0f15a6-7494-4067-9ca2-ece2456c55f7@3@clinical@clinical@0@[clinic] [al] :	[clinic] [pertaining to],@"Pemphigus is a general term for a group of rare autoimmune blistering skin disorders. Autoimmune disorders occur when the body's own immune system mistakenly attacks healthy tissue. The symptoms and severity associated with the various forms of pemphigus vary. All forms of pemphigus are characterized by the development of blistering eruptions on the outer layer of the skin (epidermis). In pemphigus vulgaris, lesions also develop on the mucous membranes such as those lining the inside the mouth. Mucous membranes are the thin, moist coverings of many of the body's internal surfaces. If left untreated, pemphigus will usually be fatal. The exact cause of pemphigus is unknown.  The term pemphigus is a general term for a group of related autoimmune blistering skin diseases. The two main types of pemphigus are pemphigus vulgaris and pemphigus foliaceus. Each type has subtypes. Additional disorders are sometimes classified as pemphigus including paraneoplastic pemphigus and pemphigus IgA. Some physicians consider these disorders similar, yet distinct, autoimmune blistering disorders with different causes and clinical, immunological and microscopic tissue (histological) features. Pemphigoid is a general term for a different group of skin disorders. These other disorders are discussed in the related disorders section of this report.  "
fd0f15a6-7494-4067-9ca2-ece2456c55f7@3@immunological@immunological@0@[immunologic] [al] :	[immunological] [pertaining to],@"Pemphigus is a general term for a group of rare autoimmune blistering skin disorders. Autoimmune disorders occur when the body's own immune system mistakenly attacks healthy tissue. The symptoms and severity associated with the various forms of pemphigus vary. All forms of pemphigus are characterized by the development of blistering eruptions on the outer layer of the skin (epidermis). In pemphigus vulgaris, lesions also develop on the mucous membranes such as those lining the inside the mouth. Mucous membranes are the thin, moist coverings of many of the body's internal surfaces. If left untreated, pemphigus will usually be fatal. The exact cause of pemphigus is unknown.  The term pemphigus is a general term for a group of related autoimmune blistering skin diseases. The two main types of pemphigus are pemphigus vulgaris and pemphigus foliaceus. Each type has subtypes. Additional disorders are sometimes classified as pemphigus including paraneoplastic pemphigus and pemphigus IgA. Some physicians consider these disorders similar, yet distinct, autoimmune blistering disorders with different causes and clinical, immunological and microscopic tissue (histological) features. Pemphigoid is a general term for a different group of skin disorders. These other disorders are discussed in the related disorders section of this report.  "

In pemphigus vulgaris, lesions also develop on the mucous membranes such as those lining the inside the mouth. Mucous membranes are the thin, moist coverings of many of the body's internal surfaces. If left untreated, pemphigus will usually be fatal. The exact cause of pemphigus is unknown.  The term pemphigus is a general term for a group of related autoimmune blistering skin diseases. The two main types of pemphigus are pemphigus vulgaris and pemphigus foliaceus. Each type has subtypes. Additional disorders are sometimes classified as pemphigus including paraneoplastic pemphigus and pemphigus IgA. fd0f15a6-7494-4067-9ca2-ece2456c55f7@4@immune@immune@0@resistant,@"Pemphigus is a general term for a group of autoimmune blistering skin diseases that is not very often found. Autoimmune disorders happen when the body's own immune system mistakenly attacks healthy tissue. The symptoms and intensity linked with the various sorts of pemphigus vary. All forms of pemphigus are characterized by the development of blistering outbreakw on the external layer of the skin (called: epidermis). In pemphigus vulgaris, lesions also develop on the mucous tissue layers (called: membranes) such as those running along the inside the mouth. Mucous membranes are the thin, wet coatings of many of the body's inside surfaces. If not treated, pemphigus will usually result in death. The exact cause of pemphigus is not known.  The term pemphigus is a general term for a group of related autoimmune blistering skin diseases. The two main types of pemphigus are pemphigus vulgaris and pemphigus foliaceus. Each type has subtypes. Additional diseases are from time to time classified as pemphigus including paraneoplastic pemphigus and pemphigus IgA. Some physicians see these diseases as similar, yet different autoimmune blistering diseases with different causes and clinical, immunological and microscopic tissue (histological) features. Pemphigoid is a general term for a different group of skin diseases. These other diseases are talked about in the related diseases section of this report.  "

Each type has subtypes. Additional diseases are from time to time classified as pemphigus including paraneoplastic pemphigus and pemphigus IgA. Some physicians see these diseases as similar, yet different autoimmune blistering diseases with different causes and clinical, immunological and microscopic tissue (histological) features. Pemphigoid is a general term for a different group of skin diseases. These other diseases are talked about in the related diseases section of this report.  "
fd0f15a6-7494-4067-9ca2-ece2456c55f7@8@kinds@kinds@0@sort,@"Pemphigus is a general term for a group of autoimmune blistering skin diseases that is not very often found. Autoimmune diseases come about when the body's own immune system incorrectly attacks healthy tissue. The symptoms and the intensity linked with the various sorts of pemphigus vary. All kinds of pemphigus are characterized by the development of blistering outbreaks on the external layer of the skin (called: epidermis). In pemphigus vulgaris, lesions also develop on the mucous membranes such as those running along the inside the mouth. Mucous membranes are the thin, wet coatings of many of the body's inside surfaces. If not treated, pemphigus will usually result in death. What exactly causes pemphigus is not known.  The term pemphigus is a general term for a group of related autoimmune blistering skin diseases. The two main types of pemphigus are pemphigus vulgaris and pemphigus foliaceus. Each type has subtypes. Additional diseases are from time to time classified as pemphigus including paraneoplastic pemphigus and pemphigus IgA. Some physicians see these diseases as similar, yet different autoimmune blistering diseases with different causes and clinical, immunological and microscopic tissue (histological) features. Pemphigoid is a general term for a different group of skin diseases. These other diseases are talked about in the related diseases section of this report.  "

d7c923c1-75de-44e4-a9de-ed7c3d9d53a0@1@treatment@treatment@0@Use verb form: treat,@"Asthma is a condition in which your airways narrow and swell and produce extra mucus. This can make breathing difficult and trigger coughing, wheezing and shortness of breath.  For some people, asthma is a minor nuisance. For others, it can be a major problem that interferes with daily activities and may lead to a life-threatening asthma attack.  Asthma can't be cured, but its symptoms can be controlled. Because asthma often changes over time, it's important that you work with your doctor to track your signs and symptoms and adjust treatment as needed."

7cecefc8-e626-4fe0-a725-14b127520793@2@mueller@mueller@0@[muelle] [r] :	[muelle] [blood vessels],@"A Mueller-matrix polarimeter in transmission mode using two electronically controlled liquid-crystal variable retarders has been developed. Its design, theory and calibration are described. Although liquid crystals have been proposed earlier, this paper is focused on the process of the calculation of the Mueller matrix by a matrix-inversion method, oriented to static systems and in vitro samples. By driving the retarders with appropriate voltages, nine independent pairs of polarization states can be produced (incomplete polarimetry), while the other additional seven pairs are obtained by placing two quarter-wave plates (in the input and output optical paths respectively). This configuration allows extraction of 16 independent measurements of intensity. The Mueller matrix of the sample is calculated from them. The results of Mueller matrices for air, a linear polarizer and a quarter-wave plate are presented. Additional polarization parameters such as retardation, ellipticity or degree of polarization were also computed and some applications of the system are proposed."

83d28d88-3acb-4ed6-8d1b-82de6122469d@1@overview@overview@0@[ov] [erview] :	[Of or pertaining to the eggs, the ovum] [erview],@"Overview of the Immune System  How it works  The overall function of the immune (resistance) system is to prevent or limit getting infected. An example of this rule is found in eh group of immune-compromised people who are susceptible to a range of microbes that typically do not cause infection in healthy persons. This group includes those with genetic immune diseases, immune-debilitating infections like HIV (the AIDS virus), and even pregnant women.  The immune system can tell apart  normal, healthy cells and unhealthy cells by knowing a variety of "danger" cues called danger-associated molecular patterns (DAMPs). Cells may be unhealthy when they are infected or when they are damaged by non-infectious agents like sunburn or cancer. Infectious microbes such as viruses and bacteria let go of another set of signals known by the immune system called pathogen-associated molecular patterns (PAMPs)."

An example of this rule is found in eh group of immune-compromised people who are susceptible to a range of microbes that typically do not cause infection in healthy persons. This group includes those with genetic immune diseases, immune-debilitating infections like HIV (the AIDS virus), and even pregnant women.  The immune system can tell apart  normal, healthy cells and unhealthy cells by knowing a variety of "danger" cues called danger-associated molecular patterns (DAMPs). Cells may be unhealthy when they are infected or when they are damaged by non-infectious agents like sunburn or cancer. Infectious microbes such as viruses and bacteria let go of another set of signals known by the immune system called pathogen-associated molecular patterns (PAMPs)."

9632d814-d485-4fd5-a6b7-073983c0abf4@1@rigorous@rigorous@0@strict,tight,@"The government’s first rigorous clinical trial of the experimental drug remdesivir as a coronavirus treatment delivered mixed results to the medical community Wednesday — but rallied stock markets and raised hopes that an early weapon to help some patients was at hand.  The preliminary results, disclosed at the White House by Anthony S. Fauci, chief of the National Institute of Allergy and Infectious Diseases, which led the placebo-controlled trial, found that the drug accelerated the recovery of hospitalized patients but had only a marginal benefit in the rate of death.  That falls short of the magic bullet or cure that many were hoping for in Gilead’s drug. But with no approved treatments for Covid-19, Fauci said, it will become the standard of care for hospitalized patients and serve as a key building block as clinicians hone their approach."

864f58c2-d019-4e23-829f-f74ff25e1691@1@vaccines@vaccines@0@vaccine product,@"The work on a new coronavirus vaccine is using new, and less tried out, approaches called "plug and play" vaccines. Because we know the genetic code of the new coronavirus, Sars-CoV-2, we have the complete design for building it.  Research personnel in Oxford have placed small parts of its genetic code into a harmless virus that infects chimpanzees. They hope they have gotten a safe virus that looks enough like the coronavirus to make the immunes system respond.  Other groups are using parts of raw genetic code (materials in our cell, either DNA or RNA depending on the approach) which, one time injected into the body, should start creating bits of viral proteins which the immune system again can learn to fight."

This also moderate-sized left pleural effusion.  HEAD CT:  Head CT showed no intracranial hemorrhage or mass effect, but old infarction consistent with past medical history.  ABDOMINAL CT:  Abdominal CT showed lesions of T10 and sacrum most likely secondary to osteoporosis. These can be followed by repeat imaging as an outpatient. 08f5af45-3525-44a8-a3b9-7107c5064e76@1@airways@airways@0@air passage,air lane,flight path,respiratory tract,@"Asthma is a condition in which your airways narrow and swell and produce extra mucus. This can make breathing difficult and trigger coughing, wheezing and shortness of breath.  For some people, asthma is a minor nuisance. For others, it can be a major problem that interferes with daily activities and may lead to a life-threatening asthma attack.  Asthma can't be cured, but its symptoms can be controlled. Because asthma often changes over time, it's important that you work with your doctor to track your signs and symptoms and adjust treatment as needed."

0c558ce3-cf86-47b3-a799-3a6d610c9887@1@medicine@medicine@0@medical science,drug product,@"Alternative medicine describes any practice that aims to achieve the healing effects of medicine, but which lacks biological plausibility and is untested, untestable or proven ineffective. Complementary medicine (CM), complementary and alternative medicine (CAM), integrated medicine or integrative medicine (IM), and holistic medicine are among many rebrandings of the same phenomenon. Alternative therapies share in common that they reside outside medical science, and rely on pseudoscience. Traditional practices become "alternative" when used outside their original settings without proper scientific explanation and evidence. Frequently used derogatory terms for the alternative are new-age or pseudo, with little distinction from quackery."
